title: I stopped reading
text_review: I managed to get halfway through this book. Thought it somewhat daft but then it leaped into improbability drive. I burst out laughing because it just became ludicrous and then gave up with it. Very, very silly,

title: Stick With It
text_review: Gradually abandoned by her family and shunned by the locals of Barkley Cove,Kya manages to eke out a living in the surrounding swampland.Although she is supported by Jumpin and his wife Mabel from Colored Town,their social status is barely above her own.Kya quickly becomes more at ease with nature than people and her relationships with the opposite sex are traumatic.Delia Owens' rich,descriptive prose gives us a valuable insight into the scenery and wildlife of the region but most importantly the intriguing character of Kya.I gave this four stars because the beginning was painfully slow,the poetry becomes annoying after a time and the timetable of events at the Fire Tower seemed implausible.

title: Boring about a girl walking through mud.
text_review: The blurb of this book suggest an interesting crime thriller with twists and turns along the way. That couldn't be farther from the truth. The book - at least the first 100 pages of it - is just simply a little girl walking through mud. That's it, that's the plot. The dialogue is also horribly written, with the author writing down the pronunciations rather than just the words, essentially making it near impossible to read and understand, which in itself is incredibly frustrating. The murder part does happen, but it's not a big plot point, just randomly placed here and there to act as a break from reading about a girl walking through mud.As said above, I am currently only 100 pages in and already falling asleep every time I pick it up. I can see that the end of Part 1 is in sight, so I will keep going until then at least, but if nothing changes, I'm afraid I will have to stop reading.I don't usually quit on a book, but this one is so dull, frustrating to read and waffles on and on and on that I may just have to make an exception.

title: The most amazing book
text_review: I was so looking forward to this book and I have to say it didn't disappoint.  The story is exceptionally well written.  The Author wraps all the characters around you so they are believable. The story is based around a girl left to survive on her own  deep in the marsh land of the Carolinas, where she has been abandoned, mistrusted  by almost everyone.  She manages to survive through many strife's until, years later,  there is a body found and villagers, not knowing what else to do, point the finger at the Marsh girl they have come to fear over the years ....  I will say, the story had me hooked from page one and it was finished within 24 hours!!!

title: Croak, Croak
text_review: When a female friend I trust recommended this book, I downloaded it without hesitation, but was then overcome by misgivings that I had let myself in for a cloying dose of chick lit. The opening of the novel, written in barely comprehensible Deep Southern dialect, did not reassure me; it almost stopped me in my tracks, but I persevered and did not regret it even though the story line is preposterous. That Kya, a six-year-old girl, would be serially abandoned by her mother, brother and father, leaving her to  bring herself up alone in a swamp while evading the legitimate benign interest of the social services stretches credulity to the limit. However, her history is told with such vim and affection for place and time that one is drawn into the fantasy with the added incentive of having a mystery to solve once the little girl has grown to a woman of twenty-two. The novel switches from the past to present almost every alternate chapter, which helps to sustain interest in both the history and the mystery. Anyone, like me, who has pursued a career in the natural sciences will be drawn to the author‚Äôs portrayal of Kya‚Äôs passion for ecology, which saves her from maddening isolation. There is a lonely corner in everyone‚Äôs life where a Kya-like figure might inhabit, and her sexual awakening is described in such painfully frank and realistic detail that it helps to reconnect suspended belief. The patient detective work and the courtroom drama are also well woven into the narrative. However, there was too great a tendency in the novel towards exaggerated wish fulfilment to avoid the taste of saccharine overwhelming my sensitive palate. Amongst other things, abandoned and deprived children almost never thrive, vanishingly few amateur naturalists (Jane Goodall being the exception) outshine the professionals and not all people from ethnic minorities are warm and generous; to imply otherwise does injustice to reality. Moreover, the outcome of the mystery is so telegraphed that it becomes more of a whydunnit than a whodunnit. After all, Where the Crawdads Sing is politically correct chick lit, albeit extremely well-crafted and endearing even to an old curmudgeon like me.

title: Why is it that everybody thinks this book is so good?
text_review: Let‚Äôs take the positive to start with.  The swampy meandering prose conveys a good sense of place.BUT, the characterisation is is universally unappealing and unconvincing.  As a result, you end up not caring what happens next.  The coming of age theme has the smuttiness normally associated with such a theme.  The ethology theme seems artificial and too clever by half.  This is a contrived book written, I suspect, for people who would want to think that they are lapping up a flavour of the swamps and marshes of North Carolina without ever straying from the air conditioned comfort of their strictly tarmac-ed existences.  I don‚Äôt normally complain about lack of authenticity in novels - novels are fiction after all - but this is pretentious un-authenticity!

title: Nicely written.
text_review: I enjoyed most of this book, and it was nicely written so it was quite easy to ignore some of the more irritating things, like constant head-hopping, and the fact that the main character's situation was a bit far-fetched. Her sudden change from wild child to (quite prim) author of brilliantly-received books was a bit of a jump; I'd have preferred to have read a little more about how it happened, that might have made it more believable. I thought that was brushed aside too quickly, and meant I didn't really experience it the way a reader should.The murder storyline held me for a while, but ultimately it was no surprise when I found the 'twist.' It was kind of telegraphed.The characters, which should have been the driving force behind what seemed like a literary novel at first, were mostly flat and cliched;  that was a disappointment; much more could have been made of them, which would have enriched the reading experience. The brother coming and going was a bit pointless and went nowhere, and the white-hat/black-hat aspect of the two young men in Kya's life was another cliche that brought the rating down.The writing was often startlingly good, there were many sentences which really sang, but overall it all felt a bit cobbled together, and the intrigue felt shoe-horned in. Also it did feel a bit like a nature lesson at times, with the descriptions nicely done but unnecessary, and delivered in a very lecture-like way. Not as they'd be viewed from the 'Swamp Girl's' perspective.Overall then, I liked the writing, and the premise was promising, but I don't think it quite delivered in the end.

title: Quite weak
text_review: Was highly recommended by most people yet I ploughed through wishing it would end.Very unrealistic ending and an overall story not believable at all.Probably more suitable for high school reading.

title: Not well written!
text_review: Pretty awful!

title: A unique and moving first novel
text_review: Wow..‚Ä¶..this first novel really has polarised opinion!  I read it because it was recommended by a friend.  If I had seen the reviews first ‚Äì especially the US ones ‚Äì I might not have bothered.  I am extremely glad that I did.They say you should write what you know ‚Äì  for your first attempt at least ‚Äì  and that is just what Delia Owens has done with Where the Crawdads Sing.  The book is therefore a mix of story, poetry, murder-mystery and expert scientific understanding of fauna and flora.  I found it to be a fascinating combination.The story line is ambitious, with two simultaneous timelines ‚Äì the earlier one stretching over the years from 1952 onwards, and the second starting at 1969.  The first line gradually catches up with the second, until they merge into a satisfying denouement.I would agree with those who say that the story ‚Äì of a little girl abandoned to fend for herself in the marshland of North Carolina and her subsequent emergence into an expert in her scientific field, despite only one day at school in her life ‚Äì is highly unlikely‚Ä¶‚Ä¶  but so what?  This is, after all, a work of fiction which draws on the rich imagination of the author, coupled with her own knowledge and experience.  Many of the best works of fiction go beyond likelihood ‚Äì look at most of Dickens‚Äô novels ‚Äì and thank goodness they do.I wonder if the American readers found it hard to take the portrayal of prejudice against the main character and of racism in general, which we all know was endemic at that time.  The British have learned to regard the constant criticism of their colonial past with the composure of a people confident in their long and largely illustrious history.  Perhaps the more recently rooted Americans need longer to cease trying to prove themselves.  For whatever the reason, I was shocked to see the thousands who agreed with the vitriol of some of the US reviewers.Do read this book.  It is totally unique.  It is at times very moving, and it is a superb first novel.

title: Where the Crawdads Sing is a deep and moving novel that I have no doubt I will forever remember.
text_review: It is a mind-blowingly poignant debut and easily one of the best books I have read so far in 2020. This is exactly the kind of novel that will the first in my mind when I think of recommendations.The story begins with a six-year old girl living in a shack by the marshes and swamps, near the coast of North Carolina. Though she faces many disheartening and painful traumas from a young age, Kya matures into a beautiful and intelligent young woman. She learns to become industrious, relying on her talents and knowledge of the marshland to survive. However, after years of fending for herself, Kya has a natural guard up, save for a small number of trustworthy allies‚Ä¶ and the gulls. The town of Barkley Cove labels her the ‚ÄòMarsh Girl‚Äô, and all eyes point to Kya when ‚Äògolden boy‚Äô Chase is found dead among the everglades.I love Kya‚Äôs independence. She‚Äôs a character that‚Äôs incredibly easy to connect to, even as a reader I found myself feeling protective over this young girl. While she is sensitive and timid, she has a fierceness that‚Äôs admirable. And her courage, agility and intuition add to her brilliance as a protagonist. I also deeply appreciate the way the author interweaved poetry with Kya‚Äôs thoughts and emotions. Furthermore, the significance of poetry to the principal figure plays out magnificently. When reading, Kya feels so real it‚Äôs almost natural to smile or frown when she does.Secondary characters, like Tate, Jumpin‚Äô, Mabel and Jodie infused life into the tale of Kya. They‚Äôre an additional layer to this charming coming of age story. The characters‚Äô reflections and musings have an emotive depth that makes each of them feel earnestly human. But above all, Kya is the extraordinary personality, and one I‚Äôd happily revisit.Owens‚Äô rich and eloquent reflection on humanity paints a vivid picture from the first page. The author‚Äôs passion and understanding of nature is evident in her splendidly descriptive poetic prose. As a zoologist, the author‚Äôs fascination with ethology becomes addictive. In Where the Crawdads Sing, Kya develops a love of collecting shells and feathers as she grows up. Correspondingly, Owens turns from an author to an artist as she creates a world that‚Äôs easy to dive into and fun to explore.Her writing floats between a thick intensity and an empathetic calmness that makes it near-impossible to forget. I found the atmosphere of 1960s North Carolina effortless to imagine. Owens‚Äô expertise and familiarity of the natural world also gave me a refreshing outlook on life and value. While the plot of Where the Crawdads Sing is very impassioned and rousing, it‚Äôs the author‚Äôs elegantly revealing voice that will remain sharp in my mind.Where the Crawdads Sing is in two sections, Part I ‚Äì The Marsh, and Part II ‚Äì The Swamp. The chapters alternate between 1952 and the murder trial in 1970. With each chapter, the years grow closer, while the tension and uncertainty deepen. As a reader, my heart was pounding during the final chapters the same way I imagine Kya‚Äôs was. It‚Äôs truly a gripping and exhilarating read.And although the narrative is written in the third person, the tone never feels shallow. Where the Crawdads Sing has the qualities of a run-of-the-mill murder mystery. But what makes it stand out is the emotive power and alluring rhythm. The story slowly draws you in, the emotion keeps you hooked, and the characters create the connection. It‚Äôs the recipe for a perfect plot, and exceeds all my expectations.Originally, this isn‚Äôt a book I originally planned on reviewing. Where the Crawdads Sing has suffered the curse of being stuck on the TBR list for way too long. But when I think of this novel now, I only wonder why I didn‚Äôt read it sooner. It‚Äôs a moving and inspiring story about survival against the odds. Themes of family, love, prejudice, poverty and loneliness are insightfully explored in this truly gripping story. There is diversity in the characters, the style and the emotion. It‚Äôs not only a novel that will have you sobbing by the last page, but also stuck in awe and wonder at the natural beauty of Delia Owens‚Äô words and descriptions.‚ÄúGo as far as you can ‚Äì way out yonder where the crawdads sing.‚ÄùAnika | chaptersofmay.com

title: A novel of two parts ...
text_review: As a former North Carolina resident, I was looking forward to reading this novel.  At the start it did not disappoint.  Early on, I cared so much about Kya's fate that I had to take a peek at the book's end to see if she survived!  However, about  two-thirds of the way through I began to notice a change.  From chapter 30  Kya began quoting the mediocre poetry of "Amanda Hamilton", whom she had never mentioned before.  These passages added nothing to the book and were so irritating that I gave up reading them.  There were also longer passages of dialogue, whose language seemed to me unnatural and stilted.  Would a reunited backwoods brother and sister really talk to one another like two professors discussing an academic paper?  The whole "what happened to Ma" scenario was unnecessary and added little to the story,  Kia seemed change overnight from a simple and sensuous nature lover to a respected and erudite academic authority.  Sometimes a book is written in stages and it seemed to me that the marked change in tone could be due to that.  Or was there a new editor at this stage?  However, on the whole,  the nearer I got to the end, the more improbable the plot became and the less I cared about Kia's endless flitting about the marsh, or Big Red, or the Courtroom cat, or Tate's blond curls, or "who killed the Hockey Jock".  Plot holes galore, especially in the unmentioned matter of how many bus tickets would be purchased for TWO return journeys and how Kia become a Master of Disguise .. What began as a five-star read had, sadly, become a two-star by the final page.

title: Unrealistic
text_review: Presents the natural scenery very nicely but when it comes to the characters, it resolves the human part of them in a very simplistic way, sometimes in 1 line, so after describing the swamp in detail, you are left with, whats going on? The whole situation of the main character is unrealistic, from her living conditions, to not going to school and then to becoming an author.... oh well.

title: Mesmerising coming of age story of a lonely young girl living on the marshy North Carolina coast.
text_review: Delia Owen‚Äôs first fictional novel tells the immersive story of the so called ‚ÄúMarsh Girl‚Äù, Catherine Danielle Clark, known as Kya and is an extraordinary story of a young woman‚Äôs survival and self-reliance in the marshy coastland of Barkley Cove, North Carolina.  Delivering Kya‚Äôs heroic journey alone would be enough to fill any book but Owens excels in her descriptions of the vivid setting which I found enlightening and also explores the profound loneliness that sees Kya reach out for a connection and eventually sees her implicated in a murder trial.Spanning 1952 to 1970, Kya‚Äôs story begins as a six-year-old, the youngest of five children living in a shack in the remote marshland of a backwater town.  Accustomed and in tune with the natural world around her she draws comfort from singing to the gulls and exploring the wilderness when her mother abandons her at the age of six, swiftly followed by all four of her siblings.  Left in the company of her truculent drinker of a father she is shown no love and quickly leans to fend for herself and so when he predictably disappears at the age of ten, Kya is left alone and forced to become self-sufficient in order to survive.Derided as swamp trash and traumatised by the experience of a single day at the local school she finds acceptance in the natural world around her and remains alone until she is befriended by sensitive and sincere local teenager, Tate Walker, four years her senior and as drawn to the magic of the marshlands as Kya.  Taught to read and trust by Tate, Kya‚Äôs only other support comes from black husband and wife, Jumpin‚Äô and Mabel, who can empathise with the prejudice she is faced with and to whom her loneliness ie evident.  Abandoned by Tate after he leave for college, Kya retreats further into the world where she is happiest and learns valuable lessons about life in the rhythms, patterns and animal life in her marshy homeland from mating to nurturing their offspring.  Tentatively daring to trust again despite bearing the scars of Tate‚Äôs betrayal, the interest of the handsome but manipulative character of Chase Andrews sees him begin visiting Kya on her own territory and making hollow promises, only for her to eventually learn of his engagement in the local newspaper.The novel opens with the discovery of the body of local golden boy and star quarterback, Chase Andrews, in the marsh in 1969 and Kya‚Äôs story is intercut by the investigation of Sheriff Ed Jackson spurred on by Chase‚Äôs mother who is quick to send them in the ‚Äòmarsh girls‚Äô direction, aided by local rumours and abetted by a string of prejudiced witnesses pointed in the intended direction.Although the likelihood of a ten-year-old being left alone, escaping local authorities and learning to cope without interference is easier to accept in 1960s remote small town America, Kya‚Äôs rapid development from basic reading and arithmetic into self-taught acclaimed naturalist, published author and leading light on the landscape around her really does take some believing.  It would be easy to quibble about the implausibilities of the story and to lament the black and white characterisation which makes it pretty clear from the off who the goodies and baddies in Kya‚Äôs story are but there is something wholly enchanting about Owens story.  Despite reservations, and the predictability of the ending with Kya‚Äôs romantic reunion inevitable and obvious, the suspense around the murder trial and Kya‚Äôs innocence endures until the very last and in the most fitting of tributes, the natural world around her closes ranks to protect her secrets.Tender and emotive I enjoyed the novel for what is was, namely a poignant story of one extraordinary young woman‚Äôs journey against a multitude of obstacles and bigoted options in her way.  The descriptions of nature are illuminating, the setting inspires a mesmerising atmosphere and Kya‚Äôs story is a magical one which will stay with me.

title: Disappointing
text_review: After reading so many positive reviews I had such high hopes for this book but was sadly disappointed. Parts of it are beautifully written and I really enjoyed the descriptions of the marshes, estuaries and animals. This is where Delia Owens knowledge really comes into play. Sadly however, the plot itself I found weak, far fetched and at times ridiculous! A child raises herself alone, from the age of 6 but never gets sick, needs to see a dentist and manages to stay healthy despite eating grits everyday! Not for me

title: A fabulous enigmatic experience.
text_review: I have just finished reading, 'Where the Crawdads Sing' by Delia Owens. A first novel by an American scientist who spent much time in Africa and who has produced several best selling non-fiction books.It tells the tale of a seven year old girl who lives with her family in a tumble down property, situated in marshland. Father is a drunk and is violent towards his wife and children until one by one they all leave. Kya is alone and has to survive. Her story is magical, scarey, gentle, violent and presses all emotional buttons for loads of different reasons. She becomes at one with the birds and learns how to dodge school authorities. She explores the creeks on her small boat and finds a friend in Tate, a young man from the small town. He teaches her to read and write and agently and slowly a love affair emerges. However he leaves for university and Chase begins to call. Not quite so kind.This sounds so ordinary when I read it through, but in fact it is the most wonderful manuscript. Incredibly well written! Unputdownable, for sure! Magnetic with the sea, sky and call of the birds. The author portrays the magical atmosphere of the times so beautifully, even through a murder trial. This is one novel I shall be sure to read over again. Superb.üåüüåüüåüüåüüåü.

title: This book is so badly written it made my teeth hurt
text_review: If a cliche had sex with a box of fondant fancies - this would be the prodgeny.  Possibly the worst book I have ever read. More adjectives than you can throw a pelican at - alliterative adjectives to boot.  How this has become a best seller is beyond me. Appalling, illiterate, non sensical, unrealistic, ill conceived, drivel.

title: This dense limey needs a glossary!
text_review: This book was all over the reviews along with the dreaded words ‚Äúreally popular with book clubs‚Äù.  I tackled it without having a clue what a crawdad was, and I really struggled as a non-American with a lot of the words, dialect and above all the names of the stupendously ghastly sounding poor white southern food. Disclaimer; in the interests of fairness and research I once ate grits.  The best comparison I can make is that it was rather like eating lumpy wallpaper paste.  I do find that some books set in the rural US would benefit foreign readers if they did have a glossary! But that is my problem.  I was also completely mystified by the ubiquitous biscuits that appeared (along with grits) at most meals.  I had to Google in order to work out why one would eat biscuits (as Europeans understand them) with everything!It appears to be very much a marmite book, with some US reviewers pointing out all sorts of things that are simply lost on non-Americans.  They really lay into it about the accents, names, education system, conduct of justice and things that I‚Äôm simply not qualified to comment on.  I noted that the author was a wildlife writer, and that did shine through.  What hit me immediately however was how similar it felt to Barbara Kingsolver‚Äôs Prodigal Summer. This was a lockdown recommend from a friend who loved it and had spent quite a lot of time living in North America.  While I think it was a better novel, more structured, with more layers and a more believable and intricate plot, it didn‚Äôt really float my boat, although I did enjoy it (and had less problems with understanding it!)  But I kept ticking the comparisons.I appreciate that with all the many thousands of reviews out there, writing this is a spurious exercise.  However, I actually enjoyed it quite a lot on a superficial level.  As a novel/whodunnit it might not have been of the first order, and there were gaping plot holes and improbabilities.  As another reviewer has said, being eaten by alligators was clearly too good for the father.  I felt that a point was being made that previously well connected and bourgeois folk could end up at the bottom of the heap, reviled and ignored.  I have no idea how the US social system works (although it did imply that there was one) and whether or not it was wildly unrealistic to have a sort of jungle child who, with the aid of a decent boy, was able to self-educate to professorial levels.  I suspect highly unlikely.  Like the heroine in Prodigal Summer, Kya had supernatural abilities when it came to identifying random bird feathers and was of course an expert tracker, and naturalist, as well as being wildly beautiful with amazing hair (check again Prodigal Summer!)I liked the fact that the Sheriff and his side kick were thorough, meticulous and as it turned out, right! They could have been portrayed as ignorant swamp town hicks.  All right, they failed to make a watertight case, but the magically appearing pro bono ace lawyer was the one who really did for them.It wasn‚Äôt a terribly good book, but that didn‚Äôt stop me guiltily enjoying it and not being that surprised at the reveal.  I kind of guessed a crawdad might have some connection to crayfish, so that‚Äôs a new piece of natural knowledge I‚Äôve gained at any rate. I‚Äôd briefly travelled down the Outer Banks, and been to a couple of American swamp areas, so I enjoyed the nature descriptions and was surprised at being told the age of most of the buildings in the settlements. Then I remembered Roanoke and the earliest settlers.  Not really a 4 star book, but I enjoyed it more than 3, so 3 and a half if I could.  Lots of people will enjoy it.

title: Good read, but does not bear too much plot analysis
text_review: There are so many things to like about this book - interesting setting, well-written characters, absorbing plot, lyrical writing.  Such a pity, then, that it is spoilt by a weak denouement to the murder mystery, with a storyline that has so many holes it could be crocheted. Some of them are so easily remedied that the Editor ought to be taken and shot (ok - extreme, just a turn of phrase.) Also,  Amanda Hamilton's 'poetry' should have been left out. The character Amanda Hamilton adds nothing to the plot, her poetry is woeful and when it is quoted it feels as shoe-horned-in as an Abba song in Mama Mia (the movie).  Again, the Editor should have dealt with this (kindly). These few tweaks could have made the difference between Where the Crawdads Sing becoming a modern classic in the style of To Kill a Mockingbird (yup, that good) and simply being a mass-market pot-boiler, which is what it is, sadly.

title: It‚Äôs trite
text_review: I hated this book pretty much from the beginning....it‚Äôs a ridiculous premise and in no way reads as either possible or probable...Everything about it was annoying, important issues skated over or dealt with in a couple of paragraphs then never mentioned again and the characters were completely cliche.The only people I would recommend this to are hormonal teenagers...perhaps not even them..

title: Incredibly overhyped
text_review: Novel is easy to read but so unrealistic that I could not suspend disbelief. Odd portrayals of responses to trauma and lots of tired literary tropes used.

title: Dreadful
text_review: After all the rave reviews I was so looking forward to this book. The gushing praise for the writer's lyrical descriptions of nature had me hoping for something akin to Thomas Hardy. What I actually got was Virginia Andrews on a bad day. Clunky, unrealistic dialogue, thinly drawn, 1D characters and cliche upon cliche that made me almost cringe myself inside out. Huge disappointment.

title: Interesting read
text_review: I very much enjoyed the wonderful descriptions of the landscapes and coastal scenery of North Carolina.  There were detailed descriptions of the flora and fauna, and Delia Owens is obviously passionate about this and very knowledgeable.  I was not so keen on the story, although I felt it was just about feasible, but really it was a vehicle for  an in depth look at the ecology of the area.  I warmed to Kya, but felt it was very unlikely that without any formal education she would have become, not only an expert re her homeland, but also a famous author and something of a classics scholar too.  Just stretching the bounds of credibility a bit far.  Also I was shocked by the twist at the end, though I should have expected it - others in the book group thought it was quite predictable.

title: A beautiful and moving book
text_review: The Introduction, set in 1969, has a poetic description of the marshes and swamps near the coast of North Carolina ‚Äì a foretaste of many other poetic descriptions of nature in the novel. It also ends with the discovery of the corpse of one Chase Andrews in a swamp, and that is a foretaste of a murder mystery.The chapters alternate between the times following the discovery of the body and times after 1952, in which the first chapter is set.The central figure of the novel is Kya (Catherine) Clark, at this point aged six, the youngest of five children.  Kya‚Äôs father is a violent drunk, and her much-loved mother, who was educated and a painter, could no longer stand his attacks.  She left, abandoning her children.  Kya‚Äôs four elder siblings also cannot stand their father, and, before long, they leave also, (including Jodie, her favourite brother), leaving Kya alone with her father; and he was almost always out, playing poker and drinking whisky and, in 1956, when Kya was ten, he disappeared altogether.  The truant officers had taken to school, but she hated being with so many people and attended only one day, and later hid from the truant officers until they gave up.Her loneliness is in part self-inflicted:  she is frightened of most other people (except for the friendly black couple who ran a local store), and tends to hide herself from them.  She is illiterate, but she loves, and is knowledgeable about, all the fauna and flora around her, and she had a fine collection of feathers, shells and other such objects, and had done wonderful drawings and paintings of them.She made a little money for her barest necessities by collecting and selling sacksful of mussels.Back in 1953 she had come across Tate Walker, then aged eleven, who shared her enthusiasm for the fauna and flora of the marshes.  Seven years later, he gently courted the timid girl, and she responded. He tactfully taught her to read, and even to appreciate poetry, and the book has her reciting many poems by heart.  She read voraciously, especially scientific books about nature. When, at the age of fifteen,  she has her first period cramps, it is Tate who has to explain to  her what they are.  There is a tender awakening of physical love between them. Out of respect for her youth, Tate did not go the whole way, though both of them longed for it.  And then he had to go away to college to study biology.  He promised to be back at Thanksgiving ‚Äì but he never turned up.  Now her loneliness was the worst of heart aches.Four years passed; she is now nineteen. She was then spotted by Chase Andrews, the handsome village Lothario. He, too, courted her, and eventually she responded to his advances. They now met frequently. After a year, he talked of marrying her, and then she surrendered her virginity to him. And then she saw in a local newspaper the announcement of his engagement to another woman. This did not stop him, when next they ran across each other, from trying to rape her, and she only escaped after a violent struggle.Tate had reappeared to warn her about Chase, and things now seem to improve for her. Tate persuaded her to let him send some of her nature pictures to a publisher, who was enthusiastic; and for  the first time she had a fair amount of money and was able to modernize her shack.She showed her gratitude to Tate, of course; but the hurt he had caused her meant that she could still not trust him;  and often she hid when she saw him rowing in the marsh.All seems to be going well ‚Äì but all this while we have had chapters about how the sheriff and his deputy have been looking for clues who might have killed Chase.  Though Kya seems to have an alibi for the night Chase died, the clues seem to point towards Kya, and in 1969 she was charged with his murder.  We are about two-thirds through the book.I must not reveal what happened from then onwards, except to say that at the very end, after Kya has died in 2010 at the age of 64, we learn two astonishing things about her.Some of the few negative reviews of this book have said that in many ways it is hard to believe in it ‚Äì and I agree. But if you can suspend your occasional disbelief, this is a quite wonderful, beautiful and moving book.

title: Beautifully Descriptive Writing, Coupled with Unique & Memorable Characters!
text_review: Wow. This book has some of the most beautiful writing I‚Äôve read in a while. The descriptions are so rich, and they actually move the story along. I was easily pulled inside the story, into the marsh. The mystery of Chase Andrews was kind of secondary to everything else.The themes of loneliness, abandonment, isolation run through the whole book, and there are times when Kya just breaks your heart. She is so fragile, so vulnerable; but she is also incredibly strong and brave. I love her. She‚Äôs a great protagonist. Jumpin‚Äô is fab, also. He really looks out for Kya. And, Tate. Ahh, lovely Tate. As well as being a story about loneliness, it‚Äôs also a love story that is wonderful to watch as it unfolds.I absolutely loved this book. It is full of unique and memorable characters. The writing is first class. The descriptions, out of this world. A fantastic book, through and through!

title: Wish I had never bothered to invest my time and emotions.
text_review: Fell for the hype, and was initially surprised by how much I actually loved this book.  However, I have never been so disappointed by the ending of a novel.  For me it made everything that had gone before seem like a total con-trick, and it all turned to ashes - what a waste of time, seriously don't bother.

title: Disappointed, given it's popularity
text_review: I‚Äôm afraid that ‚ÄúWhere the Crawdads Sing‚Äù, did very little for me. I wondered at first if it was the place I was at in myself but I don‚Äôt think so. I found a lot of the descriptive passages, which at first and on the surface seemed beautiful, become more contrived as the novel went on. That soon started to irritate me. The young girl Kya and her life from 7 to 12 just stretched credibility too far for me.  In addition I never found her to be the most sympathetic of characters. The murder mystery aspect was fine but all in all the book disappointed me.

title: The worst ‚ÄúGreat Book‚Äù I have ever read
text_review: It‚Äôs a lesson I still haven‚Äôt. A book with Great Hype does not make a Great Book. Crawdads is the perfect example. 17,000+ reviews on Amazon.com. A rating of 4.8. It has to be an excellent book. Surely. No. This is a poor book, flimsily constructed with weak characters and an implausible plot.Although targeted at adults, it‚Äôs basically a Young Adult Coming-of-Age Romance with only three characters. Kya, a girl who at six years old is abandoned by her mother and then a few years later by her father too and therefore has to fend for herself in the swamps of North Carolina. Tate (perfect body, dark eyes, golden hair), is a young boy from the local town who falls in love with her and teaches her to read. And Chase (perfect body, dark eyes, but DARK hair), is a young boy from the local town who falls in love with her and whose body is later discovered at the bottom of a fire tower amid suspicious circumstances. So who killed Chase? In a book with only three characters, and one of them is dead, that doesn‚Äôt leave a lot of room for surprises.The book is also totally unbelievable. Tate teaches Kya English when she‚Äôs 14 years old. A few years later, Kya walks into the town library and asks for the Principles of Organic Chemistry by Geissman, Invertebrate Zoology of the Coastal Marsh by Jones, and Fundamentals of Ecology by Odum! She then writes ‚Äì and has accepted for publication ‚Äì a scientific paper! This is not only implausible but a huge insult to researchers who have had to study hard for years to achieve the same goal.Moreover, she lives by herself in the swamp but never gets ill, never suffers from malnutrition, her boat never breaks down. The dialogue is trite and simplistic. Finally, the minor characters are so weakly drawn as to be invisible. So we have cops who, surprise surprise, like eating donuts, and a clich√©-spewing ‚Äúwise‚Äù African-American woman.I could go on, but I‚Äôve wasted enough time reading this thing. Thankfully I gave up after 51%.

title: Well worth reading.
text_review: I‚Äôve been putting off reading this book as although it‚Äôs been raved about it just didn‚Äôt seem the kind of book I‚Äôd like. I was so wrong, in part it‚Äôs a book about a murder but really it‚Äôs about society, relationships, nature, our environment, social interactions and so much more. It‚Äôs well written, beautifully written and one of those novels that each person will get something different out of, depending on the person reading it and what they personally bring to the experience. Getting a bit deep now but this book was such a pleasure and torture to read that it‚Äôs an experience not just a book and one that keeps popping up in your mind long after you‚Äôve finished it, or should I say devour it as once started it‚Äôs hard to not keep reading even if you really should get to sleep as you have work in the morning.

title: Utter nonsense
text_review: Silly plot, unbelievable characters. Tedious.

title: Cliche ridden ridiculous story
text_review: I read this for a book club, otherwise I would definitely not have finished the book. It was not the quality of writing that I normally read.The story was really unbelieveable. A young girl left to fend for herself in the wilds. Suspending disbelief, the description of her wonderful eyes, gorgeous, long black hair, slender waist was so cliche'ed, and along with the kindly old black man, his fat lovely wife, the tall handsome suitors....really! Had this young girl really been living on the kinds of scavenged foods described, she would have had poor skin and bad teeth! The passage where the young lad was able to inform her about periods was ridiculous! And why didn't she get pregnant?In my view, the only redeeming part was the end when it was revealed that........but I won't spoil it for anyone who might want to read it!

title: Bodice-ripper whodunit that doesn't quite match the hype.
text_review: This period piece murder mystery, albeit being an undeniable page-turner, was a frustrating one to read. I was well aware of the hype, and had friends who rated it highly. For the first 60 or more pages, i was spellbound. I was starting to think it was for real - maybe we had the next Harper Lee on our hands. The story has hallmarks of her style, small town, rather prejudiced southern United States mixed race community, with analogous characters, the heroine child,  handful of good men and women, both black and white, and many of lower character. The courtroom drama.Sadly, after its promising start, it falls into a series of cliched traps which bodice rippers and whodunits often suffer from, the "thrusting manhood" scenes, the manufactured tension, the stereotypes - the plot holes are sometimes glaring. I wont give these away but they are there in abundance. And the lack of credibility. A totally illiterate and innumerate girl auto didacts to PhD level, seemingly within a year or two, assisted by a lad who visits her shack occasionally.The police process described seems patently ridiculous. The denouement is literally on just about the last page , and is manifestly implausible, leaving about 15 major questions unanswered.It's a real shame. This book was actually an enjoyable read, and had the potential to be far greater than it is. It promised so much at first. I believe Owens does have a great deal  of prose talent (although perhaps less poetic talent - the pages are littered with poetaster verse of dubious standard ), but it sometimes descended into routine bodice-ripper and whodunit territory and could sometimes be downright clumsy.Have a go - see whether you agree with me!

title: Destination Hallmark
text_review: I have no doubt whatsoever that this novel will one day inspire a Hallmark film. A beautiful actress will play the feral wild child and start a trend for naming baby girls ‚ÄòKya‚Äô. This is ‚Äòchick lit‚Äô, trying hard to be more. I have no explanation for the overwhelmingly positive reviews on Amazon. Congratulations to Delia Owens who is laughing all the way to the bank!

title: Stunning!
text_review: I finished Where the Crawdads Sing by Delia Owens a couple of weeks ago, and I can‚Äôt stop thinking about it. When I first started reading it, I wasn‚Äôt expecting to be pulled as deeply into the novel as I was, it took me totally by surprise. I was captivated by the story of ‚ÄòThe Marsh Girl,‚Äô and I loved Delia Owen‚Äôs writing, which transports you to the marshland's atmospheric setting.Kya is one of the most memorable characters I‚Äôve come across in a long while. She lives with her family on the outskirts of the nearby town, surrounded by marshland. From a young age, things are tough for Kya. Unable to live with her father any more, her mother abandons her and the rest of the family when Kya is very small. Soon her older siblings follow their mothers lead, leaving Kya alone with her abusive father. But Kya knows her father well, and she manages to co-exist with him over the next few years, until the day when he doesn‚Äôt come back.I felt so frustrated for Kya. I couldn‚Äôt understand why the rest of her family had abandoned her, particularly her siblings, who could have taken her with them. It seemed so unfair that she was the one left behind at such a young age. Because of this, Kya has to grow up first. She has to provide for herself after her father abandons her as well. Kya also becomes the topic of a lot of gossip among the locals. That‚Äôs how she earns the nickname, ‚ÄòThe Marsh Girl.‚ÄôThis novel isn‚Äôt a fast-paced read. When I was reading it, I decided I wanted to take my time with it as I was enjoying the writing so much. We flick backwards and forwards from the late fifties and early sixties to 1969. In 1969 the body of a young man has been found. But we get to learn more about the background of this man in the scenes from earlier years. What is his connection to Kya? I wanted to find out what the connection was, and I wanted to know why he had ended up dead? The police are treating his death as a murder, although some believe it was a tragic accident. But the police want to wrap the case up quickly.There were moments towards the end of this book where I was literally holding my breath as I waited to find out what was going to happen next. Kya was the one character who I rooted for throughout the book. I wanted her to succeed in life and to find someone to spend her life with.Where the Crawdads Sing is a masterpiece, it‚Äôs haunting, and it is beautifully written. It is one of the best novels I‚Äôve read in a long while. I‚Äôm sure I‚Äôll be thinking about this book for a long time to come. I highly, highly recommend it!

title: Fascinating but flawed SPOILERS IN THIS REVIEW
text_review: This book started out with so much promise - the stunning descriptions of the marshland and the extremely likeable character of Kya, the little girl who is abandoned by family and lives alone in a run down shack drew me in easily. But it veers between evocative language that hauls the reader into her world and clunky plotting that made me cringe.She is taught to read in a single session, skipping merrily from being introduced to the alphabet to a complex sentence full of blended phonics, consonant digraphs and modifying vowels. This scene shattered my belief in the story and I started to notice the far-fetched plotting more.The boy who adores her and promises to return changes his mind for the sketchiest of reasons to create a bit of mid-novel tension, then changes it back again for equally unprompted reasons, so that all can end well. It would have taken very little to strengthen this plot strand but it read as though the author was pretty bored by the mechanics of storytelling and just wanted to explore the marshlands without the onerous task of creating a realistic narrative. The dialogue in the love scenes reads as a cut and paste from a Mills & Boon. Characterisation vanishes. And, given this is nominally a murder mystery, the local police are bafflingly dim. Having lived all their lives in swampland, it takes them months to work out that tidal water might have washed away any footprints from the scene of the crime.Despite these criticisms, the landscape is so vivid, so stunning that I felt lost inside it while reading the novel and for that alone, I'm glad the book was recommended to me. Few novels suck you into their world so completely as this one did. The long passages of descriptions of Kya in nature, combatting her loneliness by focusing on the land were really compelling.

title: Beautifully written touching story
text_review: I was aborbed by this book from the moment I started it.  So well written that I could almost smell the sea breeze and hear the gulls above me.  Centres around the tragically lonely life of a child left in her poverty stricken home as one by one her siblings leave her behind.  Her fight for survival is sometimes heartbreaking but sometimes made me chuckle.  I found myself. even sometimes .envying her natural peaceful existence at one with nature.  Of course she ends up tough and  beautiful but her rollercoaster fortunes keep you page turning.  I won't give away the end by it found myself sobbing on my sunbed and eagerly wondering who would pay this fantastic character in the screenplay that has to follow.

title: Where The Crawdads Sing by Delia Owens
text_review: Whilst reading this novel I kept thinking of the book Winter's Bone by Daniel Woodrell. Both stories broke my heart exposing human suffering from cruelty, prejudice and poverty.Kya is a young girl who has brought herself up on the Marshlands.  She avoids school and the authorities by hiding and making up excuses for her parent's absence when fetching supplies from town. She works out who to avoid and who she can go to for help.Even when her family lived with her it was hard. They all suffered terrible violence from their father.  He spent most of his days drinking.  Yet, she still has fond memories of her mother.  The thought of seeing her mother again gets her through life along with her amazing spirit for survival.  We watch her grow up into a beautiful, self sufficient woman.The main plot is about the body of a local man being found and whether or not is was murder.  Kya becomes the main suspect after some of the townsfolk talk to the Sheriff.This is Delia Owen‚Äôs debut novel although she has written wildlife books as an expert scientist. This comes through plentiful in the novel.  If you love learning about nature you will love this. The descriptions are intense and detailed. I had to read them twice sometimes to help me imagine the environment.I related to Kya‚Äôs solitary life. I like my own company and socialising is a nightmare to me too. I would rather curl up in bed with the cat and a book. Socialising is dangerous as people can be harsh and hurtful and I really get that.  The book like Winter‚Äôs Bone reminds us of the poverty going on right under our noses. Maybe like the folk of Barkley Cove we should ask ourselves do we do reach out? or do we judge?In conclusion I would recommend this book if you like description and beautiful writing along with your murder mystery.  Even the book cover is beautiful.  There is plenty of bird and plant life references which makes for an unusual and interesting read.

title: Incredible. A must read.
text_review: A quick scan of my previous reviews (momobookdiary-com) will show that I read crime fiction and romance fiction - rarely much else gets my attention. This book caught my eye on various times and places.  Most recently a friend was reading it and I decided that I too needed to read it.  I knew NOTHING of the book - didn't what it was about, where or when it was set - NOTHING. I liked the cover and many many people were reading and talking about how good it was.  Then I received my copy and saw it was set in 1969 I feared I had made a mistake - I don't read books set in the past.... but I wanted to give it a chance so started reading - and couldn't stop until I reached the end. I am so glad I read this incredible book - and you should too!The author‚Äôs outstanding knowledge and understanding of nature and the natural world is evident by the beautiful descriptive emotional writing.I had tears in my eyes many times throughout the story which pulled at my emotions. Reading the book during the Covid-19 isolation period made the setting of the book seem even more relevant today. This story takes us back to a time when the world moved at a slower pace and right now it feels like the earth is being given a chance to recover whilst we all stop and I think it is much needed - for the earth as much as for us humans.I envisage this novel becoming a 'classic' which will be read again and again in the future. I believe there is a lot we can learn from this novel about the world we live in.  Everyone should read this book.  It is a story of survival, of prejudice, of poverty, of isolation and loneliness, and of nature and humanity. There is mystery. There is love. There is heartache. There is hope.Congratulations Delia Owens on an epic first novel. Thank you for sharing with us this insight into your knowledge and experiences. I look forward to reading your next novel when it is released.... there will be a next one, right?

title: Disappointing
text_review: ‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è starsI caved and read this one even though it‚Äôs never appealed to me but everyone I knew recommended it!It started well and I loved the chapters of Kay as a kid. Even though they were ridiculously implausible (boating and bartering at 7?)But then when she became an adult the book changed for me - too much poetry, too much overly descriptive narrative about nature, birds etc.I couldn‚Äôt gel with any of the main characters but Jumpin & Mabel were great.The Chase storyline just felt off and I truly had no interest in what happened to him.Not for me sorry!!

title: Boring! Disappointing! Unbelievable!
text_review: So, I think the title I‚Äôve given my review says it all. This book is very hard going! The storyline, characters and plot are underdeveloped and unbelievable and I was bored with it early on. I kept going with it, hopeful that it would pull me in and grip me at some point, but the boredom continued right through to the end.  It was a relief to finish it, but it left me feeling disappointed I‚Äôd wasted my time reading it. From the reviews, lots of people have enjoyed reading this book, but if you‚Äôre struggling with it and just hoping it gets better, don‚Äôt bother - it doesn‚Äôt !!

title: Astounding, Extraordinary, Startling
text_review: The writing is so intense, so beautifuly descriptive, not only do you feel like you are with 'Kya' but you 'love' her and want her to be safe and happy with every line.The book takes you over, it becomes the only thing you must do that day 'Read'.The story of survival against the odds, how cruel a society is to 'diffence' and mostly the cost of 'love'.The plants and birds and 'Life' in the Marsh was something that I thought I would rush through, how wrong I was, I slowed down, absorbing all the natural beauty of Delia's words and descriptions.Wonderful book, I brought on my Kindle for 99p, this is a book that I must have sat proudly on my bookshelf, so will now order it and will recommend to all I know!!!

title: Unrealistic clich√©d and predictable.
text_review: Sadly spent a number of hours of my life reading this clich√©d drivel.  Ridiculously unrealistic  to expect a 7 year old to survive alone in a swamp let alone be taught English then biology by a slightly better off boy, fall in love, gets broken heart, ends up being used etc etc. It drags on and on to the inevitable but predictable outcome which I won't spoil but suffice to say that the "murder" plot is also hair brained and lacking in detail. Thoroughly unsatisfactory.

title: The touch of a great writer
text_review: Delia Owens‚Äô "Where the Crawdads sing" is a best-seller. It doesn‚Äôt just say so on the cover : it really is a best-seller, and I am very glad that it should be. It‚Äôs got everything : social consciousness, condemnation of racism, exposure of domestic abuse, a detective story, a court drama, scathing exposure of snobbery, but also displays of generosity, kindness and humanity.The main character is Catherine, nicknamed Kya. She is brutalized by an alcoholic father whom everyone avoids, including her own mother. In the end, she is left to live alone in a shack at the age of six, in the middle of the North Carolina marshes. Somehow, she manages to survive. While doing so, she unwittingly becomes an expert on marshland : its waterways, vegetation, fauna and marine life.You would think that the good, righteous, church-going citizens of Barkley Cove, the nearest small town, would instinctively have organized help for this abandoned child‚Ä¶ Not a bit. She is ‚Äúwhite trash‚Äù, barely above the status of animals. Kya shows up at school, one day, only to be ridiculed and rejected by the other children. The teacher, who could have shown some Christian compassion (makes you wonder if there is such a thing) does nothing to discourage the little bullies. Kya will never go back to school after that. Paradoxically, the only person who develops a soft spot for Kya, is the county truancy officer. She can‚Äôt help admiring the ingenuity and survival skills of the child.Kya grows up alone, with the reputation of a being a wild child. Soon, she is known only as The Marsh Girl, which means, of course, that when a young brutal and arrogant football player is found dead, she becomes the ideal suspect.Two rays of sunshine in her dark life : Tate, a boy who is a few years older than her, and who teaches her how to read and write. There is also a black couple who run a small boat service station cum grocery shop on the wharf.Kya loves, understands and studies the marsh ; to the extent that she manages to have several books published on the subject.What props and sustains the plot and the characters, is Delia Owens‚Äô style. Such beautiful, fluid, poetic prose ! As a reader, you are made to see, hear, smell, taste, touch and feel the mash. To the five senses Delia Owens ads the sixth sense of dreams and exaltation. She is not just a great writer : she is also a scientist. Her style is clear ; the structures of the story are impeccably constructed, all the way to the unexpected twist at the end.We have more than a masterpiece, here : we have what will become an American classic.

title: Kept me reading until the end.
text_review: I have just read a remarkable book by Delia Owens.  Ms Owens is an acclaimed wildlife scientist and has written bestselling non-fiction about her time studying wildlife in Africa.  She uses all her love and knowledge of wildlife to set the scene for her first work of fiction 'Where the Crawdads Sing'.Townspeople in Barkley Cove talk of the Marsh Girl, who is sometimes seen boating along the marshes of the North Carolina coast.  As a child Kya Clark was left abandoned when first her mentally ill mother walked out of the family home, and then subsequently her alcoholic father.  She learns to cook and fend for herself, and grows to love her surroundings and the wildlife that inhabit the marshes.  Illiterate, she collects feathers and shells, but shuns school after attending for just one day and being bullied.One person brings light to her life. A boy, Tate, who also loves the marshlands.  He leaves feathers  for her to add to her collection, and she gradually learns to trust him over many years.  However, circumstances change, and Chase Andrews comes into her life when Kya is grown.What happens to Chase also runs through this book, and adds a 'whodunnit' interest to this story. The townsfolk are against the Marsh Girl, and they instruct their children not to go anywhere near her.  They are sure she had a hand in Chase's ultimate fate.Is Kya just marsh trash, or a poor abandoned soul looking for love?  Have a read of this wonderful book, and you won't be able to put it down.  No wonder it's now being made into a film!

title: Beautiful descriptions and great plot
text_review: This was chosen as my latest bookclub read. I picked it up immediately after reading Shuggie Brown, a story about a child living with harsh neglect and abuse so, at the beginning of this book, it seemed to take a relatively soft approach to Kya's world. I needed a few chapters to settle into what would become a wonderful rhythm within the narrative of the story.Kay's life is guided by the seasons and the natural world around her which is charming and it is clear that the descriptions of nature are a big part of this book. Many of the phrases jump out of the text, one example being "Autumn was coming: the evergreens might not have noticed but the sycamore did"The book is presented as two separate time periods. They don't fit naturally at the start but gradually come closer. They show different perspectives of the same area and they engage the reader in disparate ways. As the plots develop the earlier time catches up and we see more background to the death of Chase Andrews.Poems feature within the narrative as Kya becomes aware of the outside world and its culture. This highlights further the poetic qualities within the regular narrative.At its heart this is a crime story but the descriptions of the natural world raise up the level of the book. The prose are deep and gorgeous, allowing the reader to see the world through Kya's eyes.Wonderfully, there is also a thoroughly satisfying ending which is one of the best compliments that a book can receive.

title: Beautiful poignant story with some minor criticisms
text_review: ‚ÄúWhere the Crawdads Sing‚Äù follows Kya, the ‚ÄòMarsh Girl‚Äô from 1952.She was abandoned by her family as a small child. She survives with gulls for company on the marsh in North Carolina. She is largely shunned by society and faces poverty and loneliness. She survives with limited support from black shop owners Jumpin and his wife Mabel, also a boy called Tate, who luckily looks out for her and later becomes her lover.The story also follows another time line (1969) which starts with the death and possible murder of town golden boy, Chase Andrews.The book covers a child surviving on the marsh, her later limited romantic encounters, a murder mystery and a court- room drama.I absolutely loved the descriptions of nature on the marsh, the vegetation, insects and birds, the mud and the sand‚Ä¶ The marsh permeates the story from start to finish.I also loved Kya‚Äôs spirit throughout the book.She develops a total understanding of her environment, learns to read and eventually to write authoritative scientific books about the marsh.I enjoyed the murder mystery with its‚Äô few possible endings and the court case was well done.I do however have some minor criticisms as I did find some of the story- lines totally implausible. Kya grows into an absolutely beautiful and exceptionally clever young woman‚Ä¶ She is also ‚Äòlucky‚Äô in some ways especially having someone patient enough to teach her to read!!I also found some parts of the book, especially the romance sections, full of clich√©s‚Ä¶.I do however realise that it is fiction and the story is beautifully poignant. It is a book that I won‚Äôt forget. My book group gave it the highest score of any book we have read!!

title: Memorable but not sure I'd recommend it
text_review: I was recommended this book by a friend.  I initially started to read it soon after I bought it but stopped as this sort of book requires time and concentration to read and I was too busy to set aside this time.  However with a second lockdown I picked it up again.  The description of life in the swamps of Carolina is beautifully written.  The description of nature and the wildlife interesting and the author paints the picture well, however I did find myself at times think - ok enough with the description, I can see where and how she lives , now can we continue with the story. The jump forward in time and the little bits of the future story did not seem to match the descriptive writing of Kya's childhood and young adult hood.  It is definitely a book of two halves almost to the point of two voices.  The description and the young life of Kya and then the court case. This is certainly a book that will stick in my memory for a long time but I felt the book as a whole was rather contrived and unbelievable. The fact that this waive manages to survive unaided and become an accomplished author seems a step too far.  I can understand that someone in her position understands the life around her, in her immediate vicinity, the nature she sees but survives so well unaided - perhaps not.  The end maybe has a twist but again it really pushes believability!  I think at best I would say a beautifully written book about the swamp-life but an overly romantic story.

title: Beautifully written
text_review: A beautiful book in so many ways.A book about a young child, Kya, who is abandoned by all those she loves. Her poor, suffering mother (how could she?), and finally all her siblings. She is left with her no good father, an abusive drunk. However, they survive together because they are all they have, until eventually he too leaves and never comes back and Kya is on her own in the family home, little more than a shack on the edges of the marsh. The marsh becomes Kya's salvation and in return, she studies the wildlife and records and documents the creatures that live alongside her.The loneliness and sadness seep out of the pages, 'I burst into tears and sob and sob. I feel so desperately alone.' As does the beauty of the place, 'bark on the tree like dead skin cells.'Kya does eventually have encounters with other people as she grows older and stronger. Some are good and some are not. She even finds love, which comes with its own problems.There is a murder mystery as part of the plot, however who really killed Chase Andrews is secondary to the whole story. This is much more about survival and hope and growth against bigoted views and prejudice. It is a description of the waterways and marsh and the life that teems within and how life survives on the margins.

title: Brilliant.
text_review: Where the Crawdads Sing¬†is going to be one of my top ten books of the year. I can say that with absolute confidence.It is the gorgeous story of Kya Clark who has been utterly let down by life. Everyone has abandoned her and she has been shunned by the local townsfolk. However, she raises herself on the land. It is only when one true friendship comes along that she really begins to change her opinion of and her belief in herself.However, old judgements are always going to plague this town and when a local man ‚Äì celebrated in his teens for being a sports star and the fact that he has come from a well to do family ‚Äì is found dead the finger of blame is firmly pointed at Kya.¬†Where the Crawdads Sing¬†is a beautiful story the looks a small town mentality and how prejudices are formed and sustained. The beautiful lyrical style of Delia Owens‚Äô writing manages to immerse you in the story immediately. I began to read the book more quickly because I needed to know what happened yet I cursed myself for reading it too quickly because I didn‚Äôt want it to end.¬†Where the Crawdads Sing¬†is one of those magical books that makes you feel so much.Where the Crawdads Sing¬†by Delia Owens is available now.

title: Hands down THE BEST BOOK I have read in the last decade! A true literary  journey
text_review: Wow!!!! And i mean WOW!!This has been a revelation of a book! I haven‚Äôt been this emotionally invested in a book in i cant even remember how long!Quite possibly THE BEST BOOK I've read in the LAST DECADE. And believe me, it is a very tough read at times, very very tough, but boy! You truly go on a journey with Kya. I mean WOW.I haven't stayed up late reading a book until the wee hours of the morning, unable to put it down.It has taken my breath away. And even though my smart arse bookworm brain tried to guess the plot and where it would all end, this book definitely didn't follow the usual linear path. The last fee chapters i read holding my breath.Critiquing a book is very much an ambiguous activity for it completely depends on the tastes of the reader.And some may have read this book and found it wanting, but for me, WOW. I will NOT forget it.Its about resilience, survival, connection to nature, human spirit, human nature, discovery, hardship...i could go on....This is a BEFORE and AFTER book for me. Like The Eight by Katherine Neville was over 3 decades ago and Outlander not long after that. One of those books that stays with you forever.Thank you Delia Owens üôèüèº

title: Review
text_review: I've heard a lot about Where The Crawdads Sing this year and I really wanted¬† to see what everyone is talking about for myself. Firstly, Owens' writing is absolutely beautiful and it conjures up wonderful images of the marsh and the lifestyle of Kya and her family which really helped me to connect emotionally with the story. The novel is also peppered with beautiful poetry that definitely increased my ability to picture Kya's surroundings.The reader first meets Kya when she is a young child and the novel follows her journey into adulthood. It did take a while for the story to gel with me, but once it did, I was fully immersed in Kya's life and the emotional turn of events. I loved seeing her grow. There were several moments where I wanted to jump inside the book and give her a hug. She is definitely a character who will stay in my mind long after this review is published.As the plot progressed, I really wanted to know what would happen to Kya, and this makes some parts of the novel very tense. The author certainly gives us a lot to think about, and the ending fits the tone of the whole novel perfectly.

title: My Best Read this Year
text_review: Every now and then I select a book sonewhat removed from the usual categories which make up most of my library. This is one such case and boy am I glad I took a punt.The storyline is captivating and the skill with which it is constructed is peerless. There is such a feeling of sensitivity about the way that Kya`s early life appalling experiences are related that total immersion in her character and her life becomes impossible to avoid.What strikes me as quite remarkable is how she finds beauty and solice amidst her surroundings despite all the negative and life quenching, appalling events and circumstances that surround her.Thankfully, to restore our faith in human nature, there are just one or two hero / heroines who support her with acts of simple human kindness whilst the majority of the township folk and institutions simply turn there back on the little Marsh Girl.I read with pleasure how, with a little help, she finds an avenue for her life's work and along with supported self eduction reaches the pinnacle of published author and renowned expert in her field of study.Yes, she got away with murder, but what other choice did she have?Little to no chance of being believed if she'd tried to bring rape charges against Chase and his clear threat to have the last word, a kill or be killed dilemna.Trouble now is what to follow this book up with that will provide half the reading satisfaction...

title: Where The Author Sings.
text_review: I cannot believe I clicked past this book so many times eventually selecting some second or third rate book. Where The Crawdads Sing is an astonishingly accomplished novel featuring one of the finest drawn characters in literature. Kya is three dimensional and true to life. Her psychology is utterly convincing and, unlike that in lesser books, does not bend and creak to accommodate the story. Her shack stands as an apt image for her character : unassuming on the outside, complex, growing and dynamic on the outside.Some of the imagery is exquisite: " Clouds lazed in the folded arms of the hills" drew an entire landscape for me. The book is full of such gorgeous, stunning, apposite word pictures. There is some poetry in the novel but it is testament to the author's writing that it is less poetic than the prose. I can't emphasis enough: the prose is superb.Delia Owens' day-job expertise subtly permeates the novel, filling out Kya's and the swamp's elemental nature, as well as breathing enchantment, conviction and education into this reader's brain.I suspect the black haired swamp girl will be with me for a long time.

title: Lyrical and profoundly moving
text_review: Unless you have been living under a literary rock for the past few months, I‚Äôm sure you have heard of this book. You‚Äôve probably already read it, as I seem to be a little late to the party but, if not, I suggest you pick up a copy as soon as possible because this is one of the best things I have read for a long while and will definitely be one of my top books of 2020.This is the story of Kya, a young girl abandoned at a young age in the marshes of North Carolina who learns how to survive on her own by studying the wildlife that surrounds her on all sides. Her life is touched by a few souls from the nearby town, but largely she is an outcast, misunderstood and feared by local residents so, when a local man is murdered in the marsh, she is the prime suspect.This book is a masterpiece in so many ways. It begins as a mystery story with the body of the man discovered in the marsh, so we are immediately engrossed in trying to discover, along with the local police, who is responsible. In this way we are introduced to Kya, the ‚ÄòMarsh Girl,‚Äô an outsider who has lived alone in the marsh since she was a child and who is deeply misunderstood by the local townsfolk. The book then runs along two timelines, the current investigation of the murder, and Kya‚Äôs past as she grows up in the marsh. The  mystery is compelling and involves many twists and turns and false paths, so the reader can‚Äôt really know who did it until the very end. However, despite the fact the mystery is well-developed, this is probably the aspect of the novel that drew me the least.The things that make this book so special are the exploration of Kya as a character and how she survives alone in the marsh from childhood and how this life affects her emotionally, and the vivid and immersive descriptions of the landscape and nature of the marsh where the book is set. The author writes so captivatingly and movingly about both that the reader cannot help but be swept away in the story.The development of Kya‚Äôs story from her abandonment by her entire family as a young child and how she has to learn to survive alone in a hostile environment with very little contact with or help from her nearest neighbours is tender, believable and completely heart-breaking. It is a damning commentary on the way society frowns upon anyone who chooses to live a lifestyle outside the mainstream and how such choices invite disdain and a cold-shoulder. How people are largely concerned only with themselves and quick to ignore problems they don‚Äôt want to address. The only people who have the good heart to help Kya are others who are similarly shunned for their differences, or who want to use her for their own ends.Kya is a fascinating and wholly endearing character. Her stalwart determination to survive alone, learning from the creatures that surround her, adapting their habits and survival skills to help her and, in doing so, falling in love with the life and creatures of the marsh and studying them in a way few people ever do. The way the author draws parallels between humans and the wildlife of the marsh and uses those parallels to inform the reader about both is deft and clever. We fall in love with both Kya and her delicate and unique environment and come to care deeply about the survival and protection of both by the end of the book.The marsh, then, is an integral part of the book, as essential to the story as any of the characters. In fact, it becomes a character in its own right, as intricately described and developed as any of the human participants, a living, breathing organism that is vital to Kya‚Äôs happiness and well-being in a way no human has ever been. It is the one thing she loves, trusts and knows will never let her down. Their lives are so intertwined that, when she is forcibly separated from it, it feels like a form of death to her. Like removing a fish from the ocean, she feels like she cannot breathe. If you ever wanted to read a book that really transports you to an environment you have probably never experienced but into which you will completely disappear, this is the novel for you.The writer‚Äôs prose is lyrical and flowing. I know some people have found the book a little slow, and it is true that is is very descriptive and languid, but this is a huge part of the beauty of the novel and, if you stick with it, I am sure you will find the whole story as beautiful, heart-rending but, ultimately, uplifting as I did. The languorous nature of the prose is entirely fitting to the plot and the setting, mirroring the slow, warm, unchanging days in the Carolinas and will envelope you in the mindset if you let it. Just kick back and go with the flow and let this exceptional novel float you on a magical journey that will leave you fundamentally affected by it.

title: very poor
text_review: did not like this book one bit utter rubish

title: Loneliness defeated.
text_review: With over 100000 reviews already published, I am sure that this review will add nothing new. Nonetheless I am glad to add my voice in praise of an exceptional book. Delia Owens is a well respected academic. She has published in "Nature" which is one of the world's leading research journals. She is a renowned naturalist. This knowledge base shines through in "Crawdads." In this, her first novel, the plot is skillfully woven and the descriptions of American marsh land are captivating. The language is a delight. Set in the deep South of America, there are some parallels with "To kill a mocking bird." In essence the story tells of the survival of a young girl when deserted in the middle of swamp land. She does survive, encounters love and becomes an acclaimed author. The book explores the problems of deep South America before black Americans were given their freedom. It details the problems of loneliness and abandonment. It is permeated throughout with a profound love of nature and the relationship between man and creation. A must read book.

title: Absolutely dreadful
text_review: I read this as a book club read, otherwise I would have abandoned it after a few chapters - life is too short!The overall impression is of very immature writing. Steeped in cliche, the prose is amateurish and repetitive. Why it has such rave reviews I cannot imagine. That's several hours of my life I will not get back.I recommend you read just about anything else other than this rubbish.

title: Mixed feelings, but a decent first novel
text_review: I've read a lot of Southern literature and always enjoy finding a new author. Based on glowing tributes, I probably expected too much from this book.The Good: It is written quite well, and as a piece of Southern literature it compares well with more middle-of-the-road authors. The murder mystery aspect is quite well thought-out, and the pattern of flitting between the past and the present is knitted together quite well. The final denouement was handled well. Altogether, a decent summer read.The Bad: At times elements were almost forced into the fiction - the zoology of coastal Carolinas is fascinating, but too often read like a textbook. The "romance" in the middle part of the book was way too Mills & Boon. The coastal vernacular was a bit too patronising, and, I believe inaccurate. Other details about North Carolina were a bit implausible and seemed to have lacked background research. (I lived in the North Carolina coastal plain for 10 years, so know it fairly well).Overall, I'd probably give a second novel a chance, though currently there are many other Southern writers I'd read first.

title: Hearbreakingly beautiful
text_review: This book enveloped me from the start, I have not been able to put it down. I found her characters were well drawn and believable. The protagonist Kya, was a true child of nature. Her early childhood was tough and when she is finally abandoned, Kya finds ways to survive. I find her wholly believable, children can be exceptionally resourceful. The subtle nuances of the storyline, constantly draws parallels between Kya's situation and nature. She is a highly intelligent girl, picking up reading skills from Tate, the young lad who has always been in the fringes of her existence. She goes on to become a leading authority on the flora and fauna of the swamp marshes. What I like is the constant tension of the wildness of Kya, at one with the animals and birds of the swamp, and this other life amongst civilisation where she will never fit in. I find this book inspiring and it is a testament to leaving some habitats and civilisations alone. Kya dealt with the main threat to her way of life, using lessons from nature, she ensured her own safety. I want a hard copy of this book, having it on kindle isn't enough, it was a wonderful read and now I feel like I have said goodbye to an old friend.

title: Captivating.
text_review: A captivating story of a young girl abandoned by her family and shunned by her neighbours. Kya runs native in the marshes and lagoons of her North Carolina home.The depictions of landscape, wildlife, flora and fauna were exquisite. It is no surprise to learn the the author is a renowned naturalist. Kya‚Äôs journey from timid and vulnerable child to wary, unsocialised woman is very well drawn. Her inner life was compellingly believable.I could have done without the crime and courtroom aspects of the story although they were exciting. Kya‚Äôs journey would have been enough for me.The cast of small town characters added colour,  but, with a couple of notable exceptions, the gulls and herons peopled the neighbourhood more sympathetically.
