It did not help that the dialogue came across as stilted and wooden. The writer is clearly more comfortable in a world peopled by nature, the weather, the sea and stars.

title: Richly deserved plaudits
text_review: The plaudits are in, and richly deserved.  It's always interesting, when a debut novel scores this highly, to have a peek at the one star reviews.  In this case, the dissatisfied readers appear to be largely academics who cannot abide the thought of a poorly educated girl becoming largely self taught and finally accepted as a world authority in her subject.  These moaners should be reminded of Mary Anning, a real life girl who, with no education at all to speak of, is now recognised as one of the finest paleontologists of all time.  I too have a couple of minor moans about the Crawdads.  It was careless of the author, in what is otherwise a beautifully crafted novel, to put her heroine in the dock without a shred of evidence against her apart from the suspicions of a few villagers.  This was more Salem than late 20th century justice and I am puzzled by it.  And the poetry, as others have commented, is just dire.

title: Beautiful writing style
text_review: Delia Owens has a uniquely beautiful writing style. Meticulously detailed and picturesque, setting each and every scene to transport the reader into the world of Kya, a young girl living in the Marsh.When she occasionally inserts extracts of poetry she finds ways of evoking thoughts and emotions that even her own beautiful writing could not have achieved. It is breathtakingly genius.Owens takes considerable time to allow the reader to familiarise with the characters of the novel, particularly Kya. This is usually a quality I am drawn to in a novel, but I did feel that the first third of the book gave just a little too much time with Kya and her uneventful surroundings, and I didn‚Äôt engage until the story began moving at a quickened pace.At a guess, I would say that Owens was heavily influenced by one of my favourite novels, To Kill a Mockingbird. I found myself drawing strong parallels between the way in which both authors utilise innocence, naivity and youth to challenge the strong prejudice present in the societies depicted in both novels.Having said that, there was more than one moment where I audibly gasped...so despite the obvious influences, Owens still managed to shock and surprise.This book was oh so almost perfection...with love and heart-ache, strong characterisation, beautifully unique story-telling and an element of mystery and with just a slightly quicker hook at the start I couldn‚Äôt have faulted it.

title: The best book I have read in a long time.
text_review: I  rarely enjoy fiction that is outside crime, police procedural and psychological thrillers. However, I'm so pleased that I followed a recommendation from a friend to read this book. I was engaged from page 1 to the end. The depiction of the swamp land and the life that Kaya was left to live there was spellbinding. The characters were well drawn and the story built to an interesting conclusion. I'm surprised & sorry that this is Delia Owens' s debut novel as I would love to read more. If you are a fan of Barbara Kingsolver then you should enjoy this. A brilliant debut which I cannot praise enough.

title: A beautiful and captivating book
text_review: This is such a beautiful and captivating book. Kya is one of the most interesting and endearing characters I have come across in a novel and I loved following her story from a very young girl right through to the end of her life.Her strength and resilience permeates through the story despite the many challenges she faces, such as fending for herself when members of her family abandon her one by one, being an outsider to other children her age, dealing with the almost mythical "marsh girl" label she is given, the rumours surrounding her and most notably being accused of murder.I loved the beautiful love story at the centre of Kya's narrative which was believable and well constructed and the addition of the "murder mystery" element provided a level of mystery and intrigue which drove the plot forward.A thoroughly enjoyable read and I cannot wait to read more by this author.

title: Sublime. I loved it
text_review: üìöüìöBook review üìöüìöüí´üí´üìöWhere The Crawdads Singüìöüí´üí´ Delia Owens  üí´üí´üìñ Kya Clark has spent most of her life living in the marshes of North Carolina on her own after her family desert her üìñMy heart broke for Kya who from a young age was left by all her family members to fend for herself in a shack on the edge of the marshes in a small community in North Carolina. Her resolve and determination to survive on her own isolated from those around her was so thought provoking.  A few local people help Kya out now and then but most days she spends her time in the marshes with the wildlife and the nature she found there. As she grows she makes friends with Tate who also shares her love of the marshes. He also leaves her to pursue a life and career of his own but the ties they had prove difficult to break. üíïShe then meets Chase and as their relationship grown Kya‚Äôs dreams of love and companionship comes to an abrupt halt. Chase‚Äôs death leads local prejudice against Kya for being different to directly affect her future. By the end of the book we see Kya‚Äôs life lived as she so wanted it to be and she finds comfort and calm from the nature in the environment she so loves.I adored this book, it‚Äôs a coming of age of someone who is different to others but whose passion drives them to find solace and love in nature. I am not surprised the author is a wildlife scientist - the importance of nature in the book is forefront to the story and her passion for that comes across. üêöüå∏.I loved Kya - a resilient, courageous young woman who yearned for those around her to accept her for what she is but ultimately lived  the life she wanted in her younger years without that understanding. She did what she wanted to do and loved what she wanted to love üíì  I think she will stay with me for quite a while ü§óI would give this book üåüüåüüåüüåüüåüüí´a 5 plus star read. ü§óü§ó it is sublime  üòç

title: Riveting reading
text_review: A book that holds your attention from the start. Every time you think the plot is going down an obvious route it surprises you, and each character is beautifully drawn and believable. But over and above everything is the extraordinary detail and observation of the marshland where the central character lives and the descriptions of the wildlife and the atmosphere of the environment. Breathtakingly observant and irresistible even if you are not normally a nature fan. And, yes, I am sure there are people who have survived like Kya in what seems like impossible circumstances but it is powerful stuff.

title: A society misfit overcomes life changing trauma to emerge triumphant
text_review: The story of Kya , the Marsh Girl, abandoned by her family & society at the age of 6. Left to fend entirely for herself in an alien environment , she not only survives but triumphs in life to become a renowned author & scientist. This doesn‚Äôt happen without great personal cost, alienating Kya from anyone who tries to befriend her, engage her, help her.An amazingly evocative story set in a landscape far from a reader‚Äôs experience & sadly , yet again , highlighting American society that rejects anyone outside a perceived norm, even a 6 year old abandoned child. The first people to offer help are themselves marginalised , Jumpin‚Äô & Mabel are black, working class, but even they are not as despised as Kya, their nickname is friendly, hers is a derogatory  term of abuse.Throughout the novel lines of inspirational poetry are quoted & it is only in the last chapter that the source of the poems is revealed.An unforgettable novel , especially as it is Delia Owens first novel.

title: Beautiful Book
text_review: I heard so much about how wonderful this book was, but never really understood what it was about, so here goes...A young girl born into extreme poverty in the 1950‚Äôs America learns to survive. Her life is described along with the nature surrounding her. So beautifully, that you almost envy her. I certainly envied parts of life that she experienced, parts that most of us don‚Äôt see. Woven into the story is a crime that‚Äôs committed, linked to the nearby town, in the 1960‚Äôs. As she grows the stories link together. I loved this book. I loved the story of her life, I felt for her and cared for her. I worried about her, my heart broke and then soared for her. I also learnt interesting facts about firefly‚Äôs and other ‚Äòsneaky f**kers‚Äô, lol üòÇ A must read for anyone who loves to visualise a book and really feel for the characters.

title: Destined to be a modern classic
text_review: Deserves to be up there with To Kill A Mockingbird. Wonderful evocation of the place, using her skills and knowledge from studying wildlife, Delia Owens tells a love story - love of nature, discovering boys - for Kya, a girl who survives in the marshes as her family all leave home to escape a violent father. The prose is immaculate. The story both emotionally tugging as well as absorbing. Ultimately, there is a murder and the investigation and the court scene are conducted well, not spoiling the story but adding a new dimension to it. This is the best book I have read this year (and I have read some crackers). My wife has read it and we are in full agreement over its qualities. I have purchased copies for others, a rare thing for me to do, but I want them to have the same enjoyment I have had.

title: Original writing
text_review: I loved this book, the story refreshingly different, as was the writing.  Delia avoids repeating cliches, she doesn't speak of people walking together in "amicable silence", a cliche I hate, but makes her own words to describe such a scene, as she does with "dust motes in sunlight" another cliche in writing, her own description is original, thereby making the observer's thought authentic.Every character is distinct in appearance and personality as is Sunday Justice the cat who befriended Kya when she refused all contact with a human world but desperately needed a fellow living creature to share her loneliness.  I loved Sunday Justice's way of saying goodbye, and the way his tail told is thoughts.The end is a surprise, but it shouldn't be, the clues were there!

title: Rubbish
text_review: I gave up after 33 pages. The plot is simply too silly: a six-year old left by mother, siblings, father to fend for herself. No grown-ups in village nearby  seem to care a bit. Grown-ups are not that stupid, not in the 50s, not even in the USA.

title: A book for 2020
text_review: I was put off reading this book because of some very bad reviews.  Looking now at the same reviews they are completely unjustified and seem to be deliberately hostile.  My daughter was reading the book and said it was wonderful so I started to read it.  I was drawn in immediately by the language of the characters and could almost hear them speak.  The descriptions of the the marsh drew beautiful  pictures for the reader and the treatment of environmental, class, and race issues was particularly relevant to the present. Equally important was the exploration of domestic abuse and what we would now recognise a PTSD.  The issues in the novel speak loudly to us in 2020 and show how far we still have to go to create equal and sustainable societies.

title: A big hit with our book club
text_review: Our book club, the Gloucestershire Lit Lovers and Yummy Scrummy Pudding Club really loved this month‚Äôs book ‚ÄòWhere the Crawdads Sing‚Äô by Delia Owens. It is a perfect book for anyone who wants to escape from life at the moment (due to Covid-19!) We all imagined being out in Kya‚Äôs boat traveling across the marshes of the Outer Banks of North Carolina, rather than being in self-isolation at home.The main character will win your heart. Abandoned by her family as a young child, Kya learns to fend for herself. The animals and birds become her family, and her reason for going on. We felt quite emotional for her and about her.We totally recommend this beautifully written and atmospheric book, which was set in the 1950s and 60s.

title: Surprising Plot Twist
text_review: This book follows the story of Kya or the ‚ÄòMarsh Girl‚Äô who lives in a quiet town, Barkley Cove. She was abandoned early in life and lives isolated and cast out from society. In 1969, Chase Andrews is found dead, and the locals immediately suspect Kya, despite the lack of evidence. It follows the heart-breaking story of her dealing with the prejudice and harsh realities that comes with being classed as different by society. It‚Äôs written as a dual-timeline story, following Kyas life growing up alongside the unravelling of Chase‚Äôs murder and the aftermath of his death.I loved the story this book told and was surprised at how much sympathy I felt for Kya, but the small moments of happiness in her life made you smile. I thought that the ending would be predictable, but I was super surprised with the twist at the end when I was proved wrong. I wasn‚Äôt disappointed at ALL. The reason I marked it down a star is that I struggled to originally get into it. The only point where I couldn‚Äôt put it down was when her case was taken to trial in the court! I just needed to know what happened.

title: Fabulous read!
text_review: This was a great book.  I was caught in from the first page and couldn't put it down.  It is a while since I have had such a satisfying read, all the books released now seem to be so formulaic and follow a theme.  Oh, let's shine a light on this or that issue when most of us just want to escape into an absorbing piece of literature that takes us out of our rather 'groundhog day lives' - well certainly in lockdown.  Rant over; and just want to say read this book, you won't regret it!

title: Nature, Murder, Mystery.
text_review: I bought this book after reading some glowing reviews....and was left a little disappointed. The evocation of the landscape and the insights and portraits of the natural world are beautifully and lightly done - as you would expect from an author who is foremost a zoologist - but while Delia Owens excels at capturing the wild she doesn‚Äôt have much of an ear for human dialogue or pinning down descriptions of human behaviour and the expository description of the town and its folk at times seems a little naive and childlike.As an aide - there is a fascinating article in the New Yorker called ‚ÄúThe Hunted‚Äù about the unsolved murder in Zambia of a poacher from over 30 years ago, that allegedly involved Delia Owen‚Äôs former husband and stepson, which the publishers would seem rather keen we don‚Äôt allude to.

title: Exquisite
text_review: I'd heard good things about this book, and I dove in not even having read the blurb. I was not disappointed.I won't post sent spoilers, but this book is spectacular. Set in Georgia, the gorgeous accents are written into the dialogue, making you feel like you're right there in the marsh with the characters.Each personality is beautifully brought to life, allowing me to know every one as if we've met before.Without giving anything away, this book is absolutely phenomenal from start to perfect finish, and will forever be one of my favourites. The story flows so smoothly that you won't even notice when it is suddenly four o'clock in the morning and you're sat on your bed, mouth open in shock with tears streaming down your cheeks and your heart in tiny little pieces on the floor.It's been a long time since I've loved a story so very much and I can't wait to hear more from Delia Owens.I'd recommend this book to absolutely everyone because it's too beautiful and luscious to be overlooked by a single one of us.

title: Social and romantic tale of seclusion ....
text_review: Nature, grits, and love summarise this book, as the main character struggles with a never ending craving for something external including a partner, but finds more than enough satisfaction in her home and 'The Swamp'. Outdoors descriptions are unique and the analogies of nature to behaviour e.g. female fireflies change their lights to attract new mates, make up some interesting milestones of the book.Otherwise the book skates around social-political class systems, ideas of racism as the book centres around a murder and the classic 'who-dunnit' situations. Whilst the murder is almost never solved by way of cleverness, the unravelling of the main protagonist's feelings coincide in revealing clues to the case, physically and emotionally.Stunning cover and came speedily, as do all the other  NY Times bestsellers.Scenes of sexual nature and vulgar language are included as this Southern USA classic sits on the shelf with other contemporary classics, in the centre, where it can be nurtured into something more problematic for thinkers alike.Overall a shoe-in for themes of feminism, and challenging views on crimes and charges relating to gender dynamics, and convictions.Could have improved with more thought-out plot lines, and less repetitive days, and further development of the character known as Chase, who drives unwillingly to and fro, in his boat or car as the local fratboy on campus with no responsibilties ... however justice was served in this case .

title: Very poor
text_review: Can't rave about this book. I found the characters shallow, underdeveloped and inconsistent, the storyline contrived and quite ridiculous. The completely illiterate girl becomes a genius, the dreadful poetry we are meant to simper over which the ending reveals to have been her own ( ridiculous), the murder which quite frankly I couldn't have cared less who committed. Oh dear why do so many people rate it so highly?? The author would be better sticking to her expertise of flora and fauna and give up on the fiction.

title: Let the tears fall
text_review: Loved this book from the first page to the last. Its power lies in the evocative portrayal of a little girl surviving, as Kya did, on the marshes despite her isolation. The author‚Äôs understanding of Nature is the rock on which this novel succeeds- like a creature in the wild Kya has to adapt to her surroundings alone and live off the produce of the sea and the marshes.The story propels you along, always wanting Kya to surmount the insurmountable - to find love, to be accepted. By giving and withdrawing love to her the story brings you into it- and you cannot escape until the end. I would love to have seen more live narrative towards the end - her life with Tate - but I cried ...

title: The Marsh Girl is a good read.
text_review: A story of a girl in North Carolina who has been abandoned by pretty much all of her family. She's been called The Marsh Girl and tormented by many of the locals. But there are a few who give her a helping hand as a child and love her as their own.As the children of the town grow up they become more adulthood challenges for The Marsh Girl which results in a death and the Marsh Girl being blamed. The people who love her as a child and now a woman fight for her innocence.

title: A very unusual book
text_review: I discovered after I had finished this book (I listened to it as an audio) that it is a real publishing phenomenon having been on the best seller list in the USA for ages. It is also being made into a film. I didn't know any of this beforehand but just went with it - it took me on a strange, atmospheric journey which I found totally absorbing. I think it is better to suspend your disbelief and just accept the somewhat implausible plot at face value.I loved all the descriptions of the natural world and this woman whose life we learn about from an abandoned 7 year old to her older age. She is very much "bonded to her planet and its life in a way few people are"

title: Isolated beauty and survival
text_review: Such a sensitive, moving book. There are unbelievable elements to this story but that doesn‚Äôt detract from its whole. Imagining a young person living an isolated life on the edge of society, is particularly heart rending during the 2020 pandemic. Kya deals with her life by immersing herself in the bird life of the marshes and the sea. The author knows a great deal about natural science and it is woven beautifully throughout the pages while the brutality is not dwelt on. Love and loss are major themes. Kya‚Äôs creativity results in beautifully produced books - the reader can picture them clearly.An unexpected, and for me, a satisfying conclusion.

title: Pulls at your heartstrings
text_review: Set in the 50‚Äôs and 60‚Äôs, this book has two parts to it, going back and forth between the main character, Kya‚Äôs past and present . One part is about Kya growing up deep in the marshes of Carolina, she‚Äôs abandoned by her parents and siblings at a young age, and left to fend for herself with mother nature as her guide. She‚Äôs shunned by society, after spending one day at school and is nicknamed ‚Äòmarsh girl‚Äô by the people in her town. She lives a reclusive life, helped along by a kindhearted couple who are themselves separated from society due to racism, and befriended by a young boy, as interested in nature as she is and helps teach her how to read and write, eventually becoming a love interest. The other part is about solving the death of the town‚Äôs star footballer, who Kya has been rumoured to be involved with, she becomes the main suspect in the middle of the investigation and her motives questioned.This book was highly recommended by @reesesbookclub and it didn‚Äôt disappoint, I read it in a week and cried the whole way through. Kya‚Äôs character pulls at the heartstrings and you root for her throughout, as you follow her being left by her family, a small kid cooking and making ends meet by herself to a woman owning her narrative.This is a story of resilience, loneliness, what it is to be abandoned by your family and society, what someone can do against all the odds and the rare moments of kindness and hope that Kya experiences. I loved that it was set against the backdrop of a thriving natural ecosystem, with vivid descriptions of the wildlife that it almost becomes another character of the book, the joy and knowledge that she gets from it not only becomes her constant friend but is what teaches her to survive.

title: Almost a Five Star
text_review: This book has some unquestionable strong points; the nature writing, sense of place in the swamps and along the coast and sense of time in the 1960s. The character of Kya is just about right - very introverted, self sufficient but with a moral compass as well - and the minor characters such as Jumpin, the sheriff and the two boys seem to have distinct voices.My main reservation is whether really such a young girl would be able to cope on her own for so long, then be able to learn to read and write and then write published text books. It doesn't seem likely to me.I think the books tails off at the end as well - there is no need to complete her life history post the trial.

title: Disappointed
text_review: Started off well and after having abandoned several novels recently because of poor writing and plot I thought, at last a decent book! How wrong I was. The first part was good, but then it rapidly went downhill. The writing became heavily expositional, the central characters changing in an unrealistic way, the plot dragging and becoming unbelievable. I must admit, I stopped reading it and just read the end to find out what happened. Several things grated on me, how realistic is it for the son of a shrimp boat owner in small town NC to go to university and become leading research scientist? Why do the main character lose her local accent and dialect just because she reads text books? Her brother and Tate also lose theirs. I wanted to like this book. It was such a let down.

title: Writing style changed and spoiled it for me
text_review: Started out brilliant: I found the writing to be enchanting and immersive. You really felt for the main character and could imagine her surroundings well. However, I found that this dackered off a half to two thirds into the book and was replaced with lengthy dialogue of the court room conversations, which spoiled it for me. Definitely took away from the 'magical realism' that was captured in the first half of the book.The ending, in my opinion, was obvious and I could have guessed it.I think if the author focused a full book in the style of writing found in the first half of this book, I would purchase her work again.

title: Absolute Rubbish
text_review: Long drawn out , cliched and extremely unlikely. Passages of poetry dropped in at random. I gave up at 60 % as life is too short.

title: Good in places....
text_review: This was a nice read, I wasn't sure I would enjoy it to begin with as it seemed a bit tame  but it got better. I liked the storyline development although some characters were a little unbelievable such as Tate never giving up on Kya or ever finding anyone else but it made for a heart warming read. The writing was a bit drawn out and over descriptive in places so I did find myself skimming quite a bit as not every object needs to be described in such detailI'd give it a a 3.5 out of 5 as where I read it and found it good in places there are many books I'd reccomend to someone before getting to this. I do think however they it will make a good film

title: Where the Crawdads Sing
text_review: Beautifully  written novel . A story of how the beauty and wonder of Nature teaches a girl both how to live and survive . How animals  nurture and protect when humanity fails. Her freedom costs ignored by many but she overcomes prejudice living  a life forced  upon her .  A way of life that she then defends and ensuring it's protection. With poetry she hides and thru nature learns how to obtain revenge.

title: Simply spectacular
text_review: When I read the first few pages, I thought this wasn‚Äôt a book I would enjoy but given the rave reviews it had received, I carried on. I‚Äôm so glad I did!It didn‚Äôt take long for me to be completely immersed in the world of the marsh. The author has a true talent for descriptive writing and I could almost smell the grass and the sea, could hear the likes of Big Red!There were moments were I felt real sorrow, true joy, and a few gasps along the way. I felt I knew the characters in depth and the ending was magnificent.I loved this book. It will stay with me for a long time.

title: Slow burn
text_review: I had heard the hype about this book but the description did not draw me to it. It was chosen by our book club to read, so my hand was forced, so to speak.It is definitely a slow burner, but gradually I couldn‚Äôt get enough and became thoroughly engrossed. The use of eye dialect for certain characters helps to create an atmospheric ambience which enfolds the reader in the tale. The descriptive terms used are unusual which is captivating and brings a smile to my senses.I will not spoil this story for anyone by revealing the plot, except to say that I found it immensely satisfying!

title: Going to make a great movie !!!
text_review: A lovely easy gentle read , which I enjoyed but of a stretch to believe a child of 6\7 could survive and I think it  would have been more real to make her 12\13 but  that aside the descriptions of the marsh were lovely and the story fast paced .Slightly to Kill a mocking bird copy car trial scene at the ending but without the depth ,but a good read  .I can see this being made into a movie and I bet there is a line of actresses begging their agents to get her the part of Kya as I write !!  It will make a great movie just make Kya  older when  is abandoned and you got yourself a blockbuster !

title: Gorgeous read
text_review: For some reason, when a book is ‚Äòsuper‚Äô popular, I postpone reading it.This is a perfect example. For me it‚Äôs like I had a delicious dinner, then had a super dessert. What a treat.I loved this book.Delia Owens not only uses the English language (albeit with an American accent) in a truly beautiful way, but she created a world so far removed from anything familiar to me.It would be impossible not to love Kya and care deeply about what happens to her.Thank you Delia Owens for transporting me out of the walls of my cocoon.Thoroughly recommend this book - as so many have before me.

title: Awful
text_review: What a disappointment. It started with the promise of something unique. An exploration of how a child might grow and develop alone and unsupported and who that child might become interwoven with a murder mystery. Unfortunately it quickly deteriorated into a cringy sentimental teenage chit lic novel. Some of the narrative was so appallingly bad it was painful to read. If it had been written by a thirteen year old girl it would be excusable but it wasn‚Äôt. The continuous punctuation of the dreadfulNarrative with even worse poetry just added insult to injury. How on earth has this become a best seller? I appreciate we all have different tastes but I simply cannot fathom how an adult could possibly rate this book as anything other than a weak and embarrassing example of a hackneyed genre.  I‚Äôve never left a scathing review before but this was truly dire prose almost continuously from the moment the main character became truly alone. Shockingly bad. Don‚Äôt waste your time.

title: Loved it
text_review: Loved this. It's a slow grower and I grew impatient with some of the lengthy descriptive passages, but gradually Owens pulled me in with her beautiful, honeyed writing style and when I finished I felt like I'd just returned from a holiday in North Carolina. The writing was so vivid I could almost smell the marshes and I learned a great deal about the flora and fauna - always good to learn new things from a book! The plot was OK, I guessed the twist, but ultimately the reason for the five stars is the creation of Kya, a compelling character who will live in my imagination for a long time.

title: First time fiction got lucky
text_review: Others have detailed what's wrong with this book, and a good deal of it is the fault of the editor. For all it's faults, there is a quality of sincerity coming through.However far-fetched and implausible the plot, the author's sincerity kept me interested. However, for me, the poetry device didn't work. I ended up skipping the poems and I think the book would have been stronger without them. It's enough of an ask to believe that the swamp girl becomes a nationally recognized, published naturalist, but to have her quoting poetry by an unknown , who we learn at the end was actually herself, is a layer too far.

title: Beautiful nature writing
text_review: Delia Owens is an experienced nature writer and this is where I think the book excels - when she writes about the marsh landscape the novel comes alive. I found the crime story woven throughout unnecessary and some of the characters felt very cliched. Spoiler alert: I particularly found myself struggling with the way the sex scenes between the protagonist and her suitors were done. It felt exploitative without really acknowledging that. I wanted a woman more in control of her fate (without having to murder anyone). But overall a really interesting immersion in a place and time and a great imaginative feat.

title: Beautifully written and utterly addictive - one of my favourite books EVER!
text_review: This is one of the BEST books I‚Äôve read for a while, and it‚Äôs now firmly on my list of all time favourites! A heartbreaking tale of abandonment, survival, love, loss, longing, hope, desperation, cruelty, racism, justice, trust, human connections, desire... a truly mesmerising story that keeps you hooked from chapter to chapter. Beautifully written and incredibly clever - I absolutely love this book and I am in absolute awe of this author!-I highly recommend this incredible, beautiful, gripping, haunting book. If you haven‚Äôt read it - you need to!

title: Compelling reading
text_review: As a fan of Liane Moriarty books and that Reeces Witherspoon went on to make Big Little Lies into a fab TV series, then hearing she had a book club online I saw this title. I downloaded a sample and was hooked. The book conjures up the most beautiful images of Marsh life and nature. Whilst reading it I imagined a film and lo and behold it looks like that might happen. Who would play the beautiful Kya... Ah my mind is wandering. Anyway, I'm thankful for kindle samples as I wouldn't have purchased this book without it. It is a beautifully written book from start to end. Am about to see what other books are on the book club list as this was such a different but compelling read for me.

title: Book of the Year
text_review: This is the best book I have read this year. It includes everything important in a book. A continuous story so that you just want to know what happens next. In the beginning the young 6 year old Kia watches her mother walk away from the family home, this immediately puts you on her side as she goes through the traumas of childhood, adolescence and adulthood. The descriptions of the marsh means you really can understand the harsh living of the people. A book of love and relationships, nature and survival with a clever twist at the end. Warning do not be tempted to look at the ending before reading the book.

title: Powerful, moving, funny and beautiful! A MUST READ!
text_review: I absolutely LOVED this book! Initially I was listening to the audio book, which was enchanting, encapsulating and had me hooked from the word go, but way the book is written is just so, so beautiful that I felt I needed the written word to fully appreciate it. I then ordered the paper back and have just finished it tonight.It is one of the best I have ever read!The way the author hides you through the emotions of Kya from young girl to misunderstood adult is a truly magical journey and I feel in love (or hate) with every single character!I hope you enjoy it as much as I did.

title: Devastatingly powerful
text_review: Without a doubt a book that grabs your heart and imagination and pulls on it for over 350 pages. Delia Owens has created a life here that I was fully invested in and had me feeling every emotion possible. Never have I felt so invested in a book to the point where one minute I was nervous and the next I felt I could cry. Her writing style and descriptive writing needs no praise, it's phenomenal. You can visualise the world and almost feel the surrounding through her words. Absolutely outstanding. The second book of the year I'd give six stars if I could.

title: Couldn't Put it Down
text_review: Seems like a lot of people couldn't get past the fact that a six year old girl was left alone and survived in a swamp; clearly they don't know anything about life in a lot of place in the US...the hollers of Eastern Kentucky, the bayous of Louisiana, the Appalachian Mountains and plenty of others.The author clearly knows her stuff when it comes to nature and habitat, and she wove those details into a spell-binding page turner that kept me enthralled.  I cried a few times during the trial; it was just too easy to imagine redneck sheriffs in a hick town railroading the girl who doesn't fit their mould.And that ending...I cheered.  Ask the people on the beach on Mykonos....everyone there heard me.This is a perfect summer read, do yourself a favour and grab it.

title: Brilliant- the writing is a joy!!
text_review: I wasn‚Äôt sure if this was for me, but the reviews intrigued me.  The language, at first, felt alien but within a short while I was hooked. This is about a girl‚Äôs journey of survival in a desperately impoverished, virtually solitary, existence;  where the landscape and nature become her surrogate family. Her story is powerful.  As she learns about people and navigates her path I found it moving, disturbing, beautiful and thought provoking*. The writing is an absolute JOY.  I‚Äôm surprised this was the authors first work of fiction, as it is utterly brilliant. This book is one I will keep and reread many times; as well as buy again for others. I recommend it -without question. *Especially poignant as I read it during a period of global lockdown.

title: Brilliant. Forget the negative comments.
text_review: I get the negative reviews. The plot does stretch credibility but it is fiction so we can allow the author her imagination. All I can say is that I loved every minute, couldn‚Äôt put it down, wept at the end and am still thinking about it. I think people who criticise fiction for not being realistic are rather missing the point. Fiction can be judged on many levels. The credibility of plot is one of many criteria.

title: Story
text_review: I loved this book on so many levels. The author gave beautiful descriptions of the environment so you felt you were living there with the characters. My attention never waned as there are 2 narratives , the story of Kya and the possible murder of Chase, that are told without detracting from each other.  The attention to detail, which is some books can be burdensome. here only adds to the enjoyment. I particularly enjoyed the use of poetry as an illustrative practice. The best recommendation I give is I devoured this during the pandemic

title: A beautiful story
text_review: Having read some of the one and two star reviews of this book after I purchased it on a friend‚Äôs recommendation I considered giving it a miss, but I am so glad that I did not. It is extremely well written and the descriptions of all aspects of the Carolina marshes are quite magical. The story does take some suspension of belief as the Kya is very young when she is abandoned, and very fortunate to survive the vicissitudes of living in the wild for so long, hence my dropping a star. It is also true that the trial is based on the flimsiest of evidence but it is well done and as a lawyer I have seen worse. Having said that, I loved this book; it conjures the most wonderful atmosphere and a very well drawn central character as are the supporting cast! So, ignore the naysayers and immerse yourselves!

title: Beautifully written. It has become one of my favourite books.
text_review: This is a captivating story - sad at times but also heart warming. It is beautifully written and the story has stayed with me. I wanted to keep reading but didn‚Äôt want to finish it. Evocative of the time and generation,  it is well written and compelling. The descriptions of the marshland and bird life were beautifully written. - you could hear and see the wildlife. I  had a real book hangover when I finished it. Grab a copy now.

title: Possibly spoilt by the hype.
text_review: So, everyone was raving about this book. I was so looking forward to reading it, which can be a big mistake.It started off very slow and I wondered if not being American may have affected my enjoyment.I got to like Kya and was glad when the court case brought a bit of drama.What brought down my rating was one particular passage where Kya doubts herself and is somewhat self deprecating.

title: Simply beautiful. A book that lingers in your mind long after you finish it.
text_review: Many avid readers recommended this book to me, (some claiming it was the most beautiful book they had ever read) and that was enough for me to read it; I didn't read the blurb, just made a start. Now that I've read it, I feel bereft. More bereft than I usually do after reading a book as I was completely captivated by the the marshlands, buzzing with life, intrigue and secrets.  I miss Kya & Tate, who were beautifully drawn. I feel more aware of and in tune with nature and language. The writing is skilful, well-crafted but economic; not a single word is wasted. It has the feel of a classic, with shades of To Kill a Mockingbird in the narrative perspective. A stunning debut novel from a truly talented and multi-faceted writer; I can't wait to see what Owens brings to the world next.

title: Mixed but really predictable
text_review: Why are people raving about this? It's a nice but pretty standard story. The last third of the book was utterly predictable and i forced myself through it. I enjoyed the discussions of the nature and the descriptions of the paintings and the authors deep love for both shines through. Her characters for the most part are just very clich√© and we've met them a thousand times before. I can imagine it making a decent made for netflix movie. It ain't gonna win best screenplay for sure ...

title: It‚Äôs an unbelievable story so well written
text_review: A beautifully written book and although unbelievable it is after all a novel which I was engrossed in from beginning to end.  To imagine a little girl on her own fending for herself In the swamp was not possible but written in such a way I found everything plausible and stayed with her from the beginning to the end.  The poetry just added to the gentle way the writer took us through this story.  I loved every minute of it and would recommend it to every book club.  Take it and enjoy all the descriptive padding it gives.

title: Stunning debut
text_review: A stunning debut by Delia Owens. This is a unique story that embeds a lonely, abandoned girl in the nature that surrounds her to the point where she follows the example of the insects when threatened. I found this book difficult to put down except, and this is my only gripe, when I had to resort to Google to understand words like grits. I still don't know what 'fubsy' means or 'toting his poke' In fact, I struggled with much of the dialogue. A glossary would have been amazing. Other than that this was an absolute pleasure to read.

title: Jaw dropping
text_review: I read this book until late into the night. Every line is poetry. You are right there in the marsh with all the creatures hearingThem, seeing them, breaking your heart for the child who was so solitary and yet so loveable. I can‚Äôt believe this was a first novel. This woman is talented beyond measure. So many issues are covered here and addressed so compassionately and humanely. And in the end there is a twist, so unexpected it made me gasp. I wish I hadn‚Äôt read it so that I could read it again. Brilliant

title: A spectacularly beautiful book
text_review: I was not expecting to enjoy this book as much as I did. I was hooked from beginning to end. Kya was a wonderful character. She had the most difficult start in life and it beggars believe that a whole town could shun, spurn, humiliate and neglect such a young child. She succeeded against all the odds, but this wasn't a story about vengeance or retribution. Nor was it a sentimental, woe is me yarn. Instead, the author painted Kya, the lead character, as psychologically damaged, but strong and determined with an incredible connection and empathy with nature and the marshes. She became a creature of the marshes and this enabled her to rise above human emotions which should have overwhelmed her: envy, bitterness, loneliness, self-pity and anger. This allowed the story to take on a more positive path, but still with many struggles along the way and would be expected from a child brought up by nature and having minimal human adult guidance. A beautifully written book and a thoroughly enjoyable read which stays with you long after you have finished.

title: great distraction during a pandemic
text_review: I really enjoyed this book, Owens has created a sympathetic character in Kya and put her in an unusual and interesting setting and I wanted to know her story and what became of her. I read it during the corona virus pandemic and it was great to lose myself into another world away from all the news and anxiety in a good page turning book. Couldn't put it down towards the end.

title: Suspension of disbelief required but still an engaging and engrossing read
text_review: Despite some really rather scathing reviews, which made some salient points, this was a good old page turner with some subtle twists and turns that had me guessing until the (slightly sentimental) ending.Yes, some implausible scenarios, but let's face it, we don't always want total reality in fiction. I thought the book flowed well and I liked the emerging timelines. And, seemingly a rarity in the books I read these days, some actually likable characters for a change. Not at all surprised the rights have already been bought for a film.

title: Don‚Äôt believe the hype
text_review: I couldn‚Äôt wait to finish this book....boring beyond belief!  There is a ‚Äútwist‚Äù but you don‚Äôt have to be Hercule Poirot to work it out - too obvious!  If you want to waist your time watch some paint dry instead.

title: A True Delight
text_review: Absolutely loved this novel.It did find that initially it took a while to get in to, especially with the local sayings but as I hit the third chapter, I felt more at home.I didn't find myself getting bored at any stage and the evolving story definitely reeled me in.Your heart really went out to "Kya" and the way she was treated by not only her family but all the locals too. Heartbreaking.If this the first novel by Delia Owens, I'm already looking forward to more!!

title: Page Turner
text_review: The writing is eloquent and the author draws you into the world of the central charcter(Kya). Each character in the book is believable and knitted beautifully into the story. Although it is not a thriller,  I kept turning pages, wanting to share in Kya's emotions and thoughts. The author's love of nature and poetry are obvious, again as a backdrop to the story but enriching it. i found myself laughing, despairing and being thoroughly engrossed and entertained. A must read!

title: Hauntingly Beautiful, Stays With You In Your Mind
text_review: I read a lot of books and usually pass them on after reading unless they are reference books or specialist ones.'Where The Crawdads Sing' however will have honour on my bookcase forever. Hauntingly beautiful, well written and compelling - I cannot fault Delia Owen's novel at all. The settings are lushiously described while Kya & Tate are characters that you will fall easily in love with.I've been recommending this book to everyone I know, perfect Summer read.Read it for yourself - you won't regret it!

title: A Brilliant Story
text_review: "Where the Crawdads Sing" is a wonderful story with great sadness and unhappiness but also joy it is wonderful at how the simple things in life can bring great happiness.  The birds, plants and shells which are a big part of this story for a little girl left deserted by her family.  There are some wonderful characters who show kindness and love to a lonely little girl  who  many others ridicule and see her as unworthy of their social lifeThis is a great book which will break your heart at times but make you laugh too.  I don't wish to spoil the story by writing about the contents this is for for you to explore and enjoy.

title: Wonderful
text_review: I loved this book.  A slow enthralling meander through the wildlife of Kya‚Äôs loved marshes learning to love the landscape and it‚Äôs animal and bird life.  The mystery of a murder, or was it an accident?  A love story.  This book is all these things.  Underlying it all is Kya and her understanding of her environment, her place in it and it is where she draws her strength from.  Wonderfully written, gentle yet brimming with emotion and a true love of the natural world.  Just wonderful.

title: An oasis in a literary desert.
text_review: I've been trying to find a great novel to read for years, they are so formulaic nowadays aren't they?This, however, immediately grabbed me with lovely, atmospheric prose from page 1.Fabulous main character, beautifully drawn, you do really get to know her. This book explores prejudice and poverty in an original way.I really enjoyed the setting, the cliche that the place is a character is explored really well here. I do recommend exploring North Carolina on Google Earth and looking at a bit of the history to give you a great visualisation, its quite easy to slip further into the  Cajun swamps in your imagination if you aren't careful, then you will miss out on an amazing setting.

title: Great story
text_review: I‚Äôm late to the party here but I‚Äôm so glad I came! If you can assume that a child of ten can bring herself up in isolation in a swamp, the rest is a delight. With Kya‚Äôs background and experiences by then, I was prepared to believe it. It‚Äôs a great story, pulling your feelings from side to side as it progresses. There‚Äôs an excellent courtroom drama within the book and a murder that remains unsolved. I really thought the ending was fitting. A great story and one I‚Äôll remember.

title: Where The Crawdads Sing
text_review: I loved everything about this book; the gorgeous cover, the beautiful descriptions of the environment and of course the wonderful characters.  After being abandoned by her family members, Kya is left alone as a very young girl to survive in the harsh environment of the marsh land of North Carolina.  I completely fell in love with her, and with the author's writing style as she brought to life the flora and fauna of the marsh.  I'll admit, I did find it a bit slow to start, but once I got going I loved it.

title: Lame
text_review: Sentimental mush.  Enjoyed the 1 star reviews far more than the book!

title: Superb!!!
text_review: I loved this book. It‚Äôs beautifully written, wonderfully descriptive and evocative. Part thriller it transports you to another world. Would make a superb film. ‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è

title: Excellent read to the very last page!
text_review: I was recommended this book by a friend and was very grateful for this. It was a really marvellous experience to read.  The prose was beautiful, poignant, sad and inspirational. The in depth details and descriptions of nature and the conditions in the Marsh, as well as Kya's struggles, were written in a very sympathetic way, and really evoked visions of  the beauty of the Marshland, and the amazing creatures living in that protected land. A page turner, right to the end.  I would really recommend this book, it will not disappoint!

title: A stunning read
text_review: This was a rare and unique book.  Beautifully written, I became totally engrossed by Kya's pain and loneliness and her passion for the marshes.  The combination of the natural world described so vividly, her abandonment, shy discovery of love and the mystery of a crime for which she is accused was such a fascinating combination, and there were moments when I thought my heart could break.  An absolute must-read

title: Couldn't put down this book
text_review: This book paints pictures in your mind that will stay for a long time; beautifully crafted, with characters that live on each page and a vibrant backdrop that is full of knowledge and love yet doesn't make you want to visit since you know that what you will find there could never match the place so minutely described in this clever novel. In her first novel, Owens has woven a mystery that surprises yet makes complete sense and you know that it couldn't have happened any other way. I LOVED this book. More please, Delia.

title: Beautifully told and captivating from the first page
text_review: This book manages to inspire a wealth of emotions from the very first page. I felt fully immersed in the world of the swamp and wholly gripped by the court scenes. I couldn‚Äôt bring myself to put this novel down and found myself thinking about it when I had to tear myself away from reading it. It‚Äôs a wonderful story of courage and endurance and I highly recommend as a 5 star read. I have only just finished and  think I‚Äôll read it again because I already miss it

title: One if the best books I have ever read
text_review: Delia Owens' command of the English language is unsurpassed and unique.  She weaves an exciting story around thoroughly believable characters and the result is a classically beautiful piece of literature which is an absolute pleasure to read.

title: You really do need to read this book.
text_review: I didn't think I would like this story. I hovered putting it into my virtual shopping basket so many times, but the title kept drawing me back. Then a friend said the immortal words, "Look! I'm reading this amazing book!" It was the little nudge I needed.I admit it's an unusual book, you might start reading it & think, "Oh no. I don't like this!" But persevere, I promise it's worth it. I finished my copy a couple of weeks ago and am still thinking about it.

title: This is SO much more than a standard story about a poor girl's struggle
text_review: This came highly recommended by my two most reliable reader friends.  It didn't disappoint.  One of the books that you desperately try to slow down as you approach the end.  The landscape was superbly described and every one of the characters was believable and many of them lovable.  There weren't the stereotypes that so often occur in this type of novel. The twist at the end was as pleasing at it was surprising - I say no more in case you haven't read it.

title: Grits? Again?
text_review: This novel has much to recommend it, but for me there were too many unnecessary authorial devices and flaws to make this a satisfying read. In particular, the abrasive and clumsy inclusions of poetry began to wear down my patience - whilst I accept this was (ultimately) relevant to the narrative, the cumbersome juxtapositions were just that, cumbersome. I found myself dreading the next page turn in case another poem was going to appear. And, whilst I am as a big a fan as anyone of the description of food in a narrative, it has to be relevant, spare and somehow add value - here, the seemingly endless listing of North Carolina cuisine just became repetitive and quickly lost relevance. Grits? Again? That said, the plot was well managed, the landscape made real and many of the characters were quite refreshing, even if some of the colloquial dialogue was a bit too ‚Äòloud‚Äô and again, clumsy, for my taste. I made it to the end of this novel but only just - the second half certainly lacked the sparkle of the first and the book overall fell short of it‚Äôs early promise.

title: Beautiful read. I love it.
text_review: The story is set in a small town in North Carolina. In late 1969 when the 'golden boy' Chase Andrews was found dead, the locals immediately suspect Kya Clark because she is the 'different' one.Kya also known as the Marsh Girl has been abandoned by her family, one by one, since she was six years old. She lives alone in the marshes. This book tells the story of how Kya struggles to feed herself, how she makes money to buy essentials. She spends her days learning about nature. She has no one, until one day when Tate Walker came into her life.Tate spend most of his time with Kya. I loved the chemistry between two of them üíñ. He teaches her how to read, share her passion for nature, exploring the marshes, cruising along the waterways. The description of the marsh are just brilliant. I felt as though I could smell the sea. One day Tate had to go away to pursue his studies and Kya was left alone again.The last quarter of the book was on Kya's court case. It goes back and forth between present day and days leading to the incident. Her story was heartbreaking but at the same time inspirational. It's a story of love and determination.This is a beautiful book which takes you on an emotional journey. Beautifully written story. I would really recommend this book.

title: I am so glad I wasn't put off!
text_review: Just before I downloaded this novel, I read the latest 3 reviews that all proclaimed what "ridiculous clap-trap" it was.  I wondered if I should bother but thank goodness I ignored them and decided to try it for myself.  Where the Crawdads sing is a beautifully crafted story.  The marvellous descriptions of the marsh have a ring of truth about them so I wasn't surprised to discover that the author is a wildlife scientist.  I enjoyed following the twists and turns of such an original tale to its satisfying conclusion.  I know we are all different but do give this book a try - I don't think you will be disappointed.

title: Haunting and beautiful
text_review: This is a haunting and beautifully crafted novel that draws you in. The descriptions of the mash and it‚Äôs inhabitants is so evocative that you feel as though you are there. The story sweeps you along and you fall in love with the main character whilst never really knowing her. She flies away from you like and at the same time wrenches your heart in sympathy. This is a precious and amazing book and deserves to be read and reread. I highly recommend it.

title: A wonderful book I couldn't put down
text_review: Although at first I found it difficult to get into in the end I couldn't put it down.The story of Kyra is heart wrenching.  It gives a good portrayal of life in the deep south and how prejudice still existed into the 1970s (and no doubt still exists).  Through her abandonment from her family to her first relationship with Tate. How she emerged into the most amazing author of all around her because she was not tainted by the outside world.  Tate betrayed her with the result that the alpha male Chase came on the scene totally duping her (as many do).  How she coped with her trial and lived her final years with Tate.  I liked the way the book did not stop when they came together.  Delia continued the story to the end of Kya's life not in great detail as this wasn't needed.  The bitter sweet discovery by Tate at the end, were we surprised, may be.Its one I will read again.

title: An excellent book
text_review: This was one of the best books I have read for a while and I also bought it for friends who I know would enjoy the setting and story. The setting, in America is the wild swampy sea area  of N Carolina, beautiful and filled with wild life. The story is centred around a girl left by her parents and family to grow up alone in most difficult circumstances. But this brief outline does nothing  to show the power of the writing and how it becomes, truly , an addictive page turner.

title: So well written - a modern day classic
text_review: Loved this book - the author really paints the scene and leaves you feeling that you lived in the marshes with Kya. Original and imaginative. This competes with The Goldfinch for my number one book of all time. I read the 1 star rating given by a previous reviewer who said that it was unrealistic that a child could fend for themselves at such a young age - obviously led a very sheltered life - when you see young children picking through litter and living on the streets in various parts of the world!

title: A fantastic read
text_review: A beautiful yet heartbreaking story of a young girl Kya who's family left her alone and had to look after herself  She quickly learned how to survive whilst living in seclusion and she was known as the marsh girl and she spent her days in her boat and learning all about nature Such a lovely read and the characters are fabulous and written so sensitively by Delia Owen's and Kya's character will stay with you long after her story has been told

title: Incredible storytelling
text_review: This story of a little girl, abandoned by almost everyone, in the most inhospitable of habitats, had me on an emotional roller coaster. More than just a tale of American history, it‚Äôs a murder mystery and a love story.I hesitated to read it because it looked and sounded like it was aimed at a female book club audience. Maybe it was. Maybe that shows how we try to limit our reading unnecessarily. In any case, I‚Äôm so glad I read it. I thought it was a brilliant story, brilliantly told.

title: Lovely story, sadly let down by implausible plot
text_review: This is a beautiful, sensitively-written tale of a young girl‚Äôs life and loves in the swampland of the North Carolina coast. Tragic and yet heart-warming, I enjoyed every turn of the page: until the very end. The plot is fatally flawed, and I don‚Äôt think I have ever been so disappointed by a novel.

title: Captivating and beautiful
text_review: A captivating and engrossing read... Kya is a young girl who finds herself fending for herself after her unreliable father leaves her alone in the swap lands of Carolina. Abandoned by her mother and siblings previously, she manoeuvres her way through life, forming heartwarming and touching relationships while keeping herself fed and educated. The separate stand followed the death of the local sports hero and this was beautifully done.  This was a story that kept me captivated throughout and I was willing Kya to succeed.  The intertwined timelines were wonderful and the ending tied everything up perfectly. I finished this book knowing that these characters would stay with me for a long time and it would be quite a while until I could immerse myself in another book.

title: Beautiful and heartbreaking escapism
text_review: There are loads of reviews of this book on Amazon. most people loved this book, some hated it.  I will just say this, it's a work of fiction, if you can lose yourself in the imagination of somebody that obviously has a deep love of nature then give it a try.  I loved it.

title: Absolutely Outstandingly Amazing
text_review: Well I don't think any words could ever quite  touch on how beautiful This book is. Outstanding i truly felt I was there in the swamp with Kya, the descriptions were beautiful. I have read hundreds and hundreds of books and this is only the second book that has made me cry. Felt quite emotional finishing it, read over 3 days i didn't want it to end i was fully lost . Wow

title: Lacks pace, rushed ending, irritating prose ..
text_review: This book was average.I wasn‚Äôt blown away as per the reviews.Yes - it was beautifully written but massively lacked pace.The ending was so disappointing and rushed. I found myself wishing the book away so I could read my next book on the bookshelf!The North Carolina ‚ÄúLanguage‚Äù was so irritating and disrupted the flow of the book.I was let down given the High reviews ....

title: Simply Beautiful
text_review: This is a love story. Not between of two humans, or amongst humans.But between a girl and her land, her marsh land.When humans abandons, disappoints or breaks her heart (except one), nature never does.This is a story of young girl, left abandoned and had grew up alone in the marsh land.Kya Clarke was abandoned by each member of her family. They literally walked out of her life, before she even turned puberty, and left to fend for herself, alone in a shack in the marsh, with no human neighbours in sight. It is heartbreaking cruel to her and for her to learn abandonment at a very young age.As a young child, she had to depend on nature, by collecting mussels, oysters and smoked fish for sale for money to buy grocery. She was not welcomed by the villagers of Barkeley Cove because she was different, she was the ‚ÄúMarsh Girl‚Äù.Tate Walker was her saviour. He taught and guided her to be independent. Even though he loved her, he still thought she was too different for his world.The handsome, Chase Andrews, promised her the world. She was guarded after Tate, but perhaps she saw Chase as her chance to be more than the Marsh Girl.Her story of loneliness and having the Cooper‚Äôs Hawk, Big Red, birds, insects, crabs as her companions, was heartbreaking as it. Added to the fact, she was immediately prejudiced and deemed as guilty when Chase Andrew was found dead, she was alone and felt the world was against her, was sorrowful.The storyline may not be new. However, the storytelling is beautiful and heartbreaking. It tells you of the beauty of the marsh land, its inhabitants, the ecosystem and that nature is enough for you to survive - as it is always meant to be for us, humans. We just need to remember to treat it kindly.It seems apt to read this book (on Kindle) now. With lockdown happening around the world, Mother Earth is finally healing. We should be ashamed how we had taken her for granted all this while and we had forgotten to treat her well. May we become better towards her after this.

title: Definitely a book to savour.
text_review: I absolutely loved this story and all the emotions it provoked. It ripped at my heart over and over again in this tale of a young girl, abandoned and left to fend for herself. Her journey to survive and live in a small opinionated town and her transition from young girl to young lady. Her first heartbreak at the hands of a man which made her retreat into herself over and over again with her seemingly only friends to be the marsh and wildlife around her.

title: Just wow
text_review: This had everything I could ever want in a book I loved this so much. The heartache of Kay's abandment, the romance, the mystery and the beauty and scerets of the marsh.Normally I'm not a fan of poetry written into the books as I'd find them distracting from the story. However the poetry in this was beautiful well written and added to the story being told.So grateful I final took a chance and read this.

title: Overrated
text_review: Very good on natural history covering a wobbly pathetic plot.

title: Very enjoyable
text_review: I enjoyed this book very much.  I loved the gentleness of the story, even though the main character had a hard life.  I could really visualise the surroundings as they were so well described.  I could feel for this child trying to deal with small town prejudices and her struggles just to survive, having been abandoned at a very young age.  I found myself rooting for her and wishing for her to find happiness.  Good twist too!

title: Love, death, abandonment and natural history
text_review: The  images Delia conjures up are so vivid and clear that we are there with Kya every step of the way. It‚Äôs not often you get such a page turner of a story combined with the evocative descriptions of the Marsh and its inhabitants and its wildlife. The way the people and the environment interact, and how one has shaped the other Is described well. Her people are realistic, her Marsh is magical and the storyline is gripping.

title: Spectacular writing
text_review: This is fantastic. What a book. I was gushing tears at the end. What wonderful language Delia Owens used throughout. I loved every moment of it. Her characters were so well formed, the story was superb. I felt a deep sense of foreboding throughout. Kya was such an endearing protagonist, her life could draw a tear from even the hardest of hearts. I really cannot commend this author and this book enough. It‚Äôs truly a five star read. I‚Äôll never forget it.

title: how much grits can a girl eat?
text_review: Enjoyed this story as it transported you to a completely different time and place and liked the 'twist' at the end.  Some of the descriptions were a bit repetitive as was the constant need to tell us that Kya was eating 'grits' on a regular basis - we get it  - she's poor and lives on marshland!  Still a good story of how a girl is abandoned by all the people that should have loved and supported her in her life and how she tries to find a home.

title: A coming of age mystery
text_review: I'm not a big fan of American novels (sorry), but this one I did enjoy. It's very visual. When all her family leave her, the girl, who is still a child learns how to fend for herself. She has been nicknamed the Marsh Girl (the marshes being where she lives) and avoided and laughed at by the towns people. Years pass. When the body of young man is found it isn't long before the Marsh Girl is in the picture for murder - the man being someone she had an association with. It's a good story and hard to put down.

title: Gorgeously written with an unforgettable heroine
text_review: My book club has been meeting monthly for about two years. This was the first book we have been able to agree on. It is wonderful. Beautifully written well drawn characters and improbable at the same time not wanting to end. Whenitispublishedin paperback i will be buying copies for friend not lucky enough to have read it..

title: Breathtaking
text_review: I can‚Äôt get over how perfect this book is. Although I struggled to understand the way Kya & other characters spoke at first but as soon as I got used to it this book blew me away! The writing is utterly beautiful & I could picture every plant, bird, insect just as Kya drew them. Poor Kya was left to her own devices as her family leaves her. She has to learn how to live all alone apart from help from her friend Tate, who teaches her how to read. She does a fantastic job even with people calling her White Trash. The murder mystery was so well written, I had no idea how it would play out. I regret not picking up this book sooner. Absolutely beautiful & breathtaking! ‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è

title: A welcome change of scene
text_review: I enjoyed this book because it was located in such a very specific area, and the observations of flora fauna and birdlife  and sea-life were so detailed and important to the progress of the story.  There was a satisfying balance between harshness and gentle sympathy.  Often you had to remind yourself that Kya would have made the choices she did because of her less than kind experiences of other people.  There is a happy ever after end, but with quite a twist!

title: Absolutely Marvellous
text_review: One of the best books I've ever read. Not one that I would normally have chosen but was hooked from the beginning. Beautifully written and the descriptive writing make you fall in love with a place you've never seen.  I adored the characters and whilst it's not a thriller, you can't stop reading as you have to know what happens next. Loved the ending, tearful, joyful and unexpected all at once.  This one will stay with me always.

title: Not great, not terrible
text_review: I'm more shocked by the great divide of opinion here in the reviews, some waxing lyrical about how fabulous it is, others publishing it mercilessly.I enjoyed it, not perfect and many implausibitys but a nicely observed setting and a romantic idea. A few interesting twists and quite engaging. They can't all be Nobel prize candidates but this book is quite fun and candy floss but it does stir the emotions at time. Worth a read.

title: I didnt want it to end!
text_review: Firstly,I am stunned by the 1 star critics that say they hated this book,because I loved it so much! It did what every great book should do it took me to another place and immersed me in the marsh. The poetic descriptions  of the varied flora and fauna was a delight and I was totally invested in the characters especially Kya.I really didnt want it to end and was sad when it did. Buy it,you will love it.

title: lovely read
text_review: I found this book heart wrenching, without giving away too much this book for me is about how being different and underprivileged can be a trap that leads to profound loneliness, it's also about humanity and empathy.  I love how nature is weaved throughout the story and how Kya learns from what she lives.  If you're looking for a book with a different type of setting that you can be lost in this may be for you.

title: Exciting and Insightful
text_review: So many friends had recommended this book that I finally succumbed. Wonderful descriptions of nature; poverty, man‚Äôs inhumanity to man, strength and weakness of character (sometimes in the same person), love in many guises plus a thriller - what more could you want? Some people questioned whether the heroine could have survived at such a young age but that was the only negative point I‚Äôve heard expressed.

title: Excellent read
text_review: After reading previous reviews I decided to buy this book for my kindle, so glad I bought it. After getting used to the author going back in time, I couldn't put the book down. It was almost as if you were there with the main character and felt so sorry for what she went through but as not to spoil the end, I am so glad I read it. Highly recommend this author and look forward to her writing another book.

title: Wonderful sense of place
text_review: The novel takes you deep into the marshes and swamps of N Carolina in some beautifully atmospheric descriptions. The writer evokes small town America with all its prejudices and narrow- minded characters. Yes there are stereotypes, the kindly black man  from Coloured Town, the ace sporting star, the giggling spoilt girls but all serve to reinforce Kya‚Äôs strength of character. I enjoyed the nature and wildlife scenes very much.Less believable is the idea that a 6 yr old could survive in the way she did without someone apart from Jumpin looking out for her. I also found the dialogue irritating at times as the ‚Äòmarsh ugirl‚Äô switched with apparent fluency from almost unintelligible dialect to Queen‚Äôs English. And the poetry, I confess to missing that out. It was awful and added nothing to the narrative.With more than a nod to ‚ÄòTo Kill a Mockingbird‚Äô this is worth reading for the sense of place alone.

title: Not my style
text_review: Read about 35% before giving up.  Enjoyed the beginning when Kya was learning how to survive alone.  Found some of the nature descriptions repetitive.  Once romance entered the story, I quickly became bored so skipped to the end to find out more about Chase‚Äôs murder.  Found the poetry awful.  This was a Book Club read and we rate our choices out of 10.  I am afraid this book will only earn a 2 from me.

title: Emotional, Heartwarming, Brilliant
text_review: Just simply one of the most emotional books I've ever read, not in a chest beating,wailing way, but in a gradual feeling of calm and peace way, the atmosphere created in the words is amazing,even after I finished reading it, I cried! Kya, what an amazing woman, passionate, and yet peaceful, abused and yet untouched. Honestly, quite possibly THE best book I have Ever read. Delia Owens Thank you so much.

title: Have Bought For or Recommended It To Everyone I Know
text_review: This is not the usual sort of book that I read but was told it was worth a look.  Beautifully written, very hard to put down and emotionally draining with twists and turns throughout.  Was very concerned the end would not live up to the rest of the novel but absolutely the right way to finish the story. Would definitely recommend this.  One of the few books I have retained to read again and one of the best of recent years.

title: Interesting to read about North Carolina.
text_review: A story of endurance but ( spoiler alert) I do not believe that she would have planned and murdered the guy  because she was so respectful towards living creatures.

title: Triumph over adversity
text_review: Triumph over adversity, definitely. Six year old girl left by herself to survive in shack on marsh, how could it happen? Brings out the best and worst in people, makes one wonder how we would have reacted to Kya.Descriptions of wildlife, marsh and sea are wonderful. The description of Kya's book brings it to life.I would highly recommend this book, Involving, moving, intricate a joy to read.

title: Achingly gorgeous and hauntingly beautiful
text_review: Oh my goodness.  Its been a long time since I've read a book so hauntingly beautiful and sad and as wondrous as this. Just a masterpiece.  Rich, evocative, achingly sincere and filled with such bravery and joy and loneliness and resilience.If you are looking for an intelligent and mesmerising read, this is recommended.I honestly don't understand all the poor reviews. This book is achingly gorgeous.

title: Pages missing
text_review: 8 pages of chapters 33 and 34 completely missing

title: Gripping and intensely moving
text_review: The author paints a vivid picture of life in the swamps, desperate loneliness and the strength of the human spirit. The storyline draws you in and although I guessed the ending, this is that very rare novel in which it doesn‚Äôt matter. I felt echoes of Tess of the D‚ÄôUrbevilles as I was reading but Kaya finds a strength and determination to control her own fate  that Tess lacks. Well worth reading.

title: Thought provoking
text_review: This book was beautifully written and thought provoking... the author described everything in exquisite detail and used words and poems to make the scenery jump out of the book.. I second guessed myself a few times in trying to determine who the murderer could be or even if a murder had even taken place... a number of times it made me think about how our own actions and judgements towards someone may influence the way they turn out in the future and that not everyone is as they seem. The most important thing that shapes us is the way we react to what life throws at us and how we make use of the natural world around us... a really good read

title: Superb.
text_review: I don't know how to adequately sum up how wonderful this book is but I'll try.The main character is complex and beautifully written, strange yet very easy to empathise with. Glorious description of landscapes, sharply observed other characters and a great plot, this book is poignant without being mawkish and more satisfying than a bowlful of grits.I hope this author writes namy, many more novels as this was a truly outstanding debut.

title: Absolutely delightful book.
text_review: This book is certainly a must for all book lovers. A wonderful story both happy and sad about a delightful person who came good despite fighting terrific odds. I was completely enraptured from start to finish and the ending was a big surprise. This book comes highly recommended as it was to me by a friend who also told me what a  great book it was. Have a box of tissues handy at the end.

title: Brilliant.
text_review: Occasionally you come across an exceptionally good book with a story that will stay with you perhaps forever. This book is one of those treasures. It is beautifully written and a joy to read. The importance of the environment and the wonders of nature are explored alongside themes including prejudice and loneliness . As the last page turns there is much for the reader to reflect upon.

title: Interesting but flawed novel
text_review: For me, reading this novel was a mixed experience. I thought the descriptions of the marsh & the wildlife were beautiful. I dont think I've ever read a book where the landscape has played such a big part. I felt transported to North Carolina. However, unfortunately, in my opinion, the dialogue & the depictions of the characters did not in any way match the quality of the descriptions of the landscape. Cliched, overly sentimental & unbelievable. At times it felt like reading an old Mills and Boon corny romance novel. This started to annoy me more & more as the book progressed. I did enjoy this book overall, but for me it wasn't as good as many of the reviews are claiming.

title: Unusual mix of crime and nature
text_review: This book has a very different premise in that a loner woman from the marsh lands fights against the small town prejudices of people who do not understand her, a fight which winds up in a murder trial. The natural setting and details of marsh life are excellent. I didn‚Äôt enjoy the poetry and at times the book is over written and verges into sentimentality. A good read for travelling.

title: Engaging, enjoyable & worth buying & keeping.
text_review: I was recommended this book & I am so glad I accepted the recommendation. It is beautifully written & is engaging in many levels.
