text_review: ‚Äì Set in the fictional town of Barkley Cove (near Asheville), Kya is only around six when her mother walks out leaving her and her brother with their alcoholic and violent father. The vision of her standing by the roadside waiting for her mother‚Äôs return was heartbreaking and that set the tone for the rest of the novel. This is Kya‚Äôs story ‚Äì abandoned, left alone, left to live on her wits and her only constant support and carer is Mother Nature herself. Kya spends her days in the marshes, on the land and on the water when she takes out her father‚Äôs boat. She becomes quite the skilled navigator as she grows up on this boat and realises that this is her only true constant she can rely on. Maybe it will be her escape too.Into this world then comes danger ‚Äì a man is found murdered in the very waters, Kya calls home.Much of the novel is an insight into life on the marshes, how others see Kya and how she survives. This is when the novel is at its slowest, yet its most lyrical. I loved spending time here, wallowing in the descriptions of the flora and fauna around me. I swear I could hear the buzz of the insects and the ripple of the water. This book would work particularly well as an audio book because of that. Not only that however. The language of this book is quite something too. Written in local dialect, the novel reads like a Harper Lee era novel, a Barbara Kingsolver book and others in that vein. IT reads like a classic novel of 1950s America. Hard to believe it‚Äôs a debut.As life in the marsh carries on, the novel does slow down considerably until Kya meets a boy. Abandoned by him, she meets another called Chase, the very man found dead at the start. The locals fear this strange ‚Äòmarsh girl‚Äô must have something to do with it. This is where the novel gets very interesting for me as the author has clearly done her research into what life was like back then. Small town American mindsets, suspicion against outsiders, racial overtones and the role of women. Not to mention a young woman who has grown up on the marshes alone. There‚Äôs a lot to discuss for book clubs here.What really drew me in to this novel were the descriptions of the scenery and landscape, but what kept me there was the examination of loneliness and survival. I wasn‚Äôt entirely sure at first that a young girl could do half of what Kya did, but then I wasn‚Äôt raised on a marsh in 1950s America., so I can‚Äôt really say.I admit to not knowing what a crawdad was before reading this novel. A crawdad is a crawfish elsewhere but where the book is set, it‚Äôs a crawdad. They don‚Äôt sing either but they live far away from anywhere, deep in the wild bush. Here, things are wild, raw, and far from civilization.What the book lacks in fast-paced plot, it more than makes up for in an insight into a young girl‚Äôs life, survival and strength. The landscape jumps from the page and is extremely vivid and richly drawn. All in all, I felt as if this was a novel I had to experience slowly and lounging in a big fat armchair, a pot of wind rushes beside me, to ensure I got the most from it.

title: Beautifully written, woeful conclusion.
text_review: I really enjoyed the writing style of this book - the figurative language, the beautifully crafted setting and the characters (if you overlooked the cliches) . Unfortunately towards the end it all took a dramatic turn for the worse. It felt like a publisher or editor had said it needed ‚Äúmore‚Äù and a murder mystery was shoehorned in. I would have been happy for it all to have been a tragic accident and left satisfied with the two main characters finally declaring their love. At that point I felt the story had come to a natural end.Unfortunately, the author then embarked on a rapid ‚Äútying up of knots‚Äù and the whole  plot became laughable. I cannot for the life of me see what the point of the poet revelation was, nor why we had to have a dash through the main character‚Äôs remaining years, and could have wept at the ‚Äúsecret under the floorboards scene‚Äù. I have never been so disappointed in the ending of a book that seemed so full of promise in the opening chapters.

title: 4.5 stars
text_review: WHERE THE CRAWDADS SING was a singular story, carried by a cast of many in the background but only Kya in the foreground. It was a story evoking strong emotion, anger and empathy and I experienced all of these feelings many times whilst reading. It was also a tough reading experience from a contextual perspective in a number of way and therefore there may be trigger themes for some readers.Kya was a young girl, a ‚Äòmarsh girl‚Äô abandoned by first her mother, then her siblings and finally by her father. She resided in a shack in the marshlands and learnt how to live. This aspect was much of the early book and my heart ached on reading. Kya was vulnerable, naive but a survivor with the kind of resilience that was hewn out of circumstance; it was do or die. Seeing Kya‚Äôs unfulfilled longing for love and relationships was distressing. There were themes of racism, prejudice and extreme poverty. I felt that these aspects were written exceptionally well with such tangibility.There were people who came into Kya‚Äôs life and made it bearable, Jumpin‚Äô, Mable and Tate. I adored Jumpin‚Äô and I loved Tate‚Äôs desire to help Kya without wanting anything from her. The lack of plain sailing was inevitable but it stung to read how things turned out. Chase was rotten from the first encounter and it was hard to see Kya‚Äôs naivety lead her in a sticky direction. The mystery that later unfolded was fascinating in a painful way.The narrative and description in this book was decadent in terms of the flora and fauna but there were no holds barred in terms of the reality of marsh and shack life. Delia Owens had a way of bringing nature to life, birds, trees and feathers, through their sights and sounds. My visualisation was vivid and that was down to the descriptive prose.I was grateful for the time frame and the journey in this book. I was relieved to have answers at the end and some surprises. This book has the kind of story that would appeal widely, regardless of what genre you might prefer; it is worth any reader‚Äôs time. WHERE THE CRAWDADS SING was a rare case of a book that lasts a lifetime and I sense it could also stay with me as long.Thank you to Corsair and Little Brown for the proof copy for review.

title: Really?
text_review: I am quite stunned by the excitement over this novel. Do people still believe in this fantasy romance? Yes, the language and descriptive passages depicting nature are lovely.  However, the self-education of this young woman is simply unrealistic. Most bothersome of all is that we are still being asked to accept that the way to success for girls is through the generosity of privileged white men. I really would have hoped we had progressed beyond this. Hugely disappointing and a great opportunity missed.

title: Interesting story but too disjointed for me
text_review: The story is one of Kya Clark and follows her whole life.  From infancy and gradually being abandoned by her family in a shack on the edge of a North Carolina swamp, throughout her evolution into a womanhood and then beyond her life.  Her various battles against adversity transform her from a societal outcast to a ‚Äòsuccessful citizen‚Äô in terms of the traditional Western metrics of achieving status in career and relationship.  The premise itself being an overarching clich√©.Conceptually, the novel interweaves the social politics of 1960s North Carolina with ecology and attempts to interject artistic tangents via descriptions of Kya‚Äôs painting and poetry, drawing comparisons with Elizabeth Gilbert‚Äôs Signature of All Things.  Disappointingly for me the story then centres around Kya‚Äôs romantic interests and the influence of her heterosexual relationships on her life including abandonment and a murder trial complete with courtroom drama to conclude.  I thought that this was disproportionately accounted for compared to the length of time she spent alone and over emphasised male dependency.The romantic descriptions of life on the marsh and coexistence with the nature was my favourite element of the novel and provided sufficient novelty and literary competency to negate some of the other issues I had with the piece.Generally, I thought the story too broad and not, by any means, deep enough to develop credible characters or situations.  For the narrative to work for me, I would have liked to have seen accurate representations of social and racial discrimination, alluded to but not developed farther than a mention.  This missed the opportunity that To Kill a Mockingbird seized and undermined the structure of the story, making Kya‚Äôs personal progress, the police investigation, and the court case unbelievable.  I think there is a danger in glossing over such important issues, in that it serves to minimise the damage done by prejudice and supports inaccurate historical representation.  I also found the conclusion of the story not in keeping with Kya‚Äôs character portrayed throughout as compassionate and fair.  Other inconsistencies included the standard of Kya‚Äôs education and artistic competency given minimal resources, the level of self-sufficiency she developed with little support or example and the level of success she achieved as a disadvantaged woman.In summary, I found the story interesting but suspending reality on the topics the novel attempts to cover didn‚Äôt work for me.

title: How to explain the path taken
text_review: In the marshland of North Carolina, still unspoilt in the early 1950s, inhabited only by a few  down-and-outs or those escaping justice,  branded ‚Äúmarsh trash‚Äù by the residents of nearly Barkley Cove, six-year-old Kya knows there is something amiss when her mother leaves their  decrepit coastal shack, carrying a suitcase. Kya‚Äôs  four older siblings soon follow suit, driven away by the violence of their drunken father. Expected to earn her keep by doing chores, she  avoids him as much as possible, seeking refuge collecting shells and watching herons  with flocks of  the gulls soaring over the lagoon shore. Bribed with the promise of chicken pie, Kya endures a day of bullying at the  town school, but evades the truancy officers thereafter. Abandoned by her father, she manages to survive alone with the help of strangers, including a boy called Tate who teaches her to read. So she somehow grows into a  beautiful and intelligent woman, desperately lonely but unable to fit into the community of Barkley Cove, where she is scorned as the ‚ÄúMarsh Girl‚Äù.This storyline alternates and contrasts with a  mystery in 1969 when the body of Chase Andrews is discovered in the mud at the base of an old fire tower near Barkley Cove, with foul play soon suspected. Handsome, athletic popular and married, he is also known to have been a womaniser, with Kya  among his list of conquests.This novel is remarkable for its mesmerising descriptions of the natural world, informed by the author‚Äôs knowledge as a zoologist combined with a skill which has won her at least one award and plaudits for nature writing. One can visualise every change in the landscape and wildlife as Kya makes her first journey alone by boat between the low-hanging limbs of giant trees, where ‚Äúduckweed colours the water as green as the leafy ceiling, creating an emerald tunnel‚Äù  then out to an estuary where ‚Äúwaves slammed against one another awash in their own white saliva‚Ä¶.. breaking with loud booms ‚Ä¶. then‚Ä¶ flattened into tongues of foam‚Äù.The novel is also strong on the psychology of someone who has lost trust through repeated abandonment and also the impact of the world on one accustomed to isolation. So, on her first journey by car to a distant large town,  travel on a main road is akin to a roller coaster without a security harness,  in  contrast to the wide skies of the marshes, mountains are disturbing because the sun keeps setting behind them only to reappear while the tower blocks and crowds of people at her destination are bewildering.Some who know North Caroline have criticised the factual accuracy of certain points but I can accept any errors as ‚Äúdramatic licence‚Äù. It is harder  to deny the implausibility of a young child being able to survive for so long, in apparent perfect health and no major accidents with such poor food, no innoculations.  To have been left in this state is unlikely. Kya‚Äôs ability to teach herself to such a high level, express herself so articulately, seems far-fetched. Like many novels, the plot is awash with coincidences, most of the characters are stereotypes, the harshness of Kya‚Äôs situation is too often leavened with excessive sentimentality, the final twist is rendered improbable by previous arguments and presented as morally justifiable  when it is in fact questionable.The author herself caught my interest by reason of her time in Africa where she and her former husband  became embroiled in controversy over  their campaigning against ivory poachers, in circumstances which may have inspired this book in some respects.Despite my reservations which are clearly a minority view on this international bestseller, I found it a page-turner and worth reading although I would be interested to know how male readers tend to rate it.

title: Lives up to all the Hype
text_review: I love my books but I am always hesitant to read overly hyped reads because they rarely live up to the hype and expectations created. It was for this reason that I had absolutely no interest whatsoever in reading this and only ended up doing so out of a sense of duty when an acquaintance recommended it and gave me their copy. It was one of those awkward cases where I eventually begrudgingly picked it up out of a sense of embarrassment over not being able to say id tried it when i bumped into them..... but how wrong I was....Where the Crawdads Sing had me drawn in hook, line and sinker from the first chapter. Part murder mystery and part coming of age, this book follows the story of Kya (The Marsh Girl) who has been all but abandoned by her family as a child and forced to rear herself in a shack in the Georgian swamps and marshlands. These same Marshlands are so beautifully drawn for the reader by Delia Owens that they become a character in their own right. And please don't misunderstand - that previous sentence is exactly the kind of claptrap to put me off reading under the assumption that this is a pompous, pretentious, boring book but it isn't at all!! Quite the opposite. Kya's story is one of resilience and also a lesson in the age old adage to not judge a book by it's cover - seen as little more than vermin by the local people, we the reader are privy to the highly intelligent, gentle, strong individual Kya really is. Throughout her story, we also meet some other great characters like Jumpin the kindly local swamp garage man who takes Kya under his wing.I zipped through this book and urge anyone like me who had written off this book to give it a chance - it was nothing like a expected and is now one of my favourite books iv read this year (And iv read a lot!). A great read and highly recommended by this Doubting Thomas!

title: A beautiful book which transports you to a different place and era
text_review: I loved everything about Where the Crawdads Sing. It is the story of Kya Clark who is living in a marsh in North Carolina. Her mother was from a good, reasonably well-off family, but has found herself and her five young children living in this impoverished situation with her husband who is a drunkard and abusive. One by one the family leave due to abusive situation leaving just Kya, the youngest child aged 6, and her father. After a rocky period with just the two of them, sometimes good, sometimes bad, the father disappears leaving Kya to fend for herself in their shack in the marsh on the edge of Barkley Cove town.It is a heartbreaking and heartwarming story of how Kya‚Äôs resilience comes to the fore and she learns to fend for herself with the help of a few people in Barkley Cove who are kind to her.  Mostly she is alone in the marsh but Jumpin‚Äô, owner of Bait and Gas store, and his wife, Mabel, make sure Kya has clothes, food, gas for her boat and basic necessities to survive. She also meets Tate, a friend of her brother Jodie, who is about three years older than her and shares her love of nature. Tate teaches her to read and looks out for her but then he gets a place at college so moves on.Kya was born in 1945 so most of the book is about her growing up in the 1950s dealing with her situation and isolation. Another thread of the book is in 1969 when Chase Andrews, a local football hero and womaniser, is found dead. The circumstances are unclear and many think he was murdered. Kya is one of the many women he has preyed on and deceived and there is suspicion on her as most of the local are prejudiced against her.I know many say you need to suspend belief to enjoy parts of this book but I was more than happy to do that as reading it in 2020 covid times I was more than delighted to suspend belief and be transported so vividly and evocatively by this author to a different time and different location. I am not surprised to learn the author is also a published naturalist as I loved learning so many things about marsh land and nature thorough this delightful book. It also has poetry and court room drama. A lovely book that will stick in my mind for a long time. It would make a beautiful film.

title: Marsh Girl
text_review: This book has received a lot of hype, so my book group decided to read it and decide for ourselves. It was certainly beautifully written and the narration by Cassandra Campbell was excellent, but I found the first part of the book a bit slow going. I'm also not much of a fan of court cases in my reads and although this one wasn't overly detailed, it was still a court case.Set in the 1950‚Äôs and 60‚Äôs, the narrative follows Kya, a "Marsh Girl", who is brought up in a shack on the shores of the marshes. She is the youngest in her family but feels happy and loved, until one by one, all her family leave and just she and her father remain. She tries to cook and clean, but at the age of 7, she doesn't have a lot of experience. Her father is a drunk and a bully but she persuades him to teach her to use his boat and they appeared to form something of a bond, until he disappears too and finally, she is all alone.As she grows into a woman she finds herself attracted to a couple of the men who sometimes frequent the marshes. Will she find love or just sorrow?I Googled images of the marshes of the North Carolina Coast and they were really quite beautiful, well deserving of the poetic language of this book. Even though Kya was so poor, she appreciated the beauty and grew to love the loneliness of her surroundings. Her detailed observations of the flora and fauna were impressive for a child who had never attended school.I don't know what I was expecting, I hadn't done much research before starting this book. I'm certainly glad I read (listened to) it but for me it wasn't quite a five star read.

title: Definitely NOT To Kill a Mockingbird
text_review: I had read some reviews and was keen to read this, given others had likened it to the classic Harper Lee novel but I was disappointed and wouldn't be in a rush to recommend it to friends so I am shocked this is still sitting so high on the list of popular books.The upside: it's a quick read (especially if you skim over repetition!) and I did keep turning the pages. The descriptions of the marsh and its creatures are captivating and it also attempts to tackle class and race discrimination.The downsides: The court case is laughably unrealistic: there is no tangible evidence of the crime committed, there is little plausibility that all elements would have come together to allow the perpetrator to commit the deed in the first place (a LOT of things would have had to have gone their way), the lawyers are constantly leading their own witnesses, etc. Decisions are also made by the author that make no sense: for example, why did we only find out about Jodie's scar so late? Why not tell us that detail earlier so that when the man with the scar shows up at the door, we the readers KNOW who it is because the detail was made significant earlier, rather than needing a flashback? At one particular character's death, I felt nothing and I really should have felt something because they played such a significant part in the book, but it was weakened by a death immediately preceding the death that should have had meaning (trying not to give anything away here!) so as to render both a footnote.I'm keen that when this is turned into a screenplay, that some very fundamental issues are fixed.

title: Lyrical, with a tough undercurrent
text_review: This was given to me for a Christmas present by my daughter. I did wonder about it as I read the jacket's notes, but once I'd read the first few paragraphs I was hooked.  I gather that this is the author's first novel. It will be a hard act to follow.  Kya is the youngest child of a clearly dysfunctional family, whose siblings leave as soon as they can leaving her with a mother worn down by her husband's inability to remain sober and hold down a job. The mother walks down the track, never to return. Eventually the father disappears too.So far,so potentially depressing, but this is not a Misery memoir. It is a record of a resourceful little girl who has learnt from her inadequate parents to survive on what Nature provides. The descriptions of the swamp environs, the plants and wildlife is at times too detailed, reminding the reader of the author's "day job", but it sets Kya precisely in her world. Whilst some in the "proper" world of town and society mock and reject her, there are continuous examples of those who do good quietly to make sure this Child of Nature is able to survive.  Kya's talents are finally recognised and encouraged by the boy who shares her interests, which leads to Kya sharing her world through her drawings and descriptions.  When the death of her rejected lover leads to her arrest those who have always supported her quietly come together to protect her. Imagine a wild shy woodland creature being confined and pining, then watch how she is quietly watched, protected and released.  That in many ways is Kya's story, "Nature red in tooth and claw".

title: Beautiful, well worth reading it
text_review: I picked this book based on all the great reviews I've been seeing and hearing from other readers and I wasn't a bit disappointed. This story is a real masterpiece and absolutely stunning work of fiction. I don't know why Delia Owens was waiting this long to treat us with her beautiful prose, but I hope this is not her last piece of work and we'll read many more astonishing stories from her.This book is mesmerising and really beautifully written, I don't think I read anything like this ever before. I was completely consumed by this unique story and was always worried for Kya, our main heroine, her well-being and at times was hypnotised by her strength and her ability to survive despite her unfortunate circumstances.Owen Delia's knowledge about the nature is really evident and apparent in this book and I loved her human traits comparison with those of the animals traits. This comparison gives reader a better understanding of characters behaviour and the perspective of the events surrounding the story.The author done great job developing all the characters. It was addicting to watch Kya grow and experience all she's done and who she became to survive when everyone she loved were leaving her one by one. It's a heartbreaking tale and while majority of the book is filled with prejudice, narrow mindedness and neglect, there is a fair dose of hope, acceptance, admiration and love.I really recommend to give this unique story a go and I can't wait for the screen adaptation of this book.

title: Powerful Prose
text_review: Good books get passed around my family with recommendations to one another, and recently for ‚ÄòWhere The Crawdads Sing‚Äô I am the third generation to award it a 5-star rating.  My family are not alone as I note the book has been in the Sunday Times best seller list of fiction paperbacks for over 30 weeks.  I ‚Äògoogled‚Äô crawdad to learn that it is a sort of crayfish crustacean, and there is a myth that if you go far enough into the wilderness and there is nothing but nature, then you will hear crawdads sing.Being in the wilderness and living with nature is at the heart of the book where a young girl learns about life through her interactions and survival in marshlands after being abandoned by her family.  She is totally alone in both physical and mental terms and has to provide for herself.  A few individuals help but generally she is scorned and ridiculed by inhabitants of the nearby village, and she opts-out of schooling after a single day with bullying.  Author Delia Owens skilfully tells the story of ‚ÄòWhere The Crawdads Sing‚Äô with great empathy.  Also she brings informative insights from her own background as a wildlife scientist, and she writes beautifully with magnificent imagery.The book is beautifully written and its structure has chapters headed by various explanatory words or by naming whoever is appropriate to the experience being recorded, and it shifts backwards and forwards between 1951 when the ‚ÄòMarsh Girl‚Äô was six years old to her death in 2009.  A few people help including a young boy destined for a research career in biology and ecology who teaches her to read and write, and later a popular local football hero who takes advantage of her, and a lawyer defending her in the face of bigoted villagers.  These are some of the ingredients of a gripping and compelling read, but there is so much more.It is difficult to identify a genre for ‚ÄòWhere The Crawdads Sing‚Äô as there are multiple layers including coming of age, romance, murder mystery, police procedural, courtroom drama etc.  In all its forms it is powerful prose ‚Äì fully deserving a 5-star rating.

title: It may not be the best book ever written,  but it will stay with one a long time.
text_review: First Sentence:  Marsh is not swamp.Kya Clark, aka Marsh Girl, virtually raised herself.  Her ability to watch and learn, and to depend on her North Carolina marsh allowed her to survive. When the handsome son of a prominent family is found dead, Kya is accused of his murder.  But was it an accident? Did she kill him?  Only with the help of others might Kya survive this, too.An author who paints pictures with words is one to be savored.  Owens does just that and does it beautifully.  There is a strong, lyrical quality to the writing‚Äî"Kya laid her hand upon the breathing, wet earth, and the marsh became her mother."The author does employ devices one may find annoying: multiple POVs and time fluctuations. Give it a chance, however. Before long, one may find oneself thoroughly captivated and willing to overlook those things.  Instead, one becomes immersed in a wonderful story filled with interesting characters, a setting which engages all the senses and emotions, and a desire for some real Southern cooking‚Äî"The aroma of sausage and biscuits, boiled turnip greens, and fried chicken thankfully overtook the high smell of fish barrels lining the dock. ‚Ä¶ Behind the counter, owner-cook Jim Bo Sweeny darted from flipping crab cakes on the griddle to stirring a pot of creamed corn on the burner to poking chicken thighs in the deep fryer‚Ä¶"Owens' descriptions are magnetic. She knows how to engage the reader‚Äî"There are some who can live without wild things, and some who cannot."  It is not all description.  The author creates interesting, strong secondary characters, including Jumpin', his wife Mabel, and particularly Tate‚Äî"His dad had told him many times that the definition of a real man is one who cries without shame, reads poetry with his heart, feels opera in his soul, and does what's necessary to defend a woman." One also learns the meaning of the title, and celebrate Kya's successes‚Äî"I wadn't aware that words could hold so much.  I didn't know a sentence could be so full."  Wouldn't one love to remember when one had made that discovery?Although there is a slight sense of fantasy about the plot, one can't help but be entranced by Kya's strength, courage, and perseverance‚Äî"I have to do life alone.  But I knew this."  But it's not all misty light.  Owen's takes us into Kya's feelings of being confined and through the trial, which was well done.The book isn't perfect.  The actions of one character don't always ring true and one may start to feel a bit manipulated. However, there is no question but that one's emotions become completely engaged to the point of possibly shedding tears at the finale; not a sad cry, but a lovely-ending cry."Where the Crawdads Sing" is a very good book.  It may not be the best book ever written or that one has ever read, but it is one of those rare books which will stay with one a long time. It will be interesting to see what Owen's writes next.WHERE THE CRAWDAD SINGS (Myst/Novel-Kya-North Carolina-Contemp) ‚Äì VG Owens, Delia ‚Äì 1st book G.P. Putnam's Sons ‚Äì Aug 2018

title: Lyrical Narrative
text_review: A gentle coming-of-age story and a murder-mystery, set along the coastal region of North Carolina ‚Äì a vast area of marsh teeming with insects and birdlife. The youngest child of an abusive marriage, Kya finds herself abandoned in the family home, a place which amounts to nothing much more than a primitive shack in the marshlands. She spends her time studying and documenting the wildlife, finding great solace in her environment. Her survival depends on collecting oysters and catching and smoking fish to sell to the local village store, in return for boat fuel and other supplies. She soon meets Tate, and they form a teenage kinship. Although he teaches her to read and their relationship looks set to blossom, Tate moves away to further his education, but breaks his promise to return. Chase, the handsome sporting hero about town wastes no time in pursuing the now mature, beautiful, and elusive Marsh Girl. Kya eventually falls for his superficial charms, until the day Chase reveals his true character and she‚Äôs forced to retaliate. Meanwhile, Tate has sourced a publisher interested in Kya‚Äôs detailed documentation of the flora and fauna of the marsh. While she‚Äôs on a very rare trip out of town meeting her publisher, Chase is discovered dead and the town points its many fingers at the secretive, semi-feral Marsh Girl.The first half of the book, describing Kya‚Äôs early years alone, I found a little tedious and repetitive: I‚Äôm not sure I completely swallow the fact that a girl at the tender age of seven finds the wherewithal to live quite as independently as Kya did, and that no one in the town sought to discover the truth about her living conditions and the absence of her family. And the dynamics of the murder reveal and the denouement, didn‚Äôt quite work for me. The strength of this novel lies in the lyrical narrative, which is rich in ecology, analogies, and the details of swamp life, all of which are expressed with a deft hand. It‚Äôs a unique setting, and the author uses clever comparisons of animal behaviours to add depth of character and explain motivation. I did enjoy the book, I just didn‚Äôt love it.

title: Beautifully written, captivating book
text_review: This is an enchanting but sad story.It is the story of Kya, the Marsh Girl, abandoned by her mother at an early age.Ma leaves in order to escape an abusive husband. Kya and her much elder siblings are left behind. Subsequently, the siblings leave too, including Jodie, her favourite brother.Pa is an unsympathetic character, who neglects Kya completely. She is often starving until she learns how to get hold of and sell some products.Kya can 't read or count. She only lasts one day at school, it being too hurtful to go there and be treated like ‚Äúswamp trash‚Äù.For me, one of the saddest things is that since Kya doesn't attend school, she doesn't learn to read. But then she makes a wonderful friend, Tate, who comes to her shack and teaches her how to.By that time Pa has deserted her too, or else he is dead, she doesn 't know.Tate is a good friend until he too abandons her. She is all alone. But the kindly black man, Jumpin' and his wife Mabel help Kya out and give her clothing.Kya collects shells and feathers and becomes an expert on the Marsh.Tate brings her presents of feathers. He is becoming an expert too.Occasionally, we jump forward in time and learn about the case of Chase Andrews, whose body is found in mysterious circumstances at the foot of a Tower and police are investigating what happened. Kya knows Chase too.This is a beautifully written book about a lonely, sensitive, gifted girl. I highly recommend that you read it.

title: Mills and Boon bought up to date
text_review: I acknowledge that I am out of step with most people who love this book and rate it 5* .  The story is one of Catherine ( called Kya)  abandoned by her mother , her siblings then her feckless father in the marsh and swampland of North Carolina and on the edge of a nearby town.  We are asked to suspend credulity; at the age of ten she is living completely on her own , surviving by collecting muscles and selling them to Jumpin at his Gas and Bait shop. Interspersed with her story is the investigation in current time of the apparent murder of a local man. Kya not only survives but thrives growing up to be slim and beautiful - quite startling that she has no health problems given that she seems to survive on Grits and fish! Two men enter her life. Tate, a teenager, teaches her to read and of course she becomes fluent - so fluent that within 6 months she manages to read 'Rebecca' though we are not told what she made of the tangled lives of Max de Winter and his wives.  Kya is soon borrowing books from a public library  and within a couple of years is mastering 'The principals or organic chemistry' and 'fundamentals of ecology' and musing on Einstein. Before long she is publishing books on marsh ecology. Tate goes away to college and a local man (Chase) enters the picture. He seduces her but of course it is clear all along he was never going to marry her. When he is found dead suspicion lands on Kya .  The plot is thin and reminiscent of the Mills and Boon books my mother used to read in the 1950s.  Clich√©s abound, the character are two dimensional stereotypes and the language wooden. The sex scenes and poetry are trite . I did finish it just to see if my thoughts re the so called murder were correct. They were. I wish I had not wasted my time

title: An interesting story
text_review: I have to say that the expectations for this book were pretty high from the beginning. Not only that the majority of this virtual book community loved it (or at least their reviews said so), but my best book buddies also gave it all the possible stars. The beginning was pretty hard, with all the words describing the marsh and the animal and biological species inhabiting it, but once the story went on, I got pretty hooked up on it. This is an astonishing story of a brave young six year old girl, left alone in the most uncommon place, the tiny shack in the middle of the marsh, with nothing but her own instincts and brains to help her survive. It is the story of living in fear but also in sync with the nature, coping with loneliness and betrayal, searching for love and giving second chances. What the author did the best was describing Kya's need for love and her inner fights between staying independent and strong, and falling for someone, giving herself and trusting another person. We follow her through her search for acceptance, her two big relationships, her growth and her heartbreaks. But one day she gets accused of a murder. And then it all goes downhill. The perfect surroundings and nature get replaced by the cold and life free cell, and the story of her interesting life gets transferred into all court drama. If only that part was a bit shorter, I'm sure I would enjoy the book a bit more. Nonetheless, the ending gets it right in every possible way, (so be sure to stick to it).What I loved the most was the character of The Marsh girl - sometimes stubborn, sometimes to hard on herself, but intelligent, strong, observant, sensitive and always in search for knowledge and understanding. Maybe its just me or the time I was reading this book, but even though I loved the main characters Kya and Tate, their love story which was so romantic and unspoiled, I just couldn't get all the emotions I felt I needed. I wanted to care for them, I wanted to root for them, I wanted to cry for Kya's unfortunate life. But, it just didn't happen. Hence, that's why the 4 stars for me. I will still definitely recommend this book to my friends, because of a great story, interesting plot and a breeze of a fresh air that this book gives us, taking us all to the wild parts of the marsh.

title: A book that reads like poetry
text_review: What a beautiful book.  This is the story of the survival of a child through the abandonment of her family to being brought up by the wilderness itself into the most amazing woman.  Kya is a wonderful character who we get to know through her life, as her mother, then her siblings abandon her to lead a lonely life in her wilderness home.  At first she is left with her father who eventually gives in to his alcoholic, gambling interests.  We know that she is safer with him gone, providing she finds a way to bring in a small amount of money to feed herself, having no other bills as she has no gas, electricity or water to pay for as her shack is without any utilities whatsoever.She starts selling mussels to the local shop owner for cash, while his wife provides Kya with clothes from her church as she grows and develops.  Kya is made to attend school one day, but the traumatic experience of being bullied by the other children leaves her determined never to return.  She hides out in her home surroundings so well that the truant officers give up chasing her, leaving her alone and without any help or support.The descriptions throughout the book are almost poetically perfect.  Whilst reading, the reader can‚Äôt help but imagine the surroundings like a painting, hear the birds sing and smell the rotting scrubland.  She is a determined child and she teaches herself to cook after watching her mother, clean the house and do the laundry also after watching and copying.  Likewise she teaches herself to sail the boat left by her father and this enables her to flourish in the life she makes for herself.However, she is frustrated by not knowing what comes after 29.  Luckily she becomes reacquainted with Tate, a boy older than her who offers to teach her how to read, and count.  We find out that Kya is a talented young girl who absorbs all she is taught like a sponge.  She learns all about the flora and fauna of her surroundings, delighting in learning and classifying her world.  Unfortunately when Tate starts university he becomes yet another person who abandons her as he believes that Kya wouldn‚Äôt fit in with the world he now inhabits.Unfortunately for Kya, the next person who comes into her life is not interested in including her in his life, as he keeps her a secret from his family while they spend time together alone.  After seeing each other for almost a year, Chase talks about marriage, raising hopes in Kya of being introduced into the society outside of her shack.  This is all a lie as he becomes engaged to another girl while seeing Kya.  Their relationship ends as he becomes yet another person who has abandoned Kya.Tate seeks out Kya as he becomes aware of how she is being treated.  However, Kya‚Äôs heart is now hardened and she refuses to let Tate back into her life as she can no longer trust him.  After seeing her sketches and detailed notes of her surroundings on the walls of her shack, he suggests he takes some with him as he might be able to get someone interested in her work.  This is successful and Kya gets an offer to write a book which will include her illustrations and observations of life in the marshland.Kya gets more money than she has ever known for her book, which becomes the first of many.  Kya is now able to get services into her shack, including her first toilet. Things are definitely looking up when Kya is sexually attacked by Chase.  She fights back and leaves him in pain after a failed attempt at raping her.  Kya May be naive, but she knows that men like Chase do not like being beaten in such situations and she knows she will be forever looking behind her.The same weekend that she is away meeting her publisher, Chase is found dead.  This leads on to a court case when Kya is accused of his murder.The conclusion of this book is brilliant.  Not wanting to give away any spoilers there are more surprises in store for the reader.  The book reads like a longer book, there are no spare words.  On finishing this book, I felt sad that it was over, with no hope of a sequel.  It‚Äôs a lovely experience reading this book.  I know many people have loved it.  If you haven‚Äôt read it yet, please do.

title: A solid thriller!
text_review: Thank you so so much @hachettebooks for a #gifted copy of Where The Crawdads Sing!What I have with this book is a love/hate relationship I kind of ship!I was so overly excited when I received this book that I started it straight away just to leave it aside for a whole month after just 40 pages!!I couldn't get into it. The writing style, the vocabulary used and the story itself made me think that, although this book it is a lot of people's favourite, maybe it wasn't for me.But many people kept telling me that the book gets better, that the story picks up and so I thought: Right! Let's do it!And so I ended up enjoying this book and liking it very very much!People were right when they said that the story gets better and after 50-60 pages in, things started to happen, events started to take place and I couldn't put this book down!I loved Kya, the main character. I loved how strong she is despite the life she has had, and I loved her character, how she dealt with everything and everyone.I also liked the romance story. I didn't expect it and although I am a big thriller fan, I am starting to read some more romances and this one in particular was a very good one!I enjoyed the murder investigation chapters very much. I enjoyed the whole journey from when they find the body until they discover what really happened.The last third of the book was my favorite part without a doubt. I really enjoyed the trial part. It was very well done, interesting and intriguing. The perfect end for this book!

title: Breathtaking and Beautiful
text_review: There is a moment where Kya, the main character, on reading her first book says 'I wadna aware that words could hold so much. I didn't know a sentence could be so full'. This is a perfect metaphor for this beautiful novel.In late 1969, perfect American boy Chase Andrews is found dead and suspicion quickly falls on Kya Clark, the 'Marsh Girl'. Throughout the novel we follow the timeline of Kya's life as first her mother, then the rest of her family abandon her, leaving her to live alone on the marsh. The narrative is juxtaposed with the build up to and subsequent trial of Kya for Chase's murder.The novel has echoes of 'To Kill a Mockingbird'. We witness prejudice, small town politics, hope and good people. At the heart of the novel is Kya and her story is achingly beautiful.As her family departs, Kya's teacher becomes the Marsh surrounding her. It becomes as much a character as Kya herself, the descriptions and love that Kya has for her home are simply wonderful. She takes her moral compass from the wildlife surrounding her, life lessons from the landscape and grasses and passions from the sea and tides. The marsh is home, a sanctuary providing a much needed escape for Kya. As the first line read by Kya says 'There are some who can live without wild things and some who cannot'.I have truly adored this novel and since finishing it keep dipping back in to read favourite chapters. The Marsh is as strong a character as Kya and Delia Owen's writing makes it a guiding hand to her. Despite the prejudice that exists amongst the townspeople, there is also good - Tate, his father, Jumpin' and Mabel. By and far the most engaging part of the novel is Kya herself. Strong, determined and proof that your background does not define who you are. This is a testament to the human spirit and a love letter to the Marshes. Breathtaking and beautiful.

title: Something Different
text_review: Delia Owens is not an Author that I had heard of before."Where The Crawdads Sing" is quite intriguing and really is something different.  The story covers so many aspects of life and in particular early experiences at home (being let down and abused). 'Marsh Girl' Kya Clark amazed everyone by her accomplishments. Just because she was different from what local people classified, she was constantly criticised. The general consensus was 'when in doubt, think badly of her. We travel with Kya through her struggles, her heart breaks and her success. There are many twists and turns making this debut novel and absolute page-turner.This story wold translate very well into the small screen for a short series.

title: Five stars is not enough!
text_review: THIS BOOK HAS GONE IN MY TOP 10 BOOKS OF ALL TIME! Just to put that into perspective, I have read well over 1,000 books and I haven't had a book go into my top 10 for about 8 years. That's how much I love Where the Crawdads Sing.This book enchanted, mesmerised and enraptured me. Kya, the Marsh Girl, took my heart and held it firmly in her grasp until the end of the book and beyond. It is about survival, loneliness and prejudice but so much more than that: it's about nature and wildlife and the elements.The prose is lyrical and lush and wrapped me up in a huge embrace. I lived alongside Kya with the birds and the deer, I rode in her old boat through the marshes with her, I raced down to her piece of the beach with her to feed the gulls. I wanted to eat this book up in one gulp, but I was afraid of finishing it and leaving them behind and so I read it slowly and savoured every sentence.To say I have a book hangover now I am finished is an understatement. I want to go back to page one and start all over again. I envy those of you who have yet to read Where the Crawdads Sing. What a treat you have in store. If you have read this book, other I can recommend that gave me the same feels are Witch Light by and Wolf Totem by Jiang Rong, The Snow Child by to name a few.

title: Wonderful modern classic!
text_review: This is a coming of age story with a difference and it is so beautifully written that I think it would be difficult not to be drawn in by its compelling plot.Kya grows up in the marshes living alone in a shack. Abandoned by her mother at 7 years old and left with her abusive alcoholic father, Kya learns to look after herself and rely on no one.  When her father disappears too she is truly alone.The locals call her the marsh girl and she is teased on her one and only day at school so refuses to return. She finally  learns to read and write when Tate, a friend of her beloved but absent brother Jodie befriends her and teaches her. She gradually falls in love with Tate and starts to trust that he cares for her  but he too leaves her to go to college and she is destined to be alone again.She is attracted to local bad boy Chase Andrews and they then start a relationship but it is clear from the start that he does not have her interests at heart and only cares about himself.However the book is written in two timelines- the 1950s as Kya grows up and 1969 when Chase Andrews is found dead, having fallen from a tower. Kya is accused of his murder and the second part of the book focusses on the investigation and subsequent trial.The book is very descriptive with wonderful passages describing the marsh and the wild animals and birds that live there. It is well written but also quite a compelling read which I couldn‚Äôt put down.I loved the character of Kya, how she managed to survive alone, abandoned by her whole family but desparate for human contact. Her relationship with Tate was beautiful and heartbreaking.Jumpin, the black garage owner who sells her fuel for her boat is also a great character. Gradually, over the years he begins to look at her like a daughter and help her as much as he can. Kya is an outsider because of her lifestyle and so is he because of his colour although he has family that care about him unlike Kya.Set in the Deep South of America, it certainly had the feel of a modern  day classic  and in parts  reminded me of ‚ÄòTo Kill A Mockingbird‚ÄôIt is  a truly excellent debut by this author and I will definitely be looking out for more books by Delia Owens.Thanks to NetGalley and the publishers for my arc in exchange for an honest review.

title: Amazing read
text_review: Kya has been abandoned by all her family and finds solace only when in the marsh surrounded by her wild animals and nature. Until two boys come in her life and in her heart new feelings erupt.Delia Owens has a beautiful way of describing nature and surroundings and for sure that‚Äôs the reflections on her expertise on nature and animals, as she is a zoologist.I was completely amazed by the way Kya‚Äôs behaviour and life was inspired by the marsh and loved her from the first pages, I don‚Äôt think in her shoes I could have survived what she had. Tate, Mabel and Jumpin as well were characters which I‚Äôve really appreciated throughout the book and had enough depths to them, so I could completely relate to, even tho the story wasn‚Äôt fully focused on them.However I didn‚Äôt feel Where the crawdads sing didn‚Äôt deserve 5*, cause I would have preferred to have included in the book a recounting of the night in which Chase died. How did it happen? I think that would have connected all the Ford in the story.But overall an amazing read!

title: The jury knew better than the author!
text_review: Reading the many reviews of this novel it is clear most readers love it but a few loathe it. I am somewhere in between, but certainly more positive that negative. I found the basic story-line about an abandoned girl growing up largely on her own in the marshes of North Carolina intriguing (though it does strain credulity that she never suffers significant illness). The descriptions of nature in the marshland is compelling and the accounts of her fumbling relationships with the two young men who take an interest in her make sense in a strange sort of way. But the way this is all interwoven with a crime whodunnit is problematic. We feel for Kya because she is the victim of prejudice, are pleased that the jury overcome their prejudice to declare her innocent, and then we discover at the end that she did, after all, kill Chase. A clever twist, you might think. But the circumstances in which she could have committed and hidden the crime are so unlikely that my instinct is to think, no she couldn't have done. The jury knew better than the author!

title: Beautifully written
text_review: This book kept popping up on so many must read lists that I felt a compulsion to read it.¬†Kya Clark is known as the Marsh girl and for years has been picked on by the locals because she is different. She was abandoned by her family when she was six and rather than risk been taken into care decided to fend for herself. Kya strange life style makes fascinating reading and as the story progresses she grows up into a beautiful young woman. It is plain to see why she is attracting two men in her life, Tate and Chase. Chase is a bad boy and although he is already seeing a few other local girls he now has his sights on Kya. The other man in her life Tate is the complete opposite to Chase but shares the common aim of winning Kya's attention. But in late 1969 everything changes when Chase Andrews is found dead and the locals automatically suspect Kya.The more I read of this novel the more I enjoyed it, for me it started slow but I think that was more down to the complete change in reading genre. Beautifully written and it is easy to see why the novel gets so many plaudits.

title: A haunting, beautifully written chronicle of an extraordinary life
text_review: It is as difficult to classify this book in terms of genre as it is to describe Kya, its amazing protagonist. The book is part mystery, part legal thriller and part coming-of-age chronicle, blended with a eulogy for the wonders of the natural world, as epitomised by the North Carolina marshlands.Kya Clark herself is an alluring enigma. Youngest of five children of the poverty-stricken Clark family, who dwell in a rough-hewn shack in marshlands near the North Carolina coast, her life seems set to be one of despair and neglect. The novel opens with Kya, then still very young, hearing the door opening and then seeing her mother, dressed in her finest clothes, walking up the rough driveway towards what passes for the main road. Kya never sees her mother again. Oppressed by their father‚Äôs rage and violence, her elder siblings all drift away, leaving Kya alone with her father. Somehow they manage to struggle by, and her father‚Äôs drinking and rage seem gradually to improve, although before very long he too simply goes and never returns. His disappearance is never properly explained, and Kya is left alone, her age barely into double figures, to fend for herself. This she manages admirably, demonstrating a level of amazing resourcefulness.Having been biorn and raised in the marshlands, Kya soon finds her way around, and carves a life out for herself. At one stage the authorities eem to have caught up with her, and the local Truant Officer drags her to school. She stays there for just one day, during which her separateness from the other children is rendered unbridgeably vast. She never returns, and the inhabitants of the nearby small town largely forget about her, although stories circulate about ‚Äòthe Marsh Girl‚ÄôI should stress that despite the fairly dramatic, even traumatic, incidents I have cited above, this book does not fall into the category of ‚Äòmisery saga‚Äô that seemed so popular a few years ago. Kya‚Äôs upbringing is hard, but it is also a story that resounds with hope.At different times, she encounters and befriends two young men from the town. Chase Andrews is wealthy, handsome and seems to have it all, which has left him spoilt, and entirely unused to having his wishes denied. The other boy is Tate, who is clearty entranced by Kya‚Äôs beauty, and who perseveres to break down her shyness and wariness with townspeople, eventually becoming her closest friend and teaching her to read. He will eventually leave town to go to college, where he wants to study marine biology. In the meantime, he has taught Kya all he knows, and she develops her own extreme expertise in that area of study.The novel consists of two parallel narratives. The first starts in the early 1950s and follows Kya‚Äôs life, a story that is interspersed with incidents starting in 1969, when the body of one of the townspeople is discovered in suspicious circumstances, which prompts a murder investigation.It is beautifully written. Delia Owens clearly has her own finely-developed insights into the flora and fauna of the marshlands, and a clear understanding of the fragility of the marsh ecosystem, and the beauty of its inhabitants, and this is conveyed throughout. Kya is a fascinating character: beautiful, independent and ultimately resourceful, seemingly capable of circumventing all the adversities (and there are lots of adversities!) that are thrown her way. The prose is simple but beguiling.The book is not flawless, and I wonder if the writer might have found herself struggling up against her deadlines. It seemed to end very suddenly. I also found that Kya went from being taught how to read at all to working her way through complex biological texts within the shortest of intervals. These are, however, very minor, almost petulant, cavils, and the book hung together wonderfully.Perhaps it is too early to start thinking about the best novel I have read this year, but this is definitely a long way ahead of any competitors at the moment.

title: Poignant tale of loneliness and survival
text_review: Where the Crawdads Sing was recommended by a friend, who said the writing was beautiful. She wasn't wrong. It's a story of grinding poverty, neglect and abuse among the 'marsh people' in 1950s and 60s North Carolina. The central character is Kya, abandoned by her whole family before she is even into double figures, and left to fend for herself in a rundown marsh shack. The animals and birds become her family, and though she doesn't go to school, a friend of her brother teaches her to read and write. He brings her books and encourages her to document the 'treasures' she finds in the marsh. There is a love story here too, and a murder (maybe?) but the narrative interweaves seamlessly. I would have given it 5 stars but for the frequent insertion of poetry, which jarred a little. Overall, it's a story about hope, and the importance of allowing love into our hearts, however wounded they may be.

title: Brilliant
text_review: This one grew on me as you follow Kya right from a little 7 year old and abandoned by all her family into adulthood. The neglect and loneliness that Kya experiences as a child and teenager is just heartbreaking. And this loneliness continues as she grows and develops relationships with Tate and Chase and spreads her wings out into her little town. The prejudice experienced by Kya is just awful and you can see why she relates to Jumpin and his wife Mabel (the black couple who run the local shop). I really liked how Owens describes the the marsh and its inhabitants - very much a character in its own right and simply beautiful. She also did a great job of making me connect and feel for Kya, given the rather unusual situation (both in childhood and adulthood). I must admit, I did see the big reveal coming, but not it‚Äôs delivery. A great read and Campbell does a great job as narrator.

title: Beautifully Original
text_review: So many people recommended this book to me that I was reluctant to read it in case it didn‚Äôt live up to the hype. It did!The story of Kya, abandoned by her family and doing her best to survive alone in the wild marshlands was beautifully written. I know nothing about the world Kya lives in, but the author painted such a detailed picture with words that I could visualise the landscape, the birds, the insects, the plants and the people. The use of colloquial language and dialects for the dialogue added another layer of authenticity to the story. The way that different poems were interweaved throughout the story added yet another dimension to the imagery the author created.Kya‚Äôs character is vulnerable but strong; her resilience, her love of her environment and its wildlife, her passion for learning despite being illiterate, and her issues with relationships and abandonment meant that I was rooting for her from the very beginning. I experienced every emotion alongside her and often found myself holding my breath in anticipation as situations unfolded.I thought I‚Äôd guessed the ending, then changed my mind and wasn‚Äôt disappointed when the truth was revealed. The final poem was perfect.

title: A beautiful and well written story
text_review: I have just finished this book and simply can't understand some of the negative reviews I've read.  I'm so glad I ignored them and believed the majority and read it for myself.  I won't regale the tale again.  So many people have already done so, needless to say I it was an easy for me to award 5 stars to this superb novel.  I found the writing just so evocative of life in the deep south.  The descriptions of the wildlife, swamps and marshes, the weather and the feelings it inspired in Kya are just wonderful.  My favourite character was Jumpin' and his wife Mabel who cared for Kya, identifying that she faced as much discrimination as they did.  I know people would say they're a bit of a cliche, but for me, they demonstrate the warmth and generosity that would have been a reality amongst the black community of the time. The characterisations of Kya and many of the major players in this novel were so well written that they were utterly believable.  I'm sure that many children, like Kya and her family, faced a life of poverty, suffering the violence of an abusive husband and father and perhaps, still do so today.  I found the journey through the pages often emotional, peppered with frustrations at the prejudice aimed at the Marsh Girl and the affect it had on her.  Ignore those terrible reviews, read it for yourself.  I loved this novel and thoroughly recommend it!

title: Beautiful and inspiring
text_review: Wow. That‚Äôs really all I can say right now. The praise that has been heaped on Owens‚Äô book is extremely deserved. It‚Äôs so different from other books of its type.The use of the split timeline is inspired. We start the 1969 timeline with the discovery of Chases‚Äô body and the other timeline goes back to 1952 to show Kya growing up and explains why she is the way she is. I absolutely loved this. The earlier timeline enabled me to get to know and understand Kya a little more whilst the later timeline was laying out the evidence and eventually the trial.Kya‚Äôs story was heartbreaking at times but also incredibly inspirational. The characterisation was beautiful and the ways she dealt with the, at times, overwhelming levels of adversity was truly inspiring.I hadn‚Äôt read much about the plot of this before starting it, apart from the synopsis on the back, so I don‚Äôt really know what I was expecting but it blew me away. The writing is exquisite with the flow drawing me in and keeping me there. Every time I picked this up I‚Äôd be desperate to read more.Without giving away any spoilers, the ending was absolutely perfect to me but at times it was a rocky road getting there. Parts of the trial had me so angry and I just wanted to reach into the book and help Kya.The way the narrative is split across the two timelines made it different to a lot of other books of this type and I think helped me to understand Kya and how she had ended up in this situation. She is a character I warmed to instantly and you go through a lot with her during the course of the book, suffering her lows and celebrating her highs. I feel like this is one I‚Äôm going to be thinking about for a long time after it‚Äôs done and would definitely recommend it if there is anyone out there who still hasn‚Äôt read it!What a great start to 2020!! I couldn‚Äôt fault this at all.

title: Not worth the rave reviews
text_review: Completely unrealistic and implausible plot. The characters, including the protagonist, have no depth. And don‚Äôt tell me that her being an innocent hermitic ‚Äòmarsh girl‚Äô is an excuse for poor, superficial characterisation. I think the author intended to present a character with an almost primitive mindset that we more ‚Äòcivilised‚Äô and urbanised folk aren‚Äôt meant to fully understand, but there was too much that didn‚Äôt make sense because the characterisation was so poor. The most anaemic of the characters was her love interest. He was really pathetic, all the way through the story. That alone was off-putting. My friend loved it. I didn‚Äôt. The ending, the most interesting part of the story, sadly doesn‚Äôt do enough to explain or justify the nonsensical plot. I just didn‚Äôt buy it. This author should stick to nature writing - which she does beautifully- not writing novels.

title: A Little Disappointed
text_review: (CONTAINS SPOILERS) I was excited to purchase this book because of the hype surrounding it. Firstly, I adored the descriptive and poetic narrative of the marsh (hence the 3 stars) - I really felt like I was there and that I was able to share Kya's love for it all. However, I felt the characters lacked depth and throughout the book there were many scenes that were almost rushed and glossed over with a few sentences. Perhaps this was the author's intention to kind of make the reader feel separate from what was going on as Kya would have felt. However, it was still quite frustrating and left me feeling disappointed.Secondly, the ending was also a let down for me. I mean, the court case (which I also felt was rushed and lacked depth) pretty much proved she hadn't done it, but as a twist she had done it after all?! Whaaaat?! This makes no sense. If she had done it, that was extremely calculated, out of character and nigh-on impossible with the bus timings! It just felt like a convenient plot twist that the author threw in for good measure but didn't quite work. I have a horrible feeling they're going to make this into a cheesy, slightly boring film at some point...

title: Amazing Read
text_review: This is an incredibly beautiful novel from Delia Owens, totally immersive, an ode to the natural environment and the marshes in particular. Catherine Danielle Clark, aka Kya, is 6 years old when her mother leaves their shack in the remote wilderness of the North Carolina coastal marshes, next to the town of Barkley Cove. Her family is desperately poor, and before long her siblings follow suit, abandoning her to the care of her alcoholic, neglectful and abusive father, and at 14 years old, he too leaves her for good. Completely isolated, school proves to be a tortuous experience, she stays for only one day, avoiding all attempts by the truant officer and others to bring her back. Kya is the Wild Child, The Marsh Girl, Marsh Trash as far as the residents of Barkley Cove are concerned, directing hate, ridicule, contempt and hurtful prejudice at the bewildered Kya, as she becomes the target of harrassment and attacks, the community dehumanising and shunning her. No-one other than the black Jumpin and his wife, Mabel, offer help or advice to the lonely girl, and they face a barrage of racist attacks and humiliation themselves.Unable to read and write, longing for the return of her mother, Kya desperately desires company, and to belong. For a while, she receives some sustenance in the form of Tate, who looks out for her, teaches her to read and write, and shares Kya's joy in the marsh world with its insects, wildlife, birds, weather and her untethered hold it has on her, collecting ever rare feathers and shells. A close relationship develops between the two of them until he leaves to study marine biology at university. Tate leaving has the effect of chipping away at Kya's inner capacity to trust as she once again finds herself isolated, but her curiosity about the marshes, and her ability to paint all that resides within it, has her pursuing a deeper and more academic knowledge of it. However, she still wants to belong and her burgeoning sexuality and hopes for marriage and family are met with betrayal, treachery and worse. In a narrative that goes back and forth in time from the 1950s to the present of 1969 onwards, where the favoured son of Barkley Cove, the golden boy Chase Andrews is discovered dead by two boys, having fallen from a tower. There is no evidence of murder, but the Sheriff is uneasy, and Andrews‚Äôs mother and the town are bursting with rumours of murder so a trial ensues.Owen has written a captivating and mesmerising novel, unforgettable in its vibrant descriptions of the marsh location and the life within it. Juxtaposed with that is the small town of Barkley Cove, indifferent at best, malicious and dangerous at its worst, with none of the spirit of compassion to support a young child forced to find ways to financially survive, emotionally bereft, finding comfort in poetry that lends weight to her inner feelings. Despite all the horrors and struggles she faces, she makes something of herself, something which Barkley Cove refuses to acknowledge. Her profound sensitivity to nature, which proves to be the ultimate educator, shapes Kya's perception of the human behaviour she encounters. The marsh is where she belongs, it and all that it entails is home, everyone else has left her, leaving her exposed and vulnerable when she begins to feel fear. It is barely surprising that when elements of her life begin to shift that she would be wary and distrusting, although buried parts of her harbour tiny sparks of hope. This is simply superb storytelling that winds it way into your heart as I rooted for Kya amidst the barrage of turbulence and heartbreak she endures. Amazing read. Many thanks to Little, Brown for an ARC.

title: Very average book
text_review: This is a story about a young girl, Kya, who grows up living amongst the marshes of North Carolina. We are introduced to her from a young age, where we see her being left to fend for herself as her mother abandons the marsh shack she and her family live in, and when finally it is only she and her father, who disappears for days at time drinking and gambling, then he too eventually one day leaves and does not return either. Being left in this way we see a young girl learning how to survive and become resilient to life, learning how to sail the rivers and estuaries around the marshland, and collect mussels which to sell as her only means of money to buy such basics to eat. The novel is set across 1950 - 1970, at time where communities carried such prejudices against people like Kya, and name her the 'Marsh girl'. As Kya learns to become resilient against the community of Barkley Cove, we see how she begins to learn how to live as part of the marsh, by feeding birds and getting to know particular animals behaviour and the different flowers and fauna which grow there, often having no-one to share her thoughts and feelings with but the wildlife around her. Childhood friend Tate then teaches her to read and loans her many books on the ecological systems of the marshes, where she begins to develop and deepen her knowledge and passion of the wildlife she lives in, to the point where years on she makes money by writing and illustrating books on this subject matter. The book also sees Kya deal with the issue of loss; having lost her family over the years as they all gradually abandoned the family home, and then her childhood friend and first love Tate leaves her, and then she is later deceived by Chase, another member of the local community who she forms a relationship with. We see Kya make parallels between her life and how creatures, such as bullfrogs, behave with one another, males luring females to mate and then how they move from one partner to another in a deceptive way. She makes comparisons between this and her own life and how she feels she has been let down, in particular by male relationships in her life. As her ability to read improves she also discovers poetry her mother left behind, and begins to develop a love for this, again making comparisons to particular lines in poetry to the life in which she is living. The book jumps back and forwards in time, where we see Kya grow up over the years starting back in the 1950's, but forward to 1969 where the body of Chase is discovered dead. The chapters show an unfolding of events between the two times, which finally culminates in 1970 where Kya is on trial for the murder of Chase. Whilst I found this whole story in the main well written, there were parts which I felt relied on a simple narrative of events. The story itself I felt was quite simple, to the point of being somewhat predictable at times, which for me was what let the overall book down, not really drawing me in fully with any twists or having a desire to know what happens next. It was an easy text to read, and being set in the marshes, the natural setting and ecology referenced in the book made an interesting read as well as the pieces of poetry entwined in the text, however, this is no more than an average book for me.

title: Compelling and addictive -
text_review: This book is a combination of history, nature and humanity. When those three things combine in a novel, it‚Äôs nearly always beautiful ‚Äì and this book is no exception.Like quite a few people, I wasn‚Äôt sure about how I was going to feel about this book. I was actually given it in April this year for my 30th Birthday and until July I didn‚Äôt feel ready to read it. But after I had a few more University essays behind me ‚Äì and a lovely visit from friends in North Carolina to prompt me to read a bit more about its history ‚Äì I got stuck in.  ‚ÄúShe knew the years of isolation had altered her behavior until she was different from others, but it wasn‚Äôt her fault she‚Äôd been alone. Most of what she knew, she‚Äôd learned from the wild. Nature had nurtured, tutored, and protected her when no one else would.‚ÄùI couldn‚Äôt stop reading it. Granted, the first few chapters were tricky and I wasn‚Äôt sure which direction the book was going in. But that‚Äôs the best part about books ‚Äì the ones that surprise you are often the best. The ones that hook you in halfway through and completely turn around your opinion‚Ä¶they‚Äôre even better.It‚Äôs the 1950s when we first meet Kya and learn about the bulk of her upbringing. She‚Äôs young, her mother has just walked away from the family home, and with her Kya‚Äôs siblings slowly disappear into the marsh as well. Kya brushes along with her alcoholic Father for a few years ‚Äì dodging the school system, sheltering from the shrewd opinions of the locals ‚Äì until she‚Äôs alone in the marsh, fending for herself. The book is written in two parts ‚Äì and I feel that part one definitely focuses on the beauty of the marsh (as well as the challenges) and part two pinpoints the darkness of the swamp.  ‚ÄúSand keeps secrets better than mud.‚ÄùDelia Owens is already the co-author of three non-fiction books about her life as a wildlife scientist in Africa. This is her debut novel ‚Äì and it has taken the world by storm. Perhaps most fascinating for me was when I started to dig into Owens history ‚Äì I always do that when a debut novel strikes a chord. I almost can‚Äôt quite believe it‚Äôs the authors first foray into fiction world! So it probably isn‚Äôt surprising to learn that Delia herself and her ex-husband were at the centre of an investigation into the killing of a poacher many years ago. Delia‚Äôs true life and the life of Kya in the book run parallel on more than one occasion. Delia spent much of her adult life (over twenty three years) in partial or extreme isolation due to her work.  ‚ÄúI wasn‚Äôt aware that words could hold so much. I didn‚Äôt know a sentence could be so full.‚ÄùNow that University is coming to an end I‚Äôve allowed myself the luxury of joining a few more reading groups on Facebook. I‚Äôve noticed that quite often people post a photograph of a book and say something like, ‚ÄòWhat do people think of this‚Ä¶so and so said it‚Äôs awful so I‚Äôm not sure whether to give it a go‚Ä¶‚Äô Sometimes, they‚Äôre books that are at the top of the top of the charts. I‚Äôve seen it written a few times about this book ‚Äì and I can assure you, it‚Äôs worth giving it a go and more‚Ä¶ It was liked enough that Reese Witherspoon is looking into producing it for the big screen‚Ä¶Amazon have recently announced that it‚Äôs held their number one spot for longer than any other book.  ‚ÄúOwens reminds us that we are forever shaped by the children we once were, and that we are all subject to the beautiful and violent secrets that nature keeps.‚ÄùThis book delivers a massive punch ‚Äì right at the end. I saw it coming but from the reviews I‚Äôve read there have been mixed surprise. Secrets are unearthed as the book progresses and despite the culmination in the story at the end ‚Äì Delia Owens reaches this conclusion with a gentle hand and easy writing. One of the biggest questions at the end of this book was‚Ä¶ Do Crawdad‚Äôs really sing? Well Delia Owens has an answer for that‚Ä¶  ‚ÄúTechnically, scientifically, crawdads do not sing. But I‚Äôve made a bit of a study of it myself. And I‚Äôve found that first you must go‚Äî all by yourself‚Äîand set up a small camp in real wilderness. I‚Äôm speaking of a place far from any road or village. Not a park, but a remote and wild land filled with Earth‚Äôs creatures. Just before dusk, you must walk deep into the woods and stand there exposed and totally alone as darkness descends around you. When you can feel the planet beneath your toes and the trees moving about, you must listen with all your ears, and‚ÄîI promise‚Äîyou will hear the crawdads sing. In fact, it will be a chorus. ‚Äù ‚Äì Book Browse

title: Wonderful
text_review: I‚Äôm always dubious when a book has been hyped up so much and worry¬†that I‚Äôll be¬†in the minority of people who don‚Äôt like it. I really didn‚Äôt have to worry this time, Where The Crawdads Sing went well beyond my expectations and I loved it.Kya is a character that you will instantly take to your heart, starting off as a young girl living at home in the marsh with her parents and brother Jodie we follow Kya as she grows up and is left to fend for herself. I adored reading about Kya although I felt heart-broken at times and just wanted to sweep her off the pages and protect her. I think everyone, no matter what age could learn a lesson from Kya, she has it tough but boy is she a tough little cookie.Along the way Kya meets some wonderful characters who include¬†Tate, Jumpin and Mabel, each one¬†helps Kya in a certain way but like with any town or village there are those that think they are above themselves and Kya, the marsh girl as they call her isn‚Äôt welcome.As well as being a coming of age story, Where The Crawdads Sing has a murder mystery thrown in, as well as a bit of court room drama and¬†romance. It‚Äôs a mixed bag but it works so well and although this isn‚Äôt a fast paced story it flows and has the reader completely hooked and drawn in. I didn‚Äôt want to rush the story, I enjoyed taking my time and absorbing every word.Delia Owens has written a debut novel that is wonderfully descriptive, the marsh comes to life through the words and I felt it was as much of a character as Kya was. The natural beauty and the ever-present wildlife became like a mother to Kya and it was just wonderful to read about.I can honestly say that this book lived up to the hype its receiving and its well deserved, it‚Äôs been an absolute pleasure to read and it‚Äôs a story that will stay with me for a long time. Where The Crawdads Sing will be¬†one I‚Äôll definitely be recommending, I think it will appeal to many and if you haven‚Äôt read it yet then don‚Äôt hesitate, it‚Äôs wonderful.

title: The power of the female
text_review: 4.5 starsI have a lot I could say about this book but I'm determined not to spoil it. It is gloriously and evocatively written (I actually listened to it and some of the descriptions of nature brought tears to my eyes). It is a book about the power of nature and the power of women. If you're considering reading it go for it - and give it time. For a while there I almost gave up but that slow start is there for a reason.Two things:-1.
