There has been a huge amount of negative criticism online about this book and I'm fairly sure had the author been a man (or written under a gender neutral pseudonym) a lot of the criticism wouldn't exist (there is an assumption amongst a certain sort of male reader that women are only capable of writing "Middlebrow" fiction.2. You probably will see the twist coming from quite a long way away. But it's OK. As I said, the book is about the power of women, of female creatures in general actually, and so working out the twist will only confirm that.Enjoy.

title: Absorbing and memorable
text_review: Kya is "The Marsh Girl", who has spent her life living in the marshlands of North Carolina. Since the age of seven she has lived alone, shunning society and finding ways to eke out a living. She knows the marsh like the back of her hand, is familiar with every bird and plant and shell, but she is deeply uncomfortable around people and hardly anyone has ever got close to her. When a body is found in the marshlands, it's natural for the locals to assume that the crazy Marsh Girl must have been the murderer.In many ways this is two books in one. There's the story of how Kya grows up, learns to fend for herself and gradually lets a few people into her world. This part moves slowly, with lots of descriptions of the marshlands and its wildlife. It is atmospheric and haunting. The other part is the murder investigation, which initially is in the background but gradually takes over.If the book was a movie I would rave about the cinematography and directing, but I'd say the acting let it down. There were too many times when we get told how people feel in a situation rather than intuiting it for ourselves. While I could accept that Kya could teach herself so much about the natural world, I found it harder to believe that a woman who barely spoke to other people would have such a rich vocabulary and love of poetry. Nor did I buy into the central relationship between her and Tate. Neither of them ever felt like real people to me and ultimately that meant that the core of this otherwise absorbing and memorable book felt a little hollow.

title: Where The Crawdads Sing
text_review: Where the Crawdads Sing is not my usual genre, but I had seen so many wonderful reviews I decided to take a break from my usual thriller reads and try something completely different and I am so glad I did.Where the Crawdads Sing is an absolutely BEAUTIFUL book with exceptional character development, magical and atmospheric descriptions and the language was poetic, raw and breathtaking in places.Set in the 1950‚Äôs and 60‚Äôs, Kya is a ‚ÄúMarsh Girl‚Äù brought up with her older siblings and parents in a shack deep in the North Carolina Coast within the Marshes.  At the tender age of 6 her mother walks out abandoning her children and husband and within a year the rest of the family have left leaving Kya alone to fend for herself.This story centres around the mysterious death of a young man called Chase Andrews and we are taken back and forth from Kya‚Äôs earliest childhood memories to the time Chase‚Äôs body was found.Without giving anything away Where the Crawdads Sing is a combination of historical fiction, mystery and coming of age.  The spellbinding words bring the Marshes to life and Kya is a character that literally jumps out of the pages, under your skin and buries herself deep into your heart.This is an emotional story of love, loss, abandonment, fear and loneliness but the overall feel is hope.  Highly recommended.

title: A love song to the Carolina marshes
text_review: Kya is six (she thinks) and her Ma has just left home.  Her father is violent and often drunk and his beatings drive her elder siblings away one by one.  Soon there is only Kya and her father left and Kya has to learn to cook, clean and survive.  She manages one day of school before being bullied out but she finds it easy to escape the school truancy team by hiding in the marsh.  One day her Daddy doesn't come home and then Kya has to survive the best she can.  Friendship with Tate, a local boy, helps her learn to read and write and Kya falls in love.  When Tate leaves for college Kya falls for a local boy who treats her badly and when he is found dead, Kay is the main suspect.For the majority of this novel I was entranced.  The writing is so lyrical and warm, Kya is a complex and interesting character and I was prepared to forgive the gaping holes in the story because it was almost like a fable, the tale of the Marsh Girl.  However towards the end I found the story far too predictable and the 'twist' at the end was just annoying.  90% of this book is wonderful, the rest lets it down.  However what shines through is the story of the marsh itself, the wildlife, the weather and the whole ecosystem.

title: Hard read
text_review: Kya was gradually abandoned by her family, having to grow up and survive on her own in the Marsh. She knew the ins and outs of the swamp, Including the wildlife. She‚Äôs a very quiet, shy girl, who keeps herself to herself. She only went to school once in her entire life and hated it, so she kept herself hidden in her shack. Then a boy, who falls in love with Kya teaches her how to read, write and count. She became friends with 2 people from the ‚Äòcoloured town‚Äô. Jumpin and his wife Mabel, who helped her when she was in desperate need for clothing and food.It is a good story, but painfully slow at the beginning and sudden, short and deflating at the end. From beginning to about half way through, I found it very hard to understand and in some cases, hard to pronounce. As the story went on, it was easier to read. This is because it‚Äôs based in North Carolina, where they have the southern twang.

title: BY FAR ONE OF THE BEST BOOKS OUT THERE
text_review: I picked up this book not expecting much of it because I learned that not all "hyped" books are actually that amazing. Well, I was surprised when I couldn‚Äôt stop reading. I wanted to go deeper and deeper into the story, I wanted to dive in and take it all with me. I imagined myself in the marsh, quietly observing how a six year old Kya was waiting for her mum to return, was wondering why everyone abandoned her and I felt the loneliness surrounding her but also the incredible determination to survive, to live and learn, to provide for herself and avoid all trouble.Kya is ‚Äúthe marsh girl‚Äù ‚Äì the dirty kid everyone avoids, the uneducated, the savage child nobody wants to have anything to do with and most definitely the one expected to fail. In reality she is a smart and clever girl who knew the marsh and found ways to make money and provide for her basic needs.It is an original story, a true page turner, haunting and unpredictable book. It has it all ‚Äì a coming of age story, adventure, a murder and mystery but also lots of love. It‚Äôs a winner from page one. It is so beautifully written that it wraps around you and captures all your senses.This is by far one of the best books I have ever read and I am so looking forward for the movie. Thank you Reese Witherspoon for deciding on taking this book as a project and for choosing it as your book club pick as well and making it so known in the world of readers.Also, I can say that as a debut novel, Delia Owens climb up the writers ladder very fast and I am so waiting for another incredible book from her.

title: Amazing book
text_review: Every now and again, you read a book that simply blows you away. So, this book was "Where the Crawdads Sing". It was not only superbly written, moving and intense, but also delivered a great great ending too. I cannot recommend it enough. This is the story of Kya, aka Marsh Girl, a child abandoned by her family, ostracised by people who should have helped her, growing up in the marshes in North Carolina, on the outskirts of Barkley Cove in 50s. Kya learns to trust no one until she grows up and yearns to belong. At the same time, we follow the story of the mysterious death of the popular young man from Barkley Cove - is Kya involved in his death? What has happened to Chase? "Where the Crawdads Sing" is a story of heartbreak, loss, loneliness, but also hope, endurance and love. It's poetic language, beautiful descriptions of nature and Kya's isolation are emotional and atmospheric. Although the sadness permeates from pages, there is also beauty, acceptance and quiet endurance. For Kya, nature becomes her mother, the marsh becomes her home and family and despite the sadness, there are also moments of beauty and peace in it. The friendships that Kya develops, the deep understanding of the world around her, it all infuses the book and leaves the reader speechless. This book highly deserves all the praise.I received this book in exchange for an honest review

title: Beautifully written
text_review: Where the Crawdads Sing is a highly readable novel about Kya, a young girl growing up in abject poverty who has to raise herself in the coastal marshes of North Carolina in the 50s/60s.Essentially a feral child (although bright and literate), Kya has an innate ability to connect with the natural world around her. From the animals to the water and woodland. The most interesting and tender moments focused on her learning to navigate the cruel and confusing 'civilised' world using what she knew of the natural world.There's some YA romance thrown in and a dash of mystery and even a bit of courtroom drama for good measure. The bulk of the book, though, is Kya's relationship with the marsh she calls home and the writing focused on that is immpecable. By contrast the courtroom section feels dry and stale. I'm not sure if this was intentional on the author's part to show the stark contrast between the natural world vs civilisation but even if not, it worked for me.(semi spoiler alert - no details ahead though)I didn't even mind the happy ending and the other thing because they were a footnote in the overall story and the author didn't feel the need to make it long and drawn out. It felt beautifully connected without disrupting the narrative of young Kya.So, all in all, it was a memorable book with some really exquisite moments of descriptive and poetic writing.

title: 5 stars for this beautifully written and emotionally compelling story
text_review: My heart went out to Kya from the very early pages, the moment when her mum walks out on her when she is just 6 years old. Living in a marshy wilderness alone, Kya is feeling lonely and abandoned, as people in the town turn their backs on her, making her feel unwelcome. Kya only has nature to nurture and protect her when no one else would and the wild creatures of the marsh as her friends.The chapters of Kya's story starting in 1952 are intertwined with murder investigation chapters set in 1969 until the two timelines collide. For one reason or another, Kya becomes the prime suspect in the murder case as she has history with the 'dead' local golden boy and a couple of witnesses can place her near the crime scene. But how can the Marsh Girl get a fair trial with the jury full of prejudiced villagers who rejected and ignored her for years?The vivid depiction of the marsh surroundings, the heartbreaking story of Kya's survival, the suspense of the murder trial and especially Delia Owen's beautiful prose completely sucked me in and made the reading of the novel such a memorable experience. I loved this book and cannot recommend it enough.Many thanks to NetGalley and Little, Brown Book UK for my ARC in exchange for an honest review.

title: Nice character led, summer read
text_review: In Where the Crawdad Sings, we follow the trials of Kya, The Marsh Girl, living in the North Carolina swamplands through the 1950s and 60s. Abandoned by all the family she knows by the time she is 10, she is often met with prejudice and suspicion from the local townsfolk.  However Kya shows resilience and fortitude when most people would have given up. Her childhood friendship with Tate is something to be savoured as he shows maturity beyond his years when he teaches her how to read. Once she has the power of words, Kya is truly free ‚ÄúI wasn‚Äôt aware that words could hold so much. I didn‚Äôt know a sentence could be so full‚Äù.Ward‚Äôs accurate descriptions of nature obviously come from meticulous research and this enables the reader to see Nature as another character - a third parent that shapes and looks after Kya ‚ÄúPushing against the sea‚Äôs strong body, she is grasped, held. Not alone‚Äù.The murder case that is presented in this story is secondary to the power of nature and Kyra‚Äôs relationship to it. As a reader we are presented with facts for and against Kya but all we want is for her to be out in the open again and reunited with nature. Whether she is guilty or not doesn‚Äôt matter. A fabulous read.

title: Stunning
text_review: A beautifully written coming of age/mystery novel and love story.It's wonderful to find a book whose words sing out at you and this is certainly in that category.  Owens sense of place is mesmerising and her characters sensitively drawn.The book evokes a time and place that is alien to most of us but we are drawn in to the extent that it becomes so real it's tangible. My heart broke for Kya to extent that I didn't know if I could bear to read on at one point but I'm so glad I did. I won't go into detail and spoil it for those who haven't yet read it but I will say I didn't wee the end coming and that's unusual for me. Very unusual.If I could give this book more than five stars I would. The best book I have read for a long time.

title: One you'll want to read slowly to make last forever
text_review: It's all been said before so I'll just say this isn't my usual type of reading at all but with all the hype I felt I was missing out on something and should have a look. I'll be honest and say I put it down about 10% in as I couldn't get going and read a few other books but something drew me back in and I gave it another shot. Am I glad I did that! I adores this beautiful book with it gorgeous descriptions of the area Kya was left to survive in, but without being twee or too much. About 50% in I realised it was one of them books where you want to read fast but at the same time don't because you know you'll be sad when it ends. I was totally enamoured with the poetry included as it's just not for me but I found I could skin read this and move on with the story no problem. All in all I'd describe this book as breathtaking and one that I'll remember for a long time to come.

title: Great read, but a poor ending...
text_review: I‚Äôm not sure why people have taken such umbrage with this book - I really enjoyed it for the most part. It is beautifully written and the protagonist is extremely likeable. The imagery is good, but it‚Äôs not as evocative as I expected from reading other reviews.The book itself is relatively simple and very easy to read. There are aspects of the storyline that seem unbelievable, in this day and age, but it‚Äôs important to remember this is set in a different time. (And as a Brit, I‚Äôm neither surprised nor shocked by the justice system portrayed, as I don‚Äôt know any different.)Without giving away too much, there are times reading this when you feel like pulling your hair out. It is ridiculous and you feel so frustrated for our protagonist. This is how you‚Äôre supposed to feel.That being said, I detested the ending to this book. It led me on a journey that had ups, downs and down right stupidity in places and I was rooting for our leading lady at every turn. For a while, I was delighted and then, the last chapter destroyed everything I thought I knew.  Whilst I was extremely disappointed with the turn of events, I can‚Äôt say it made me hate everything else I‚Äôd read previously. When I think of this book, I‚Äôll remember it fondly and just emit the ending from memory completely!Let‚Äôs not forget - this is a work of fiction. Whether you feel the circumstances believable or not, is completely irrelevant. Isn‚Äôt that why we read fiction? To get lost in something that‚Äôs not real life? If you want something completely relatable and believable, with no mystery or magic, then maybe fiction just isn‚Äôt for you.

title: Absolutely beautiful
text_review: Nothing pleases me more than a book that is poetic and rich with descriptive prose.  I cannot believe that this is Delia Owen's first fiction book.  It is simply stunning.I was mesmerised from the very first page.  Kya is left by her mother, her siblings and finally by her father.  Alone, this beautiful child learns to survive in the wilds of the marshes.  She is cast out by the villagers who should help her but she continues to thrive with the love of the birds.Her story is poignant and heartbreaking at times but also lifting because it is a story of survival and overcoming prejudice.Sometimes I think I could write a book and then I read something like this and know that never in my lifetime could I create something as beautiful as this book. And so I continue to just be a reader instead so I can enjoy the very skillful craft of writers like Delia.

title: Thoroughly enjoyed it
text_review: I‚Äôm always a bit wary when it comes to reading a book that has so much hype around it, and has high expectations to meet, but this one certainly didn‚Äôt let me down.This book has so much going on in it‚Äôs storyline that it covers a range of genre types from Mystery, Romance, Suspense, and Police Procedural. For me, I really enjoy that in a book.The way this book has been written, and the detail in the description that has gone into it,takes you right into the story and gives you such a clear picture of what is going on, some of which fills you with warmth, some of which fills you with dread and sadness.A fabulous ‚Äúall round‚Äù book that I have throughly enjoyed.

title: Read this book
text_review: I bought this book because it was recommended to me as a good read. I wasn‚Äôt disappointed. The story has so many layers to it, based on one child‚Äôs journey into adulthood having been abandoned by those she loves and are supposed to care for her. There are adults who help her from a distance. A local boy teaches her to read and this opens up opportunities for her to thrive. Her situation also makes her vulnerable to abuse of which she suffers to a horrific degree.Alongside the story is a police investigation of the murder of a local resident. These story lines eventually collide and move apart again.The poetry used is the only voice she has to engage with at times and to help her through her emotional rollercoaster.This book examines loneliness, abandonment and societal childcare brilliantly and with great empathy. A really good book.

title: Beautiful
text_review: This is a beautifully written, extremely emotive book. The blurb made it sound absolutely dreadful and I'd never have picked it up if someone hadn't recommended it to me. I laughed out loud when I read the negative reviews on here but then life would be dull if we all liked the same things! I loved it; perhaps the storyline is far fetched in some places (I actually don't think it's implausible and, hey, it's a work of fiction) but the deeper meanings within the storyline really resonated with me. To the people picking apart the police and legal procedures: it's America in the 60s, I wouldn't be surprised. And if you've never ran down a beach screaming to the gulls then, quite frankly, you need to do so immediately.

title: Reminiscent of A Girl of the Limberlost
text_review: What a delightful read and it certainly lived up to the hype. The story reminded me of a favourite childhood read ‚ÄòA Girl of the Limberlost‚Äô that had me enthralled as a young adult and the same themes run through this book.An abiding and profound love and respect for nature is at the heart of this story and the unlikely heroine, Kya Clark, is brave and resilient in the face of adversity. Abandoned by her mother and siblings and left to fend for herself in a rundown shack with only her drunken father to provide for her, Kya turns to the marsh and the sea and lagoons that surround her. Eventually, even her father fails to return from a bender, and she is all alone. With no money to buy food, she starts selling oysters to buy her necessary provisions and learns to forage and hunt and fish to survive.The natural world around her becomes her classroom and her source of income, and she resists all attempts to by the locals to get her to attend school. She has a deep mistrust of the local people, and they never try to earn her trust; instead they call her names and vandalise her shack and treat her with contempt.Only a local boy called Tate And Jumpin and his wife Mabel go against the current and befriend Kya. Tate teaches her to read, and this opens up a new world to Kya, and Mabel teaches her the facts of life and how to cope with growing into a woman. The book covers so many relevant themes - small-town prejudice, child abuse and child neglect, resilience against all the odds, love and betrayal and racial tensions, all set against the backdrop of a wild and untamed landscape.The author, Delia Owens, is a wildlife scientist as well as a writer and her love of nature comes across vividly in the book. The beautiful descriptions of the marsh and surrounding lagoons transport the reader to another world.Kya‚Äôs journey from childhood to adulthood is beautifully written and a joy to read.GillianBreakaway Reviewers received a copy of the book to review

title: A beautiful and gripping
text_review: ÍßÅÔº≤ÔΩÖÔΩñÔΩâÔΩÖÔΩóÍßÇ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ùêñùê°ùêûùê´ùêû ùêìùê°ùêû ùêÇùê´ùêöùê∞ùêùùêöùêùùê¨ ùêíùê¢ùêßùê†‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚ÄúThere are some who can live without wild things, and some who can not.‚Äù‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ùêíùêÆùê¶ùê¶ùêöùê´ùê≤For years, rumors of the 'Marsh Girl' have haunted Barkley Cove, a quiet town on the North Carolina coast. So in late 1969, when handsome Chase Andrews is found dead, the locals immediately suspect Kya Clark, the so-called Marsh Girl. But Kya is not what they say. Sensitive and intelligent, she has survived for years alone in the marsh that she calls home, finding friends in the gulls and lessons in the sand. Then the time comes when she yearns to be touched and loved. When two young men from town become intrigued by her wild beauty, Kya opens herself to a new life - until the unthinkable happens.‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ùêëùêûùêØùê¢ùêûùê∞I absolutely loved that we follow Kya throughout her childhood. How she copes with her traumas growing up.  See how she teaches herself to survive in the Marshes. Kya is so resilient and such a strong character as she explores her world.The story focuses on how the town see Kyra and the prejudices against her. She‚Äôs just an outsider, a Marsh girl who has to fend for herself, isolated and alone in a vast world with nothing but the gulls to keep her company. I instantly fell in love with her and my emotions ran with hers. She is definitely my favourite character.The story has a gentle flow about it. It‚Äôs not too fast paced, not until right at the end. Delia Owens knows how to tell a story with fantastic description. I could just see everything in my imagination. I felt like I was right there with Kya either in the mud flats or on her boat floating around the lagoons. The language was also fantastic.I really enjoyed learning about the nature and biology aspect in the book. Deliah has an unsurpassed knowledge and understanding of nature and I loved how she incorporated that into the story.It was such a beautiful read and will stay with me for a very long time. Definitely has the beginnings of it being a classic.Highly recommend.ùêëùêöùê≠ùê¢ùêßùê†: ‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è

title: What a good read!
text_review: This book is set in the marshlands of the North Carolina coast of America.  Two main threads to the story.  One part starts in the early 1950s, the other in the late 1960s.  The book is about the life of Kya Clark, known locally as the Marsh Girl.  The early 1950s part of the story follows her growing up in the marsh and isolated from most other people in the area.  The 1960s part relates to the discovery of a body of a well known local man who is found dead on the edge of the marshland.  Can these stories really be connected?The setting here, both in terms of place and time, are vivid.  The writing draws pictures effortlessly.  The sense of atmosphere is almost tangible.  The local look down on the marsh dwellers and the marsh is often seen as an inconvenience to be resolved.  Kya grows up loving the place and becoming an expert on it.  As her real family dwindles the gulls and marsh creatures become family.  The marsh itself becomes her playground and school as well as a source of income.I found this book incredibly easy to become immersed in.  Kya is one of those characters who will stay with you for a long time,  Other characters are well rounded and interesting in the main.  It is descriptively very strong however I never felt that this slowed down the narrative.  I became a watcher of Kya's life and felt the highs and the lows.As this book had been published in the USA before it was published in the UK I was able to read reviews of it before I had the opportunity of reading it.  It came over as a remarkable story.  I am somewhat distrustful of books that everyone raves about and I considered not taking it.  However the outline of the story appealed and I'm very glad I read it.  Without question it is one of the best books I've read this year.  It will stay with me for a long time I'm sure.  This is a very rich story of the environment, people and their lives and deaths with a great central character.  What is there to not like - 4.5/5Note - I received an advance digital copy of this book from the publisher in exchange for a fair review

title: Gorgeous love song to the beauty of The North Carolina marshlands
text_review: I listened to this on audible, and it's a good one.  I loved this book so much and would read it again when it comes out in paperback.Coincidentally, like Everything Under by Daisy Johnson, that I just reviewed), parental abandonment, living in the margins and being close to water are also key themes.  This one is set in the marshlands of North Carolina and centres on the story of the extraordinary Kya, The Marsh Girl, who survives alone, living in abject poverty.There is little more I can say without dropping in spoilers.  It's courtroom drama, love story, whodunit, survival story.  But its so much more than that. It's a gorgeous love song to the beauty of the flora and fauna of the marshlands. It is such an unusual setting for a story and you can practically feel the wind in the grasses and see the light on beach. And Kia its towering heroine.

title: Good!
text_review: I think the greatest aspect of this book and it‚Äôs strength is Kya, she‚Äôs feisty with a great sense of self, she has a wild strong will despite everything, and the wilderness where she lived I was fully into, this part of the book in my eyes had a touch of Circe (which I loved) so this got me.However the story then drifts off in a direction I didn‚Äôt find overly necessary, it‚Äôs heartfelt yes and it‚Äôs aims to make the audience think but I liked the wild marsh girl - you can‚Äôt please everyone right.But I do recognise this is a strong debut, I can see why people are falling for it all over the place and if you are a fan of books such as Beartown and Little Fires Everywhere I think this is a 2019 must read!

title: Loved it, so different.
text_review: I was so sad to read some negative reviews of this book, I have read hundreds of novels during my 72 years and I found this to be absolutely beautiful. It undoubtedly goes into my lifelong top ten. It's a debut novel too.  I loved the beautiful images the writer put into my mind's with her exquisite descriptions of the natural world. It took me right out of my "coronavirus fug" for a little while. I love courtroom dramas and enjoyed the one that comes in the final part of this story but the real beauty and joy of this book comes before all that.  It was truly a joyful experience to become so immersed in such a lovely story.

title: An incredibly beautiful book
text_review: This book made me laugh, cry and fall in love with the marshland.I absolutely loved this book, it was so beautifully written and brought me to tears a couple of times but made me smile. Kya is such a beautiful character and has such an amazing, deep soul that you can't help being drawn towards.This book is all about Kya who has been abandoned by everyone except the nature around her in the marshlands. She learns from them and learns to fend for herself in a world that is silent from all man-made sounds apart from the marsh boats.This book touches on racism, segregation, abandonment and overall the love we need to be showing each other.I'm having so much trouble reviewing this book because I absolutely loved it and can't fault it at all. This book deserves all the praise it gets. It is magical.

title: The nuances of a second reading.
text_review: I first read this book December 2018 and now it has been put on as material for our book club. So I read it for the second time. I was positively impressed on first read and am even more impressed on the second. The strength of the central character is so well developed and that's not to take away from the others. The wildlife observations are so accurately appealing that I feel as though I'm all too familiar with the North Carolina swampland. Setting the story in such a location adds to the ominous undertone running through the account. With being aware osf spoilers, the courtroom scenes are possibly a little long drawn out. Perhaps the book didn't need the last chapter; there's a whole other book to tell the rest of Kya's life

title: 1960's fairy tale
text_review: An interesting books I thoroughly enjoyed as some other reviews have stated it is far fetched, if you look pass that and enjoy the story. The descriptions of the marsh are realistic, saltiness in the air,a sand between your toes, the sun on your face.  Kya is a delight an abandoned child left to grow and evolve in her marsh world. Learning about the male species. She learn to read with the help of her friend Tate. Her journey as she grows. its an easy read I did look up on the map where it was based to get an understanding of the location. Partly predictable but didn't stop me from finishing the book (Kindle)  read with my local "Hunters" book club.

title: A breathtaking and spectacular debut
text_review: Breathtaking, mesmerising, haunting, beautiful, heartbreaking and unforgettable: just a few words that first come to mind when I think of this sensational book.The story begins in 1969 when two young boys discover the body of local football hero Chase Andrews lying in the Marsh.  There is immediate suspicion that the death is not accidental and talk of who could have wanted to kill him.  We then go back to 1952 where six-year-old Kya is sat on the front porch watching in disbelief as her ‚ÄúMa‚Äù walks away in her best shoes carrying a suitcase.  The book then continues in dual timelines: we follow the hunt to find who killed Chase as the police try to ascertain what is rumour and gossip and what is fact, and also watch as Kya grows up on the Marsh and learns to not only survive, but flourish.Reading about how Kya lives was difficult and heartbreaking.  She is seen as ‚ÄúMarsh Trash‚Äù by those who live in Barkley Cove, and avoided and vilified by adults and children alike.  After her Ma leaves, her siblings soon follow and she is left alone with her Pa, a violent drunk who is often absent.  When he eventually abandons her too she has to find a way to make an income and finds a friend in Jumpin,who owns Gas and Bait which sells gas and groceries, and his wife Mabel.  Her one day at school was a disaster so she gets her education from the world around her and studies the Marsh, sea and sand.  For many years she‚Äôs unable to read but then Tate, who was a friend of her older brother, offers to teach her.  They inevitably fall in love and he awakens a side to Kya she didn‚Äôt have before, one where she needs someone and enjoys another person‚Äôs company.  When he leaves her heartbroken she feels unable to trust anyone and completely withdraws into herself and her Marsh again, determined never to rely on anyone but herself from now on.Very quickly after Chase is found, suspicion from the townspeople falls on the Marsh Girl, who was rumoured to have had some kind of relationship with him at one point.  Her elusive behaviour each time the police try to talk to her doesn‚Äôt help convince people of her innocence. It seems even in the absence of evidence most people have decided they know what happened and convicted her of the crime in their jury of small-town opinion.By the time I was half way through the book I was consumed and couldn‚Äôt stop reading. It was a completely different book to what I expected it to be, although I don't really know what I expected. I knew I had a book I loved on my hands and that the trepidation that comes with reading a much talked about, hyped book was unnecessary.The author has a remarkable ability to make you feel and understand from Kya‚Äôs perspective in this book.  You feel her crippling loneliness at a life lived truly alone, her overwhelming fear of anything or anyone outside the Marsh, admiration that she surviving such a life and all she accomplished despite the odds, and anger at the way she was treated, judged, used and failed by almost everyone she meets.Delia Owens is a phenomenal writer, and Where The Crawdads Sing is a spectacular debut.. It is a long book and I admit there were times that reading it felt like a slog, but that was because of the southern dialect and heavy subject matter and not because of boredom.  I loved this story and it didn‚Äôt take long for me to find it hard to put down. It is an eloquently written, powerful, emotive, and extraordinary novel.  It is a masterpiece that you won‚Äôt be able to forget and will stay with you long after you read it.

title: Where the Crawdads Sing
text_review: I have to admit that I was first drawn to this book because the title intrigued me. Then I read the blurb and a couple of reviews and I thought this would tick a box I needed from a read at the moment. I have read a few books recently which have been somewhat spoiled for me as I managed to guess too much too early and really wanted something that would wow me and I figured that this could be the book to do just that. And I am very pleased to say that I wasn't wrong as I absolutely loved the book from start to finish.We follow Kya from her time as a small child as, one by one, her family start leaving her until she is left with only her father. She has to grow up quick as he is not really the fatherly type and soon starts to become resourceful, which is a good thing as soon she finds herself all alone. Dodging the education authorities, she learns to survive mostly from what she learns about the marsh in which she resides but she does also have a bit of help from a few very lovely people.In amongst watching Kya grow up and blossom into a woman, we also go forward in time where the body of a young man has been found and follow the police as they try and make sense of what happened to him. As the two threads progress, eventually they start to give sense to each other and the whole truth eventually comes out.This really was the most beautiful book. Not just Kya's story, which in itself was fascinating and emotional, but also learning about the place she calls home; the marsh and the flora and fauna contained therein. I really did lose myself in the atmosphere of the place and whenever I closed my eyes I could see it all clearly, something that doesn't often happen as I am not usually a very visual reader. Even though my main go-to genre is crime, at times I got so lost in Kya and the marsh that I almost forgot that there was also a crime to figure out along the way. Until, that is towards the end where it all started getting a bit clearer and, hand in hand with that, a bit more emotional too.Oh how I loved Kya, she pretty much ran me the gamut of emotions as I learned more about her, as I saw her grow and come of age. How I started to wish that the book would last forever so that I wouldn't ever have to leave her. She definitely took a big place in my life for the duration of my reading this book.It's a book of survival against the odds, of resilience, loss and hope and many more things in between. It's a tale of not fitting in but then finding a way to fit in, to trust. It's a book that I am so glad I read and one of the very few that I will probably re-read and that total is still in single figures despite reading more than 300 books a year past few years. At the moment, and I know it's still early days, it's my favourite book of 2019 and I am sure will still be top ten by December 31st.My thanks go to the Publisher and Netgalley for the chance to read this book.

title: Good story and very atmospheric descriptios
text_review: I really loved this book. The descriptions of the marsh, the little town, and the people were so detailed that you felt you could see them. The narrator in this audible book was brilliant and used different voices for each character and really hit the Carolina accent.I have been to the area so it did help me to picture the scenes. the marshes, the inlets and bays and I could almost see Kaya in her little aluminum boat.This is a love story, a mystery, and a detective story as well as a very sensitive portrayal of loneliness and how one little girl manages to survive by herself by immersing herself in nature that surrounds her.

title: Spoiler Alert
text_review: For years, rumours of the 'Marsh Girl' have haunted Barkley Cove, a quiet town on the North Carolina coast. So in late 1969, when handsome Chase Andrews is found dead,the locals immediately suspect Kya Clark, the so-called Marsh Girl.***I'm conflicted....In two minds about how it is I truly feel about this book and no doubt I will probably at some point amend my review.But for now this book for me is only worth a 3/5* stars and my reasons for this review are that while I loved the main character Kya. Honestly fell in love with the lonely girl who against all odds not only survived but thrived after being abandoned by her whole family. I found the actual story lacking.Her plight as a child in the first half of the book had me hooked, desperate to discover how this fragile creature would survive, not just being left alone in the marsh but the people of the town too... But by the time the second half started and we began to follow Kya throughout her teenage and adult years, I found myself at odds with the story and I actually put it down for two solid days before resuming. Not out of my love the book but out of my desire to know what happened to that little girl I fell in love with.Over all unfortunately it left me feeling underwhelmed. But that could just be a by product of all the hype and the expectations I had laid at this novels feet even before I picked it up.In summary it wasn't a bad book, it didn't leave me wanting to put it in the bin, but it also didn't leave me wishing the story would never end so that I could stay in Kya's world just a little longer.

title: I loved it!
text_review: There are mixed reviews on here, and on my book group page. Personally I loved it, I thought this book was beautifully written and descriptive. I now always order the sample on kindle and if I'm enjoying it, I buy the book. Some people on my book group said it was slow to start and they gave up reading it (some of these were 'Fifty Shades' lovers so couldn't really take their reviews seriously!) but I didn't find that to be the case, I was sucked in straight away and had me gripped right to the end, although I did feel the ending was a little rushed maybe. People have different reading tastes... some will love it, some will hate it. If you really want to read it, then read it and don't be put off by the bad reviews. Each to their own!!

title: Where The Crawdads Sing
text_review: Where The Crawdads Sing is the story of Kya, a young girl who is abandoned by her family and left to fend for herself. Already on the outskirts of the  community, in more than just her location, she rarely ventures out of the marshes and spends her days learning about the habitat around her. When she does let the outside world in, she learns that it can be both scarier and more accepting than she could ever have imagined.The lyrical and descriptive writing made this a very easy book to listen to and get lost in. The descriptions of the marshes were so in depth I was almost transported there.I did feel it was a little bit slow to start, but once it picked up, I really didn't want to put it down.

title: On Her Own
text_review: A good storyline, but it takes a great deal of imagination to believe the storyline. The saving grace is the timeline- 1949 to 1969. In these times you can very well understand that a young girl could fend on her own. She has the townsfolk of jumpin to help her with food and clothes, and enough knowledge to help her through her life.One by one kya‚Äôs family left her. First her mom, then her sisters and brother. It was her father, a drunkard who drove them away. And, then, he was gone, and Kya had to figure out how to sustain herself. She had enough common sense and knowledge to learn how to cook and fish. She lived in her ramshackle shack by herself, but few bothered her. The local truant Officer came to bring her to school, where she was ridiculed, and she never went back.This is Kya‚Äôs story, how she brought herself up, how the black family helped her, and how she learned to read and write. The rest of her story is for you to learn.Recommended. prisrob 04-30-19

title: Beautiful
text_review: What a work of art Ms Owens has created here. The writing is so lyrical it's like listening to a 12 hour long song. The story sweeps you up, capturing your body, soul and imagination. I was on a journey with Kya, her loneliness was palpable at times and her evolution into a vital part of the marsh, until she genuinely was 'The Marsh Girl' was sad and heart breaking. Then you realise that, in fact, the marsh provides Kya the kind of safety and succour that no human ever quite matched. Ultimately, Kya finds a peace and happiness that most of us can only dream about. A remarkable book, exquisitely narrated by Cassandra Campbell and definitely not to be missed.

title: Evocative and memorable
text_review: I loved this book. I first became aware of it ,when I heard that Daisy Edgar-Jones had been cast as Kya in the film of the book. Daisy was brilliant in Normal People, so I was keen to read the book about a future role she would be doing.When I went onto Amazon to look at the book, I was amazed at the number of reviews. It was over 125,000 at the time (now 135,000). Correct me if I'm wrong but I think this is the most reviewed book ever on Amazon, by quite some way.Yes the detractors will say it's implausible, but for me it's a beautifully written love story and murder mystery, combined with wonderful descriptions of the natural world.The courtroom scenes at the end genuinely had my heart racing, and the ending is a good twist.All in all a fantastic read, and I can't wait for the film

title: It was..ok
text_review: For someone who isn't big on nature, the novel certainly turned that around on me which I appreciated and I was able to get lost if you like in the way in which Owens depicts the marshland scenery through her language. I also found the whole first half of the novel compelling and sad in telling of Kya's upbringing and how she became to be the way she was. However the second half of the book I found the book lost its pace and in the end the plot became rushed. I don't think it lives up to the hype of these reviews.

title: Bestseller for a reason
text_review: I almost was not going to buy this book based on the amazon & goodreads negative reviews, but received this as a gift.  It was a little slow to begin with, but I was glad that I stuck with it, as it then became a page turner.I have never read a story about a girl growing up in the marshes, it was unusual, strong themes of abandonment, prejudice, survival, love/friendship and surrounded by nature.  My verdict on the book is, it was an enjoyable read and I could immerse myself in the story and the setting, I like to be able imagine where the character is and I had a good picture of this.

title: Don't get the hype
text_review: I don't often write reviews but I just had to for this book. No offence to the author but it was absolutely awful. I am very open minded when it comes to fiction but this was so boring. I made it to the end of the book but only because I read it for my book club. The characters are so undeveloped and the whole plot is completely unbelievable. I really don't get the hype.

title: Definitely not a book to read in lockdown
text_review: I was rather disappointed by this book and slightly mystified by the description of this book as 'just lovely' by all my friends. On the one hand, it is beautifully written - a haunting elegy to the redemptive power of nature and a beautiful love story. On the other hand, it was a total downer with its main themes of abuse, abandonment, prejudice and isolation. I had to take a two-week break in the middle because I was so depressed by the whole thing: this poor child abandoned at the age of six - first by her mother, then by all her siblings and eventually by her alcoholic, abusive father - and left to fend for herself.  Although she eventually makes something of herself due to the kindness of an older boy, who teaches her to read and shares her fascination with zoology and biology, her loneliness and isolation permeates every page of this book.  Definitely not a book to read in lockdown, particularly not if you live on your own! I also found the characterisation somewhat lazy and predictable: prejudiced, small-minded, predatory white townsfolk versus the kind, warm-hearted black characters, Jumpin' and Martha, who take pity on the poor, motherless child - her 'otherness' equating her with them.  Not my idea of a 'lovely' book at all.

title: Amazing
text_review: I understand why this book received the many accolades it did.An incredible tale of a young girl being left to fend for herself in the swamps of Mississippi basin. Being left first by her Mother and then her Father made her grow up fast and fearless.Se experiences both happy and unhappy friendships with boys.I found the fact that given her unfortunate background her ability to write and publish books seemed a little far fetch.However that is what story telling is about.Eventually settling down with the love of her life after the wickedness of a former boyfriend leads to a happy ending,or was it?

title: Fantastic read best read for years
text_review: Beautiful fantastic read please take no notice of negative reviews about it being unrealistic a girl fending for herself etc. I just don't think they have a good sense of what this book does and how it's meant to be fiction written in the best way possible. Books are meant to take you to a story that creates atmosphere and happiness sadness and mystery This book does all that and more. Read and enjoy it's not meant to be non fiction who ever thought it was with such negative reviews need to look at the factual section of books.

title: Loved the first part but hated the last few chapters
text_review: I loved the beginning of this book but hated the end.  Everything in the middle was entertaining enough but it fell short for me - but I often feel this way about over hyped books though.  The bar of expectation is raised so high that it's almost bound to fail.Kya's story was incredibly sad at the beginning and it was part 1 of the book that moved me the most.  The last few chapters felt rushed and I wish that the author hadn't felt the need to tie up loose ends.  I'd rather have left some of the answers to my own imagination!

title: Good but not perfect
text_review: I resisted buying this book for a while as the reviews were fairly polarized.  And some of the negative reviews suggested to me that I wouldn't like it.  However, in our third lock down I was desperate for something light and easygoing to read.  And to be fair that's what I got.  It's nicely written, the story is mostly engaging, and all in all it whiled away a weekend.  I think the author should have had the confidence to concentrate on the main story line (the young girl fending for herself, educating herself and becoming an expert on the wildlife in her very specific area of the country) - it was strong enough on its own to carry the book, and had she concentrated on that she would have been able to do it more justice.  It really didn't need the extra plot line of a suspicious death.  I'll try the author's next book (if there is one) in the hope that the quality of the writing continues but the author has confidence in her story telling and doesn't get led off down side tracks and over complicates things.

title: A lovely heart warming story
text_review: I loved this book from the minute it started, true it's hard to believe a child could fend for herself from such a young age, but not beyond the realm of possibility. The narrator was fabulous and there was so  much feeling in the story telling. The story flowed so well and the characters were all well written, you could imagine the way Kia was treated by the town folk. The description of the marsh with it's flora, fauna and amazing birdlife was fabulous, you could picture the beaches, waterways and everything about the area. Brilliant writing look forward to the next Delia Owens book.

title: A mixed bag
text_review: I listened to the audio book version (excellent narration) Not sure I would have stuck with it had I been reading it. The positives: beautiful writing about nature and it made me want to know more about the Carolinas (? Correct spelling) negatives: wondered if slightly implausible that a young child would be able to survive alone for so long and would a rickety shack have stayed upright so long .... just s few of the many things that seemed a tad unlikely. Maybe that‚Äôs not entirely fair on the author, it is after all, a work of fiction. Overall, enjoyed it.

title: Loved this
text_review: Well goodness me - never seen so many reviews almost re-telling the entire story !  And so many dissenters - Yes it was implausible.  But how many books arent?  I dont mind fanciful if theres also an abundance of skilled, thought provoking writing.  Im still reeling at the real life prejudice in the backwaters of the U.S. in relatively recent times.Nor did I see the ending telegraphed at all!  I was absorbed from start to finish and enjoyed every single page.  For a first novel it was stunning !!!

title: Breathtaking.
text_review: What a fabulous read. I went through a whole range of emotions. Although the style is more descriptive than I normally like, it fitted well, and painted such a picture of Kya's life and environment that it became part of the story. For most of Kya's young life I felt uncomfortable as a reader that a child was forgotten about to such an extent. As the story went on I felt nothing but admiration for the resilience of the human spirit. What a wonderful person. I held my breath during most of the trial and thought I knew what had really happened - until the very end. I'm so glad our book club chose this to read.

title: An extraordinary and brilliant achievement
text_review: This is one of the most beautiful and moving novels I have ever read.  It is brilliantly paced and constructed.  The way the events of different periods intertwine gives it a terrific momentum, making it a book that can barely be put down, it is so compelling.  The backdrop of the marshlands and their wildlife is unique and extraordinary.  And then, at the heart, we have the amazing story of the Marsh Girl and her heart-rending experiences that lead up to the final story of the murder of Chase Andrews, Kya‚Äôs trial, the restoration of Tate as her true and constant love, and the final d√©nouement.  Crawdads ranks with ‚ÄòThe God of Small Things‚Äô written by Arundhati Roy many years ago, which set a new standard of story-telling.  Like ‚ÄôSmall Things‚Äô, ‚ÄòCrawdads‚Äô portrays a woman as victim in an unusual location, with a marvellous sense of time and place, wonderfully drawn characters - good as well as evil - and unexpected twists and turns before the final episode.

title: Oh! It's gender war diatribe.....
text_review: You will be familair with the "daddy-issues" formula before you open this book but this one is so far-fethched it makes the Jungle Book look like a documentary, but has nowhere near the charm.Blah, blah blah....neglectful drunk of a father unable to cope ith life in the "swamp" (geddit?).Blah, blah, blah six year old child is so much more mature....so sensitive and intuitive and nurturing and earth goddess and etc etcCliche-riddled pap that appeals to a tedious demographic!

title: Ecology with a sting
text_review: The wildlife is all-embracing and the description deeply poetic, but the social world breaks in with rape and murder, and the effect so shocking that I had to start reading the book all over again.  It is hard to believe in the accomplishments of Kya - naturalist, artist, poet, survivor - until one remembers the genius of autistic savants.  I thought the Sheriff and his assistant were just there for laughs until I was jolted into taking them seriously.  An astonishing literary achievement!

title: A tale of escape and adventure
text_review: This is such a readable story following Kya's life from abandoned little girl to feted wildlife writer and beyond. There are passages of touching descriptions, time passing and wistful desires as Kya is left to fend for herself and grow up very much alone.She discovers who her true friends are and the extent of her powers as time passes and events happen that shape her life and those around her.I enjoyed being wrapped in a very different life for the duration of the book, and being surprised by the ending.

title: Beautifully written, includes everything from marginalisation to human relations, to nature
text_review: Absolutely amazing. The author brilliantly describes isolation and the environment in which the protagonist lives in. The book successfully describes feelings of loneliness and how it feels to be jilted and marginalised based on your looks, poverty and the myths of the ‚Äúother‚Äú.  I have never been tearful about injustice but this book really manages to capture it beautifully, leaving you angry and sad about the predicament of the protagonist.  The plot twist at the end of the book really ends the story beautifully and I couldn‚Äôt have asked more from the book.

title: I didn‚Äôt want it to end
text_review: I absolutely loved this beautiful story which I purchased as an Audible audio book. I initially found the narrator‚Äôs voice a bit irritating (but I often do) but soon warmed to her.It is such a gentle story which I never wanted to end. The landscape was so beautifully described and woven into the story that I now desperately want to visit the marshland. The main character is so well put across. I found myself snatching every spare moment to press play on my phone and listen to a bit

title: An engaging debut
text_review: I enjoyed this book and I think that for  a debut novel it's pretty good.  The author really brings the marshland to life, as you would expect from someone who writes nature books.The ending is quite predictable in my opinion and I agree with some reviewers that the dialogue is a bit stilted and cumbersome at times but I was hooked.I'm always a little wary of books that attract a lot of hype and high ratings but on the whole I was not disappointed with this.

title: A truly wonderful read
text_review: I completely loved this book and it had me entranced from beginning to end. You really took Kya into your heart: the balance of her mature strength and yet with such childish innocence  made her such a compelling character. I also loved some of the support characters such as Jumpin and Mabel, they really helped to bring the book alive.The descriptive detail really made you feel like you knew the town and the Marsh but it never went so far as to override the narrative. This novel had charm and heartbreak in equal measure and I adored it!

title: Very slow starter that evolves into a fantastic story
text_review: Reviews for this book are at opposite ends of the spectrum. It is so slow starting that I very nearly gave up. Many others do. But I didn‚Äôt. The story evolves so well and without the leisurely build up I doubt what unfolds would hit you like it does. I read the last quarter in one go before work for 2 hours. Just couldn‚Äôt put it down. The end was very emotional. I don‚Äôt think any book I‚Äôve read had such an emotional impact at certain points. I‚Äôd recommend this one. But it does start very slow so if you want instant action, try something else.

title: Enjoyable, despite my two stars.
text_review: Not sure why some Amazon reviewers give away virtually the whole plot, but those who have may save you the task of actually reading the book.Here, nature is well observed by an author who clearly knows her subject, and often beautifully described,  but the idea of a marsh girl growing up and fending for herself without serious mishap, or adult intervention,  is totally unbelievable.  Also unbelievable is the idea that said 'marsh girl' is self-educated to such a level as to become a respected and published writer and illustrator in her chosen field.The 60s was a tumultuous decade and I found the almost complete lack of reference to events like the Vietnam War or the Space Race annoying too and just compounded the lack of plot cred.However, if you allow for artist license, it is still a good read and despite the two stars, I listened to it on Audible and it kept me company on some long walks, and I was interested as to what happened and I am sure Reece Witherspoon will do a good job with the TV rights if she has them.Lastly, I really do wish I could read a contemporary novel one day which doesn't involve the main protagonist becoming a best selling writer/published author. Such a hackneyed plot device.

title: A beautiful book that will always have my heart!
text_review: After seeing this book everywhere, I couldn‚Äôt wait to get my hands on it. From the synopsis I was intrigued to feel the emotions that are woven throughout the story. Emotion is a key to me enjoying a book, the deeper the emotional eruption whilst reading a book, the more I know I will love it. And my gosh‚Ä¶this book did just that!¬†From the first sentence, Owen‚Äôs writing was bursting with spirit. It felt like I was secured in a vacuum of energy and as the story progressed the pulse of the vibrations grew and grew. This vibrancy allowed my mind‚Äôs eye to embellish the world in which the characters existed, down to being able to visualise the very fine details of the many birds, shells and feathers Kya loved.I fell in love with Kya from the moment she was introduced to us. She is shy and timid but also one of the strongest characters I have ever known. Although Owen‚Äôs describes to us Kya‚Äôs psychical beauty through words, if you look deep enough you will also find her inner beauty. Hidden in her love and understanding for the marsh and her silent exchanges with the wildlife.‚ÄòWhere the Crawdads Sing‚Äô is a story of love and loss. It exposes to us both the negative and positives that come with solitude but most of all‚Ä¶if we just take a bit of time to get to know those we see as outsiders, maybe we will see that they are worthy of love to.

title: An exquisite piece of writing
text_review: There is something old-fashioned, and rather uplifting, about this exquisitely written book. Okay, it is pretty easy to pick holes in the plot but, so long as you suspend your cynicism, it flows beautifully. It is not intended to be a Michael Connelly forensic crime thriller. I am a 69 year old man, and I suspect that I am not the intended target audience, but I absolutely loved it. I wish I could find more of this quality of writing. Delia Owens and Ivy Pochoda are my finds of 2019.

title: Aw I really loved this book...
text_review: Aw I really loved this book...I found the start of this book a little slow but at the end I couldn't put it down and read it all in a couple of days... And I don't often do that.It's a light story with heavy undertones to it. Breath of fresh air, freeing, pleasant and from the start you just want well for the kid, which the author just makes you feel for her from the start!Even though you want and feel this book will have a happy ending it just keeps you turning the pages literally until the very end which I was impressed with.I like a nice story, Im not going to go fact checking each detail there is no point. The author let me live the story with Kya and I enjoyed it so much.

title: What a beautiful, beautiful book
text_review: My favourite novels tend to be those which tell a great story in wonderful prose; a central character (and many others) who I feel I get to know personally (or wish I had); set in contexts and surroundings which teach me things, while affecting me deeply.This is one of those books. From the off, I felt I was present in the story, at the place, with the characters. And, long after putting it down, my mind still wanders back there. To the marsh and swamplands of North Carolina...Another one please.

title: A beautiful story
text_review: i had this book sitting on my kindle for a while before I started it as it didn‚Äôt really seem like my type of book. I bought it because of all the glowing reviews and I didn‚Äôt want to miss out.Anyway, how wrong I was. I was so intrigued  by Kya from the very start, and although nature hasn‚Äôt really interested me in the past, I absolutely loved reading about the setting. As the story continues, we grow to love Kya and feel every pain she does. I just wanted her to come out on top but I won‚Äôt spoil it for you.A truly lovely story and very well written. Five stars from me.

title: Perfect escape from stressful times
text_review: Despite some very poor reviews I took a chance on this and I‚Äôm glad I did,sad and beautiful story set in the 60s and 70s,includes the awful social and racial prejudices that were openly rife in these decades, I will remember Kya,Mabel,Jumpin and Tate for a long time as they were so well developed I felt I knew them,brilliant read if u need to escape reality for a little while....apparently being made into Hollywood movie which I can‚Äôt wait to see

title: The nature writing is the best part
text_review: The author tells a story of a child growing up in extreme loneliness, an outcast from society who must depend on herself for survival. She has a strong interest in nature and animals and understands these better than people. I'm guessing that the author is very much telling her own life experience of social rejection using the swamp context and adding in a murder plot line. She describes the pain of that loneliness in the beginning quite well, as though she has experienced it herself. It is also quite clear from her writing of dialogue that she has poor insight and understanding of people's behaviour, thoughts, and motivations and it makes for strange and unlikely dialogue, particularly between the main character and her love interests. In the midst of all of this, she writes in intense detail about the creatures of the swamp and this is where she excels. The book also features an unusual focus on bird feathers which was interesting but a bit too much. I would not be surprised if the author is somewhere on the autism spectrum actually. I think she did well for her first book however and hopefully she will develop her ability to write about relationships in her future endeavours.

title: Not for me
text_review: Beautifully written with some wonderful characterisation, I have to be honest and say I think it has been a little over hyped.The story starts well but then seemed to drift and I found myself skipping bits. I loved the descriptions of the marsh and its wildlife but aspects of the story left me cold.I really wanted to enjoy this but I wasn't rushing to pick it up.

title: Beautifully written.
text_review: There are so many reviews that I don't see the need for another. The writing is so vivid I felt and smelt and saw all life in the marshes. Truly a memorable book. One little error that I find extraordinary from an author who is obviously a respected scientist - you do not feed bread to birds. They can't digest it and it can kill them. And, I hate to admit this, I don't think the ending works. Leave the death of Chase as unsolved; more believable.

title: It‚Äôs not literature - but it is a nature bath for covid isolation
text_review: I am surprised by the number of negative reviewsThis isn‚Äôt literature and the hype has been immenseBut it has good plot and the setting is  evocative - the North Carolina marshes are perfect for U.K. covid isolation dreamersThe beginning, with a little girl abandoned by her family was very clearly drawn ... I could see that family , their home, smell their foodI found it  hard to put down !

title: WOW, just WOW, Best book I have ever read
text_review: I feel all grown up, I have read a book and posting a review. After asking everyone to review my books I feel it only fair I join in.My review of, Where the Crawdads sing - Deliia Owens 5 Massive StarsWhere do I start, well it is the best book I have ever read (listened to) yes, but this comes with a caveat as I have only read 17 books in my life and written two which I know is weird. What I learned as an author is the way the marshland and Kia's journey was described, simply superb.We grow up with her, a little girls journey to womanhood, living through what she had to put up with and all of what life threw at her. There are two stories going on in two different timelines, Kia growing in front of our eyes and a murder which happens much later. As the reader we are teased with bits and pieces of information as the two timelines are set on a collision course. I cant say to much more about the story but don't want to spoil it for you, it might be a little long in parts but the way the march is described and the array of colourful characters that touch our hero's life can't fail to drag you in. I think I need to up my game, As a non-reader I commend the author for helping me fall in love with reading again, soon to be a film I here, I cant wait.Simply wonderful, storytelling at its best. Well done Delia, take a bow, masterpieceA nod must also be given to the narrator and that southern Deep South drawl, loved it

title: Must read
text_review: Having heard so much about this book from my fellow book buddies in the US- I knew I needed to read this book.I started reading this book as part of a book reading group. However sadly I had to leave the group because I was so far ahead.It is a story that is a true page turner.It is about a girl called Kya  a 6 year old girl is left on her own. People that she is/was close to have left her.Chase Andrews turns up dead.I dont want to reveal anymore but there is plenty to get your teeth into.Murder, mystery, abandoment.  So much it just leaves you wanting moreHighly recommended

title: A Captivating Story
text_review: I loved this book. It was one of those books that captivate you so much that you cannot  put it down. The depth of description that went into the main character was excellent. The description of the Marsh, indeed that of the whole natural world, was so good, it cleverly created a vivid picture in my mind.The exploration of loneliness and poverty was well thought out, disturbing but equally heartening.This is a book that stay with you, I would highly recommend it.

title: Riveting and memorable
text_review: Wow - what a story. I'd heard good reviews about this but it took me a while to warm to buying it so when ! finally came across it in a charity bookshop, I decided to dive right in. The story is unusual. Owens creates a vivid picture of her protagonist Kya and I wasn't sure what to make of it all at first but the more I read, the more I needed to know where it was all going. And I wasn't disappointed. A riveting and memorable 5-star read and one of my favourites so far this year...

title: Uniquely brilliant.
text_review: This was a gift to me and I have to say it would not have been one I would normally have chosen myself  but it was simply stunning. The further I got into the story the more intrigued I became. The background details of the marsh land where it is set are detailed but not over done to spoil the flow of the story. And the ending?? Well it deserved more than the 5 points I can give it. Read and enjoy!!

title: Lovely book
text_review: I loved this book , perhaps the marsh girls achievements were a little exaggerated but the general story line is different and interesting , I was sad to finish and really didn‚Äôt see the twist at the end until it happenedPlease take a moment to push the helpful button and make my time typing up and reviewing worthwhile ü•∞

title: Mud girl
text_review: A 6 years old, who has experienced trauma and abuse, is competely abandoned by everybody and starts eating dirt and charcoal, turning into a beautiful woman whose main purpose is to shag the pretty boys. When she is 14 the pretty boy teaches her to read and write within a few days and she starts speaking like David Attenborough. Also there are 2 black people that are there just as decorative stereotypes, probably shaped around dr Owens very own idea of black people. So the mud girl marries one of the pretty boys and kills the other one, and she manages to get away with it. She also publishes a number of biology books, written all on her own.At the same time you are asked to feel for her because she is discriminated against, just like the marginal black characters. Yep, Delia Owens thinks that in the segregated south a poor white woman and a black person have interchangeable experiences.There is also a bad poetry subplot and some marsh descriptions, bit it's mainly about a mud girl who wants to shag.

title: The Magic of Beautiful Writing
text_review: Delia Owens‚Äô Where the Crawdads Sing is a novel that literally took my breath away. It wasn‚Äôt a perfect book ‚Äì I‚Äôll get to a couple of criticisms later ‚Äì but it was profoundly moving, exquisitely written, believable in an unbelievable kind of way and, in some parts, as compelling as a thriller. I suppose it could be defined as a modern-day fairy tale, with all the grit and dark edges of authentic, uncensored fairy tales ‚Äì the good and bad, the love and hate, brutality, beauty and ugliness ‚Äì but with the added plausibility of real, rugged earthiness. It was a novel that made me feel alive; that made me look at my own existence in a different way. Here was a writer who knew how to write about love, loss and solitude in a manner that resonated with me wholeheartedly.In a nutshell, Where the Crawdads Sing is the haunting story of Kya, better known by the narrow-minded local villagers as the ‚Äòmarsh girl‚Äô ‚Äì a child who was abandoned by her impoverished family and forced to live entirely alone, fending for herself in a tumbledown shack on the wild coast of North Carolina. It is a story of love found in unexpected places; it‚Äôs also a story of inner-belief and self-development. Ultimately, it's a story of hope and determination: about the will to live, to be loved, and to persevere against all odds. There are two concurrent timelines that interweave throughout the novel ‚Äì one of them in 1969/70, the other in the 1950s ‚Äì until eventually they both converge into a powerful denouement. The modern-day timeline follows the development of a murder enquiry; the earlier timeline centres around Kya's childhood and her growth into womanhood.Personally, I‚Äôm not someone who is mad about nature - although I like it enough when I behold the first buds of spring peeking out from the dormant soil in my back garden. Yet in the pages of this novel I found the author‚Äôs descriptions so seductive, at times it really was as though I was actually there, in that marshy, muddy, tangled, utterly lush coastline that permeates the entire story. It was only after finishing the novel that I read up about the author, and when I realised that she‚Äôs a scientist, then I said, Ahh! to myself, smiling in that hugely satisfying feeling of it figures! Generally speaking, I try not to read an author‚Äôs bio before finishing their book, because I don‚Äôt like being influenced in any way. I‚Äôm a firm believer that the characters and storyline in a novel should speak for themselves, and that the reader should not be aware of the author‚Äôs presence at all.This brings me to one minor criticism. I don‚Äôt like mixed point of view, and this book has a quite lot of it. For me, I would prefer the author to disappear entirely, so that the pages of her book can be occupied purely by her characters. They are the ones who should manipulate the reader, not the author. And when you are forced inside the thoughts of more than one character at a time, within the same chapter, that‚Äôs when the authorial presence takes over. Get out! I want to yell. Let me be alone with your characters!The other minor criticism I have is that the final quarter of the novel turns into a courtroom drama, which I felt was a little too long and somewhat out of keeping with the mood of the rest of the story. But at the same time I was still glued to the pages, so I‚Äôm not even sure if this is a valid criticism.But the very fact that, despite those two criticisms, I still feel compelled to give this novel a five-star rating, shows just how deeply I fell in love with it. When you‚Äôre truly besotted with a person, you don‚Äôt care about the faults in them, right? You know they‚Äôre there, but somehow, you just overlook them. That‚Äôs the magic of love.When the Crawdads Sing was true magic for me. I am infinitely grateful to Delia Owens for having lighted up my life for the too-short time that I was allowed to be part of her marshy, lonely, at times cruel, yet ultimately beautiful, world.

title: Excellent audio book
text_review: The narrator of this book is excellent in that she has the correct accent and intonation for the story and brings it all vividly to life as she reads.  I love the authors beautiful descriptions of the North Carolina marsh area in particular the physical geography and birdlife.  There is a good solid storyline weaving through the book and I am thoroughly enjoying this listening experience.

title: Not worth the hype.
text_review: I so wanted to like this book because I have a lot of friends who said it was absolutely wonderful and you felt you were right in nature. So, I thought I was in for an absolute treat. I started to read it and felt as if I was in a swamp up to my neck. While the descriptions of nature and the natural world are very good the plot is not believable. I felt a little connection with the characters and the murder mystery seem to be shoehorned into the last section of the novel. And as for the dreadful poetry. And the ending. I hate to give up on a novel. Especially one recommended by so many people.. But I wish I had saved myself the time and read something much better.

title: Quite good but quite live up to the hype
text_review: I was interested to read this book because of the huge number of sales. While this was a nice coming of age story it is over-hyped. For me there was too much description of the surrounding North Carolina marshlands which slowed the story down somewhat. I preferred the second half of the book particularly the court scenes and the twist at the end. I believe this is being made into a film which I look forward to seeing.

title: Not great
text_review: What utter dross! I had great hopes for this book having read the many positive reviews, but after persevering I now wonder if I read the same book as everyone else. A whimsical tale which requires the reader to suspend disbelief throughout in order for the author to concoct a conclusion that had me laughing out loud. If you‚Äôre looking for some escapism from the pandemic this is your book - otherwise, save your pennies.

title: Stunning
text_review: I bought this book a while ago because of the media hype, however the reviews were somewhat conflicting which is why it‚Äôs taken so long to read it.  WOW! Total emotional roller coaster. Fell in love with the characters, the book is so beautifully written and is so visual, don‚Äôt know if there are any plans for a movie? Would make a great one. Totally recommend can‚Äôt wait for the next book by this author.

title: Who knew words could paint such stunning pictures?
text_review: Incredible. I couldn't quite get into it at first but I persisted because there was something about the story, the writing and how well the author describes everything, as if you were really there and it's stunningly beautiful, that made me not want to give up quite yet. I was not disappointed. I found myself rooting for the characters, smiling and close to tears at several points in the story. Delia Owens paints absolutely stunning pictures in Where The Crawdads sing and this is definitely one I will never forget.

title: A memorable book
text_review: I thoroughly enjoyed this book. It is a bit slow to start with, but when you get into the book, it is unputdownable.It is one of those books, that stays with you. I have recommended it to friends as it so good. One friend wants me to pass it onto her, BUT i want the book back as it is one I would like to keep. (There is not many I like to hold onto!)

title: Mixed feelings
text_review: I was looking forward to reading this one for so long and heard such good things, but had very mixed feelings, some nice evocation of the natural world and environment, but some important parts of the story were so very rushed when I wanted them explored much more carefully and needed more depth, especially the family estrangement, other parts really dragged along when I wanted it to move on, and sometimes it irritated me.

title: Great descriptions but unbelievable story
text_review: If I could, I'd have given this book five stars for wonderful descriptions of the marsh where our heroine, Kya, lives and for making me feel the claustrophobia of the inland waterways and the freshness of the sea when Kya went out in her boat. Kya loves nature and all things natural and I'm certain the author does too because her enthusiasm for the scenery and its wildlife is what brings this book alive.But the characterisation is cliched in the extreme and the storyline is unbelievable to the point of making me struggle to finish the book because it's so frustratingly cliched and naff. If you're the kind of person, like me, who likes their books grounded in reality, then I'd recommend approaching this as a fairytale set in an unusual and beautifully described setting, that's probably the best way to approach this.

title: Try it...you will not be disappointed
