text_review: I find it difficult to believe that some readers failed to enjoy this book....I thought it was an absolute masterpiece!A six year old is left abandoned by her family and has to fend for herself in the swamps and marshes of Carolina.Her story, though deeply sad and haunting, is believable and thought provoking.The descriptions of wildlife is exceptional and well worth reading.Unputdownable....

title: I never wanted this book to end
text_review: This is the most wonderful book I have read for a long time.  I deliberately took it slowly, savouring the beautiful, vivid descriptions of the swamps and wildlife.  The characters are totally believable and I felt for Kya as if she were my own daughter.  It is beautifully structured with the movements forwards and backwards in time.  The plot unfolds gradually and you are left in suspense until the very last moment.I loved it and am so sad that I have finished it.  Only those without a soul will not enjoy this incredible first novel.  Thank you Delia Owens!

title: What does Kya learn from the marsh?
text_review: I was given this book as a birthday present.Kya, the marsh girl, experiences betrayal by so many people. She is laughed at and never allowed to join ‚Äònormal‚Äô society. When there is a murder in the area who will be accused? This is a beautifully written book about a girl who experiences isolation but finds beauty and comfort in nature. I‚Äôd highly recommend.

title: Sad and haunting tale
text_review: I read this story feeling a depth of emotions. It is a very sad and haunting tale following the life of a girl who feels wrong prejudice  from the town she lives in and all she did was lose her family and carry on trying to make a life in the marshes where her family home was.I can't recommend this enough!. You must read it!!

title: Nature versus narrative
text_review: The author certainly has an eye and way with words when detailing the natural world, but for me the dialogue and story-telling were quite poor (Pedestrian prose, questionable poetry and unrealistic plot - including the court case  which inevitably lead to a conclusion drained of emotional power unless you enjoy the mawkish kind) - suprisingly so in contrast to some of the more beautiful  descriptive passages depicting the local flora and fauna.  Shame, as I was seduced for the first third but fell out of love as plot/character began to lose credibility... still I'm clearly in the minority here so you may want to give it a try...

title: A book about human and animal life and love. Superb!
text_review: My wife had recently read this book, and she recommended I do the same. I rarely read my wife's books but I thought I'd give it a chance, and I'm glad I did. It written in a very deep and descriptive way, a little like Anita Shreve. I found it very enjoyable, I didn't want it to end. I hope they choose the right director and cast for the film. A superb read.

title: Dialog from a toddler!
text_review: Great story. Great characters. Well described scenes.  Sadly, this is as far as it goes. The dialog is infantile in its naivety. Frankly laughable conversations go on throughout the book. I simply can‚Äôt recommend this book to any lover of novels. At best, it‚Äôs just a bit of a daft distraction.  At worst, it‚Äôs a waste of time and money.

title: Far and away one of the best books, if not THE best book I have ever read
text_review: Simply had to write a review for this book. Far and away one of the best books, if not THE best book I have ever read. Everything about it is simply beautiful and I can‚Äôt ever remember a book that made me feel so emotional and connected to a character. A truly moving and captivating story that transports you straight back in time to the marsh lands of the North Carolina coastline. I loved this book so much and I think I loved Kya even more. If you haven‚Äôt read this already, then please do. I promise it won‚Äôt disappoint.

title: One of my favourite books this year...
text_review: I put off reading this book for a long time, as it was being hyped everywhere and I didn't want to be disappointed but I'm so pleased I got over my inhibitions and just read it. It was such a good read, beautifully portrayed, and written in an eloquent style that really matched the slow passage of time in Kya's rural life. It's sold as a murder mystery, with the supposed killer made very obvious from the start. Whilst I love a good 'who dunnit' I was pleased that the murder was not the sole focus of the book, but rather we learn more about the life of the marsh girl and how she survives and thrives in her world. It was both brutal and brilliant, and I would heartily recommend it!

title: Compelling story
text_review: I‚Äôd heard a lot about this book and wasn‚Äôt sure it sounded like my kind of thing but decided to give it a try. I‚Äôm so glad I did! I found it a bit slow at first and as a British reader I found it difficult to get my head around the accents but I stuck with it and ended up being totally hooked by the story, the prose and the character of Kya. It‚Äôs not like anything I‚Äôve read before and it‚Äôs difficult to compare with anything else... it‚Äôs a murder mystery, but also a love story, it‚Äôs kind of mystical and compelling. It has ended up being one of my favourite books I‚Äôve ever read.

title: Audible book
text_review: I have never considered Audible books before but I took advantage of an offer and I can honestly say it added a certain something to an extraordinary book. Possibly hearing the accent added an extra dimension ?? One of the best books I have ever read/listened to and I would recommend it to everyone.

title: Unputdownable
text_review: Disregarding the obvious suspension of reality that creates the initial vehicle for the story, which I forgive, this is a beautiful book.  The writing and imagery is stunning and the artistry of the whole is something rare.A lovely work and would cause much discussion at a book club.Beautiful.

title: Best read for a while!
text_review: I understand where people who think this book is rubbish are coming from! However I found it well written, knowledgeable and  quite gripping. It‚Äôs the first book in a long time to reduce me to tears and unlike some I found it quite believable.  I would read another by this author without a doubt.

title: Highly original and engaging.
text_review: Slightly slow to 'warm up' but stick with it as you are gradually drawn in to the place and time the story is set. Kya is hard to identify with at first, but the reader begins to feel an affinity for her as you are drawn into her unique circumstances and the mystery surrounding the death of her former lover. By the end of the book, I was really rooting for her and feeling admiration for the life she had made for herself against the odds. Atmospheric and engaging.

title: rendingly beautiful book!
text_review: This book is in a class of its own.  Somehow Delia Owen's words sing through your veins as you read it. It is a song to nature, to the naked soul and the storyline is exquisite, the two main characters strong and credible, yet other-worldly at the same time.  I will take a pause, then read it again....

title: Average
text_review: Plot has been summarised in many other reviews and at times was quite compelling. However the overly poetic, flowery descriptions throughout were too much for me and I sometimes felt I was reading a Mills & Boon. It‚Äôs a murder mystery in part and that‚Äôs what kept me going to the end - which felt a little predictable.

title: A modern classic
text_review: This book is so exquisitely written, I have never read anything that depicts the beauty of nature so vividly and in such sharp contrast to the ugliness of human behaviour. The parallels between the natural world and the human world are very poetically and subtly conveyed. It is a very moving tale of one woman‚Äôs bravery and refusal to be a victim and I absolutely could not put it down. It felt like I was reading a modern classic. I hope the movie makers do it justice.

title: When the reader sings
text_review: Always sucked in to novels set in the Deep South.  At this time of virus isolation, looking forward to reading a novel that pulls you in, stirs your reactions, makes you a little more than just another reader.  This novel has so many reviews, you don't want anything more from me.

title: Awful!
text_review: I had high hopes initially given the reviews and after seeing this book everywhere! Oh dear! Cliched story of po‚Äô white trash with a drunken daddy and abandoned by the rest of her family, who raises herself out of the swamp only to be accused of the murder of a local ne‚Äôer do well. I‚Äôm afraid the ending was predictable and the writing very much inspired by Harper Lee but no where near as articulate, sensitive or gripping. I‚Äôm glad I didn‚Äôt buy this book (lent to me by a neighbour) but wish I‚Äôd used the time to read something better!

title: Loved this compelling and original novel
text_review: What a fantastic read this was. I sat up until 2am to finish it I just couldn't put it down. Such an unusual setting and written in a way that made you feel as if you were there. I loved it. Sad poignant and uplifting all at the same time. I recommend you ignore the bad reviews of those that "didnt get it" and see for yourself into the life of Kya Clark.

title: Complete escapism!
text_review: I loved this book! Yes, the plot is somewhat unlikely, but the description of the world inhabited by the Marsh Girl was nothing short of inspiring. I have to say, I was not a fan of Ms Owens‚Äô grammatically incorrect descriptive sentences. Jarring, cringe-worthy and far too frequent. Call me old-fashioned, but I thought sentences were supposed to contain a verb? Despite this annoying style, the book fully deserves its five stars for its beautiful portrayal of a solitary girl who was able to live happily with gulls as friends and who had nothing but the pursuit of a complete understanding of her environment for fulfilment.

title: Disappointing
text_review: I was expecting a fabulous, fast page turner, after reading the reviews from the online book club. Unfortunalty, it was not to be. It was a slow plodding story.

title: An emotional beautiful read
text_review: Such an emotional read. Beautifully written with such vivid descriptions of Kya and her home. A story of survival, grief and hope. I lived through every step of her journey and willed her to succeed. This is the kind of story that will stay with me for a long time.

title: Beautiful Book
text_review: What can I say, an absolutely beautiful read.  One of the best books I've read since Eleanor Oliphant is Completely Fine, where you quickly fall in love with the main character.  Really didn't want this book to end.  It got me through Lock down!  The author is a nature lover and writer, and it shows.  Very beautifully written.

title: A must-read!
text_review: I absolutely loved this debut novel by Delia Owens. She is so insightful about all things nature; which is beautifully woven throughout the story. Kya's compelling story is one of strength and endurance and shows how connected we all are to nature and the world aroundus.  Delia's portrayal of little Kya 's character right through to adulthood is so so well done that I had to remind myself many times that it was fiction. I found the book heartbreaking, heartwarming and inspiring all at the same time. I just wish she had another novel to quench my thirst for more.

title: Beautiful and emotive storytelling at it‚Äôs best
text_review: I felt compelled to write a review after the most recent negative ones were at risk of putting people of reading this novel.As a journalist and editor I can truly say this was a poetic read and a masterclass of simple yet stunningly evocative writing.I was fully immersed in the story from the first page and felt like I was reading a novel that would be talked about for decades to come.It was a joy to read and I cried real tears when it came to an end. I haven‚Äôt read a book like this in a long time and I would encourage anyone debating it to give it a shot.

title: Such a good book!
text_review: I‚Äôm not one to read novels as I feel they are all very predictable. This book is amazing. I literally could not put it down. It has such a original story unlike any other book or film I have seen before. The writing is beautiful and the book has twists and turns you could not predict. I loved it.

title: A beautiful story in every way
text_review: Such a wonderful book.  If I am reading a book, I will skip descriptions (boring!), and being an Audio book, I almost didn‚Äôt purchase it because the description is that the book is full of descriptive script.  So glad I got it because it was such a beautifully written book - I loved the story and the words in between.  Wish it didn‚Äôt end!

title: Disappointed
text_review: Found the story unbelievable, albeit well written. Rolled my eyes a lot whole reading, but I did finish it so it wasn't terrible. Struggling to understand the hype so perhaps I'm missing something, but I just found the people so unrealistic, and too neatly packaged as Good or Bad. Not for me.

title: Good read
text_review: Finally decided to read this book after picking it up and putting it down so many times. Took a while to get into it but so glad I persevered as I loved it and didn't want it to end. Think it's a book you will either love or hate but definitely give it a chance.

title: A magnificent read
text_review: This is the best book I have read in ages, so wonderfully descriptive you can feel the humidity and smell the atmosphere.  I couldn't put it down, a story that is so beautiful, touching and sad with a twist at the end and although I guessed it I wept and wept when I finished it.  Buy it you won't be disappointed.

title: Not good
text_review: Am shocked at all the five star reviews. This book is extremely far fetched with loads of unexplained storylines. It drags on and I was ready to scream at the end because of its slowness. I'm giving it two stars because of the basic idea but really it's not good x

title: READ THIS BOOK - TODAY!
text_review: Now this is how you write a book! truly beautifully written. I don't usually give long or character reviews , but Kya deserves to be noted.  Unputdownable . I loved every word written. Ms Owens has an amazing talent. I am still sad that the book is finished

title: Best book I‚Äôve read in years!
text_review: Without giving too much away, this has a bit of a To Kill A Mockingbird‚Äô vibe about it and o adored it. As much as I love reading a book that is so exceptional, I hated it when it ended as I felt lost without it- I was completely immersed into this world and wasn‚Äôt ready to leave. Also, just when I was worried that the ending was going to be a bit too easy, the author came through in the last through pages and smashed by doubts with an excellent ending that fitted the novel perfectly. I adored everything about this!

title: A *Marmite' book - love it or hate it
text_review: Utterly captivating, unputdownable, that's how I found it.  Strong characters, utterly convincing environment, gripping story.  Why haven't I given it 5 stars? Well, it is fiction but even so it is rather unbelievable if you care to dig deeper than the shallow. Feral child, however bright, is unlikely to self-teach biology to that level and Really could she have written those books? From a 'noble savage' aspect it works but probably goes too far for the sake of the story. The reviews already show that people love it or hate it and I totally get that.

title: One of the best books I‚Äôve read in a long time.
text_review: I loved this book. I thought the prose was stunning and the descriptions of the marsh land really took me into the main character‚Äôs world. There was also a page turning plot to go with the beautiful writing.I literally found it hard to put the book down and intend to read it again , which I rarely do with any novel! A truly remarkable read.

title: A compelling read.
text_review: Couldn‚Äôt put it down! I became so absorbed in the characters I found myself worrying about them when I wasn‚Äôt reading! I had to know what happened next. A beautiful, sad, compelling and poignant story which is told with true skill and flair.  A must read!

title: A great read
text_review: I really loved the book.It's sad at the beginning when the father is beating everyone. It's sad when Kay is on her own.Her life in the swamp, is also sad, her being on her own.But it's also full of love. Her love of the swamp, her love for Tate and Jumpy.

title: Beautiful, emotive read
text_review: loved this book, beautifully written and a wonderful story that has twists and turns right until the end. It truly transports you to the marsh land setting and a different time where poverty and prejudice were rife leading to the isolation of a little girl. I really enjoyed that this story walked us through her whole life not just leaving us wondering when the main thrust of the novel was worked through.Definitworth a read.

title: A pleasant listen
text_review: Throughly enjoyed delving into another part of the world with this novel on Audible. I couldn‚Äôt stop listening to it while I had a young baby to care for at home during lockdown. It helped pass the days and take me to another place, with the lovely voice of the narrator and interesting story.

title: Brilliant read
text_review: Excellent  book, not my usual but I really enjoyed it.  A lot of description around the marshes and wildlife etc which was great. Also highlighted prejudices we build up before we give people a chance.  Should be made into a film.

title: The  book is a story with some learning of great interest.
text_review: I loved this book . Some people seem to have mistaken it for history  or geography.It is a Story. There are plenty of books where things are not possible.  Films also. Sky Trek and oo7 films,for instance. Actors are mistaken for world savers!  If only that were true.

title: Not for me
text_review: I heard so many reviews about this book good a d bad. My opinion is I didn't enjoy it at all, I wasn't unimpressed with the dialogue and the plot was nothing to write home about, sorry not for me. But I'm sure there will and are people who think its wonderful.

title: A superb and astounding read
text_review: Beautifully written, refreshing , captivating with a poignant ending that leaves you reflecting long after the pages .So descriptive was the narrative my escapism to the marsh and its wildlife felt very real ..A fantastic and unique storyline ...one of the best novels of the year ..

title: Very moving
text_review: I thought that this was a very moving, emotional novel. I thought that it was very sad in places,especially how everyone left Kya to survive on her own. Its a beautiful love story as well as a mystery. The descriptions of the scenery is really moving and vivid.  I enjoyed it very much.

title: Touching, beautifully written - literary fiction at it's best
text_review: Such a gorgeous book, recommend it to anyone. A mysterious death is the underlying story running through this novel, but the book is so much more. Kya Clark, known as the Marsh Girl raises herself in her patch of marsh in Northern Carolina. Kya can rely on few people, but some are on her side.Her story is touchingly and beautifully written. Delia Clark's story will stay with me for a long time. One of the best books I've read in a long time.

title: Brilliant book!!!!
text_review: This book was very well written - so much so that I could picture in my mind's eye every detail of the marsh and the creatures that lived there. It's not often that I write a review but I really enjoyed reading it so I felt that I had to write something.

title: Beautiful masterpiece
text_review: This is a perfect bildungsroman - love story - crime story and guide to naturalism all in one. I loved the vivid descriptions of the marsh and natural world of North Carolina. Through this novel I got to inhabit a world I will never physically see but one that I now know so well in my imagination.

title: 41k + reviews for a reason. A Brilliant, and Beautiful Book!
text_review: Reading the description didn‚Äôt make want to read this book, it was the sheer number of reviews. And I‚Äôm so glad I did. This has gone to my number 1 spot of books read ever. Beautifully descriptive, takes you to the marsh itself. Highly recommend a read.

title: Badly written
text_review: This could have been an interesting story but sadly it is so badly written that any potential is lost.  The central character. Kya, is made up of every cliche going.  And the other characters are very one dimensional.  A real disappointment.

title: Wonderful!
text_review: I loved this story. Beautiful descriptions of life and nature in the marsh, a wonderful character in Kya and an intriguing mystery too. Listened on Audible and loved the narrator's soothing, gentle voice.

title: An exceptional book
text_review: One of the best books I have ever read in my 74 years.  Very enjoyable  and hard to put down.  The story telling was fantastic and the wildlife information tremendous.  I feel I have learnt a lot!

title: a beautifully written book
text_review: I love this book, such an interesting read, the nature descriptions come to life. (of course the author knows her nature).  This will stay in my mind for a long time.  Really like all the characters especially Jumpin'.

title: A wonderful book
text_review: I‚Äôve been waiting a long time to read this book and it didn‚Äôt disappoint. I made sure not to read a single review or any details about it, so that it didn‚Äôt need to ‚Äòlive up to the hype.‚Äô  It‚Äôs beautifully written and I‚Äôm almost sad to have finished it.

title: A good story
text_review: I'm giving this 5 stars because I read it in one day; that's how addictive I found it. I agree with all the bad reviews too but as a story it swept along and kept me interested all through.

title: Not bad, not brilliant.
text_review: An absorbing book, starts off well so that you want to continue. Good writing, the descriptions are beautiful but sometimes repetitive and not always relevant. Characters and plot not well developed at all.

title: A must read, wonderful book
text_review: I have just finished this fantastic book. I loved it from start to finish. Beautifully written and completely absorbing. I couldn‚Äôt recommend this highly enough, best book this year and I‚Äôve read plenty.

title: A wonderful, lyrical story. Outstanding.
text_review: I guess That I can't add much to the praise already heaped on this book It is simply the best novel I've read in years.Utterly believable, beautifully written and a credit to the author.

title: Wonderfully compelling...
text_review: I found this a little difficult to get into at first, but later found it so compelling I struggled to put it down. Wonderful characters and story, and an impressive debut by the author.

title: Better than expected for such an over-hyped novel
text_review: I borrowed this book from the library as I truly expected to ditch it by 50 pages in.  But it was a good read, an engaging story and I liked the ending even though it made me cry (and that's rare). It is over-hyped as it's nothing amazing, just a good read.

title: Where The Crawdads Sing
text_review: This is one of the best novels that I have ever read and I would like to congratulate it this talented author and thank her for the many hours of pleasure reading this book gave me.

title: Superbly written.
text_review: An excellent read, superb insight into human feelings and relationships. Once started it's difficult to put down. I was swept along with 'the marsh girl' and her isolated lifestyle.

title: A sensational debut novel. Moving and beautiful
text_review: I have not been so moved by a book for years. Yes, some of it is a little predictable/unrealistic but it is a classic, heartwarming tale of human survival against all the odds. I found the characters well-developed and exploring the marsh from heroine Kya‚Äôs perspective was breathtaking. The author‚Äôs writing style and descriptive prose are thought-provoking and fresh and her handling of suspense was excellent. Ms Owens, you have a rare gift and will have touched so many lives with this book! Keep writing!

title: Absolutely stunning
text_review: I loved every page of this book. Listened to it on audio and the narrator was perfect. A stunning piece of writing. Huge thanks to the author for the joy I had listening to this.

title: One of the best novels ever!
text_review: Really one of the best novels I have ever read.  I literally  could not put  this book  down. The twists and turns and the way the characters are developed is truly astounding. Long after you have finished this book, it will stay with you . The nicest thing I can do is encourage everyone to read this.

title: Heartbreaking but Beautiful
text_review: Got this book as a Mother's day gift, was'nt sure what to expect...but I loved it! It was heartbreaking and beautiful both at the same time and I loved the expressive way in which it was written. Well done Delia Owen's I will be looking out for the next novel.

title: too many plot holes
text_review: easy read but didnt live up to hype. Too many aspects of the plot seemed implausible or far fetched. Overall I liked the writing style although every now and then descriptions of nature felt like lifted directly from a text book which jarred with me.

title: Ignore the Naysayers - this book is a delight
text_review: I don't usually write reviews but I thought I would in this case after seeing a few negative reviews, which I thought was a little perplexing. I read a fair amount of fiction and find quite a lot unremarkable if I'm honest. Occasionally I read a gem that is original, gripping and well written and Crawdads ticked all those boxes. I loved it and would encourage others to read it too. My husband read it after me and was equally impressed.

title: Excellent read
text_review: I‚Äôm not going to analyse story lines or how realistic this book is. What I thought was it was a very good read. Able to escape from the tedium of lockdown into a different world.Will recommend it to my friends.

title: Best book i have read in a long time
text_review: I was recommended this book by book club.  I just loved it. The story line was unusual and the characters were so engaging.  I felt like I was there observing it all from the sidelines.  Great descriptions and believable characters.  I particularly enjoyed the ending.

title: Absolutely brilliant
text_review: Loved this audio book so much, I was completely immersed in the story the whole time and could really visualise what was going on. I loved it that much I want to buy the actual book for my bookshelf - a must read/listen! Fantastic story and setting.

title: Great read!
text_review: This is a great read, a coming of age story about the Marsh Girl. I felt sorry for Kya, her parents were terrible and just left her to fend for herself.I enjoyed the relationship she had with nature but at times I felt the book was a little bit drawn out.Thanks to NetGalley for my copy.

title: Compelling & beautifully written

title: Brilliant book. beautifully written

title: Fascinating novel

The terrain was well known to me and extremely well captured in words and tone. Deep, sensitive and evocative.

title: Well you either love it or you hate it
text_review: I loved it - wonderfully evocative writing with a good story thrown in - ok so Kya's lifestyle might seem a bit implausible to some but so what - it's a story and one that starts in 1952 - a work of fiction - and it doesn't claim to be anything else. Loved the poems too.  Look forward to the film and future books by this author.

title: Good read once you get into the first chapter.....

title: Great Fiction

Read it  and have a box of tissues at the ready.

title: A tale of survival
text_review: I kept seeing this book pop up on Amazon (some might argue that's just good marketing!), and the cover drew me in, it intrigued me to find out what it was about. I have to say I have read a lot but never read anything like this book. I kept reading into the night to find out what happened next. Some parts of the book were slow and it's hard to believe a child could be left to fend for themselves but that's exactly what happened here with Kya.Feeling safe a lot of the time but sometimes vulnerable, I would say you easily slip into Kya's shoes ... but she didn't actually have any and even went shopping bare foot. Her resourcefulness was impressive and it was amazing to witness her as she bloomed into a woman and then  beyond.If you want a book to take you on a journey then this is for you, it's a true escape and sometimes it turns ugly but from the dead body on the very first page, I was hooked on this novel. It made me question what is actually important in life, how to escape the rat race and also how important it is to do things that make you happy.

title: FIVE STAR REVIEW (@crosslingreads)
text_review: Delia Owens: Where the Crawdads Sing.*‚ÄúI wasn't aware that words could hold so much. I didn't know a sentence could be so full.‚Äù‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏èThis book was perfect.üìöThe descriptions were beautiful and immersive. I‚Äôve never been in marshland, yet I feel like I can picture exactly Kya‚Äôs shack and the landscape she calls home. Owen‚Äôs attention to detail was astounding. The intense, descriptive language slowed down the pace of the story- while it made reading slower, I don‚Äôt necessarily think it‚Äôs a bad thing.üìöI thought the use of time was really interesting. The novel moves across the years, between 1952 and 1970, bouncing back and forth and skipping many months at a time. If I‚Äôm honest, I didn‚Äôt pay close attention to the actual months and years. They were noted as chapter headers, but I think the passage of time was evident from the writing itself, and most of the time I was so invested in the storyline that I didn‚Äôt look away from the actual body of the text. It worked really well though, and provided a really interesting insight into why Kya is the way that she is.üìöOn Kya: she is definitely one of my favourite female protagonists of all time. She was strong and smart, which I liked, and her flaws, fears and struggles evoked an emotional response from me. I was sad and worried and frustrated for Kya, and wanted her to be safe and happy, which I think is a clear sign of a well-written character (or I‚Äôm just overly-invested, oops).üìöI loved the ending. It was the happy ending I always crave, made bittersweet with death, continuously exciting with the satisfying reveal of secrets, and an easy finality. I put the book down and was really, deeply happy.

title: Enjoyable, albeit forgettable.
text_review: Kya is left abandoned as a child in her family‚Äôs shack of a house out in the marshes of North Carolina. ‚ÄòSwamp girl‚Äô or ‚ÄòSwamp trash‚Äô is how the locals in the nearest town refer to her.She lives out the majority of her adolescence and 20‚Äôs in solitude and isolation, never going to school, with only the local gulls as company, and occasionally a visit from Tate, a friend of her departed brother.The story covers the formative years of Kya‚Äôs life, how she survives and thrives in her own little world and also her dalliances with love and desire.The story moves back and forth in time and we know from an early stage there is a sinister tale in the making.The story was an enjoyable intrigue and Owens did well to create a sense of being back in these marshlands of 1950-60‚Äôs North Carolina.However, the language seemed at times a bit overwrought for my liking although that could in part be due to the languid drawl of the narrator (I listened to the audiobook), which I‚Äôm sure is an authentic Carolina accent, but I found it distracting, and even irritating at times.Overall though it was a pleasant read but not one I imagine I will remember for too long.
